PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.
Senator Mason-Mr President, I seek leave of the Senate to ask you a question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —You may do so at Question Time. First, we shall have the usual procedures. However, you sought leave so I shall put the question.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Mason-It is a question to you, Mr President, concerning privilege.

Senator Carrick-Before leave is granted, could we have an understanding of the nature of the question which would be special so that it could be separated from Question Time and why it would not be pertinent to Question Time?

Senator Mason-Indeed, I can do that. It is a matter which follows up that question asked yesterday at this time. It relates to later events concerning constituents of mine, which I think concern a matter of privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give thanks to the Senate for its consent. My question relates to the closure, apparently, of King's Hall to visitors yesterday following the eviction of demonstrators in the early afternoon. In the evening some constituents of mine, including a Mr Paul Marshall and a Mr Rick Whyte, along with other people, were refused access to the House by security attendants, even though, they told me, they had tickets for booked seats to watch the proceedings of Parliament from the public galleries. Subsequent inquiries by my office suggest that all visitors, whether they be lobby groups, tourists or constituents with appointments to see their elected representatives, may have been refused access to King's Hall. I ask whether this is so. If so, was it at the direction of yourself and Mr Speaker? Even allowing for the eviction of the demonstrators early in the day, would you agree, sir, that this appears to breach the right of our citizens to meet with their representatives and the right of senators and members to speak with their constituents in that place? Can the Presiding Officers establish a guideline regarding access to King's Hall after eviction of demonstrators that will not deny access to others who have had nothing to do with such demonstrations? I ask, if indeed there is some restriction on visitors to King's Hall, how long will that continue?

—In the circumstances which prevailed yesterday and after the eviction of the demonstrators in King's Hall, King's Hall was closed to further visitors other than those who desired to meet an honourable senator or a member of the other place. The attendants on duty, I understand, were advised to contact the relevant member of the Parliament, whether a senator or a member of the House of Representatives. On checking with that member or senator that the person was known to him or her and that the member of Parliament desired to meet the person, it was arranged that the member or senator to be visited would go down to meet the visitor. Unfortunately, I understand that in your case, Senator Mason, that was not done. You were not contacted. I regret that that happened. It was a mistake and was not in accordance with the instructions which the Security Co-ordinator had given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 79 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned South Australian citizens respectfully showeth:
That the South Australian and Australian National Railways systems were intended to provide essential transport services to country, semi-isolated and isolated regions;
Australian National Railways' large increases in freight and parcel rates are forcing people to use Australia Post and road transport services;
Country businesses are suffering as a result of Australian National Railway's freight and parcel rate increases; and
At the direction of the Federal Government, the Australian National Railways Commission is destroying country rail services in South Australia;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will urgently review the freight increases imposed by Australian National Railways and require the Commissioner to:
reduce freight and parcel rates to reasonable levels and
encourage greater public utilisation of the Commission's services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: THOMAS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 93 citizens of Australia:

Your petitioners humbly pray that:
Cottages numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island be allowed to remain and to move only when the remaining northern end cottages do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 24 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 114 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
Australian families are being unfairly treated by the Government in respect of taxation and reduced value of family allowances.

We therefore submit that for the 1981-82 Federal Budget, all families should be permitted to split their incomes for taxation purposes and that the value of family allowances should be restored and indexed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on Plant Variety Rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the existing plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the taxpayer, and
6. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament defer introducing the legislation until full and informed public discussion of the issues involved has taken place.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
