PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That although cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island in no way impede construction at HMAS Stirling, they are now required by the Department of Administrative Services to move by 30 June 1981.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
Cottages numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island be allowed to remain and to move only when the remaining northern end cottages do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is a lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on Plant Variety Rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietary rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the taxpayer, and
6. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure:
(i) that information be made freely available to allow full and informed public discussion of the issues involved;
(ii) that the Government undertake to carry out an analysis of the cost and benefits involved to the various sectors of agriculture and the nation as a whole.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services, 1939-45 War, qualify as ''Australian Soldier'' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies, making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and, according to Acts and Regulations of the period, the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Air Force of the 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all ex-servicewomen of the 1939-40 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of the 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and garderners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Is the Government aware that any change in the price structure of the wine industry takes five years to adjust to? Grape growers and wine producers in South Australia estimate that a wine tax of 15 per cent would cost the industry $7m in lost revenue, would create further unemployment and would lead to financial hardships for the grape growers. Therefore, I ask the Minister whether an early statement can be made to refute the rumours of the imposition of a wine tax in the next Budget so that the wine industry can settle down to planning for future marketing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is aware of many attitudes that have been expressed by persons representing the wine industry with regard to the introduction of taxes, or the making of changes in regard to matters that affect that industry, but I am unable to make any comment that would pre-empt the forthcoming Budget. I am not aware of the five year period that the honourable senator states it takes to adjust to any changes, but I am conscious that frequently representations are made by the industry. I will make sure that the Treasurer is advised of the concern expressed by Senator Elstob, but I am not in any way able to pre-empt Budget decisions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORMER AUSTRALIAN PRISONERS OF WAR: WORM INFESTATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, relates to a statement in the Tasmanian Press of Friday, 29 May, by Mr Adyg Rockliff, a former Australian prisoner of war of the Japanese, warning that he has only just been successfully treated for a worm infestation that he contracted during wartime imprisonment. He has been advised by medical specialists that 75 per cent of surviving prisoners of war may still be subject to the worm, which is known as strongyloides stercoralis. Apparently the significance of the worm's ability to spread throughout the body has only recently been appreciated. Worm larvae migrations cause skin rash, which is intensely itchy. Successful treatment has been very recent. Has the Minister received requests from the Tasmanian Returned Services League conference for a call-up of former prisoners of war for testing? Has his Department indicated that it would or would not conduct such a call-up? If so, will the Minister seek to contact all former prisoners of war of the Japanese and advise them of their possible need for treatment for the strongyloides worm?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Archer for his question on this very important matter, which came to light at the annual conference of the State branch of the Returned Services League in Tasmania last week. I have not yet received a request from the State branch of the RSL to call up all former prisoners of war as was suggested in the article. As to whether an assessment of everyone concerned should be arranged, that has not been considered by the Department as no request for that to be done has come forward. However, the Department is well aware of the condition and has brought it to the notice of departmental doctors and also the 9,320 general practitioners throughout Australia who act as local medical officers for the Department.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department is also sponsoring a research project by Dr David Grove, senior lecturer in medicine at the University of Western Australia and a visiting specialist at the Repatriation General Hospital, Hollywood, in Perth, which is seeking to define the proportion of prisoners of war from Japan who still have infestation by the parasite, to simplify its diagnosis and to determine the efficacy of the form of treatment. The outcome of that project and the medical advice arising therefrom will be considered when they become available, and at that time consideration will be given to the need for further action. Of course that would include further publicity directed at ex-prisoners of war and to local medical officers. In the meantime it is suggested that any ex-POWs or any veterans who are concerned about this matter should discuss it with the local medical officer, or perhaps seek advice from the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health: Has the Government a policy supporting the establishment and maintenance of women's refuges, women's health centres and rape crisis centres? If so, should a State government fail to utilise its community health block grant to fund such centres, will the Government make provision to fund them in support of its own policy?

—Whilst it is not possible to commit the Government in advance to what might happen in a hypothetical situation, it is worth noting that the Budget Papers of succeeding years have indicated quite clearly the Government's record of support for the various facilities to which the honourable senator referred. It has been significant support. In earlier years I was involved in trying to help one of the women's refuges get under way. I think the record is there. The Government, over a number of years, has supported those centres for the benefit of the women who need them. The Government is concerned that the States should have the opportunity to take under their administrations those matters in the service area which they tend to do well. The Government is of the view that the States are likely to take up their responsibilities in a proper way, and we are working to that end.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question to get a specific answer from the Minister. Previously, the Queensland Government specifically refused to hand on Federal funds to women's refuges. Should the Queensland Government again refuse to do so, can we have a guarantee that the Federal Government will fund such refuges in that State, despite the Minister's belief that the States will respond in the way he thinks they will?
—The assurance which the honourable senator seeks would have to come from my colleague the Minister for Health. I will seek that information.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations agree that disruption to telecommunications caused by the present industrial action by the telecommunications unions is not only a threat to national security but also could endanger life in the event of a serious accident when an efficient telephone service would be essential? In view of the severity of this matter, will the Government give consideration to amending the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to provide for automatic deregistration of and/or heavy financial penalties--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. It has been the custom in this place, when disputes are being negotiated or are under review by an arbitration tribunal, for the subject not to be raised in the way that Senator Jessop raised it. In that circumstance, he might withdraw the question because the parties are meeting to try to resolve the question.
—Anything which would have an influence on that to be determined should be avoided.
—May I raise a point of order?
—A point of order has been raised. You make speak to it.

—I regard what the trade unions are doing in Australia today as quite irresponsible, particularly at a time when their case is before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I regard that as quite irresponsible action on the part of the unions, and I think my question is quite appropriate in its present form.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. I think this is very important. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is not a legal authority to which the sub judice rule generally applies, but it has been accepted that when a matter is before the Commission we should do nothing to interfere with or aggravate it, as you have just said. This case, as Senator Bishop has said, is being considered at a conference being held today before arbitrators, who have been appointed by this Government under an Act of this Government, for the purpose of settling this matter. The questioner should ask his question and do nothing else to aggravate the position. The parties may be willing to reach a settlement of this case but, after such propaganda as we have heard today and after such aggravation, there may be no desire for settlement. The parties may well be inclined to reject any reasonable course for settlement. I suggest that, in the interests of getting the telephones working again and getting us back to harmony in industrial relations, the question should not be allowed.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. I rather reluctantly tend to disagree with the point of order raised by Senator Bishop. I have a very strong view, which I put to you for your guidance in making a ruling, that there is certainly no sub judice rule involved. There may be, as the honourable senator suggests, a convention, although I doubt even that. However, having said that, I plead with the questioner and particularly with the Minister who has to answer the question that because of the incredible delicacy of the question it should be handled in a responsible way.
—Mr President, I take it that I can proceed. I am not speaking to the point of order, but I am quite happy to do so.
—Speak to the point of order.
—I broadly agree with what was said by Senator Chipp. Mr President, may I proceed to answer the question?
—No, I wish to rule on the point of order raised.

—Mr President, as you have not finally decided the matter, perhaps I can say that I think the matter is clearly within what is permitted by the Standing Orders. The matter is not subject to the sub judice rule, and if there is any stricture to be placed on anyone I would have thought it would be on me as a matter of good sense as a member of the Government not to say things which would be likely to reduce the prospect of the matter being dealt with reasonably by the parties.

—Order! In a matter such as this, as I have mentioned before, it is the spirit which should apply so as not in any way to influence a determination to be made. So it is not a matter subject to the sub judice rule as we would apply it normally. It is up to the good taste and judgment of the honourable senator to couch his question in a way which is not against the spirit of entering into discussion on a matter which could be adversely affected through such discussion.

—I will not repeat what I have already said. I just ask the Government to have a look at the matter of unionists taking action when their case is before the court. In any area of national interest some penalty should be provided to prevent the public being disadvantaged in that way. I hope the Opposition will agree with this: Will the Government also give consideration to an alteration of the Act to ensure that the Commission deals with disputes as a matter of urgency in these areas of national interest and within a prescribed period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has raised a matter which I think is in the minds of many Australians who are concerned about the potential effects and, indeed, the effects already of the Telecom dispute. On the latest advice I have, the present situation is that the parties have been engaged in private conference in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I think it would be common ground around the chamber that we hope that progress is being made in that private conference. It is a fact that industrial disputes of this sort give rise to great public concern because of the potential damage they can do to individuals who might be affected. The honourable senator referred to some of the sorts of difficulties which can arise. In those circumstances, again I hope it would be common ground that either the parties will come to an agreement which is within the guidelines which have been laid down or they will submit to the processes of conciliation and arbitration which are available to them.

ANSWER.PARA: The only other point I wish to make is that it is inevitable that, when the public of Australia is subject to difficulty and to inconvenience because of an industrial dispute, questions are raised about the adequacy of the existing mechanisms, rules and so on which we have. Inevitably suggestions will be made for change and for improvement of them. It is scarcely surprising that, in the present climate and in the present context, suggestions of the sort made by the honourable senator should be put forward. I would say no more with respect to the particular suggestion than that I will see that it is drawn to the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations, when it can be considered in the cool and calm way in which these things do have to be considered. Indeed, we had complaints last night that the Government takes too long to consider some of these matters before acting, but I think it is a fact that the Government has shown that it is prepared to give very earnest and long consideration to suggestions of the sort raised by the honourable senator, rather than to move precipitately in an area and risk causing more difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the statements that he has made in the Senate concerning the necessity to ensure that insider trading is not facilitated by the Government by selectively disclosing information. I am referring particularly to his answers in relation to the Rundle project. Can he assure the Senate that information which could affect share values concerning Government intentions about broadcasting and television was not made available to News Ltd and Consolidated Press interests in the form of draft legislation while it remained unavailable to other industry or public interest organisations and the general public? If the Minister cannot give such an assurance, will he investigate the matter and make a full disclosure to the Senate?

—Whilst I can speak of matters that relate to my portfolio, I obviously cannot speak first-hand of information regarding that of another Minister. I will bring this matter to the relevant Minister's attention and seek his study of it and any reply he may see fit to give.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. By way of explanation. I make the point that responsibility for national economic policies flows from the Treasurer, through Cabinet, to the Prime Minister. What impact on Australia's economic growth would come from the democratic socialisation of industry, distribution and exchange as well as the establishment and development of public enterprises based on Federal, State and other forms of social ownership, to say nothing of the strategic social ownership of Australia's natural resources?

—There is clear evidence that the people of Australia and, indeed, business and commerce, when confronted with the threat of a government which may take steps within that kind of philosophy, refuse to invest, withdraw their funds and retreat from Australia. A classic example of that was the fall-the very rapid decline-in exploration for oil and minerals in Australia in the latter part of the period of office of the last government in Australia that professed democratic socialism. The fact of the matter is that the philosophy of democratic socialism is accepted by the majority of people as being based on an utter fallacy-that governments can do things better than people and that free enterprise is not the spirit of initiative but is something to be suppressed. For any political party today to pursue a philosophy which has been rejected out of hand and which has been proved wrong in this country and elsewhere is, of course, to fail to understand that it is a doctrine of disaster for the community and for the political party concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. On 13 May 1981 Senator Martyr asked the Minister a rather servile question. In part, the Minister's unrelated answer was:

QUESTION.PARA: The fact is that day to day a certain number of extremely militant union leaders are denying to the Australian people the growth and prosperity that in fact the resources boom should be giving to them.

The Minister, in his answer, honestly admits to his ignorance of militant unionists by saying that he does not care to read about them. I can only hope that his reading extends to such radical journals as the Australian Financial Review. I ask: Has the Minister made himself aware of the contents of four articles written by Bob Mills for the Australian Financial Review in reference to who owns Australia's mineral wealth? Does the Minister honestly believe that it is the militant unionists who are to blame for Australians generally not being able to share in the Government's so-called resources boom? How does the Minister explain his assertion that Australians have been denied benefits by the behaviour of these unionists while at the same time some massive multinational corporations are waxing extremely fat on our resources and the labours of these same unionists? Is the Minister's answer to Senator Martyr's question to be taken as an indication that the Government's policy on natural resources is loaded heavily in favour of overseas interests and is opposed to any major benefit flowing to the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to my comment about militant leaders doing damage to the living standards of the people of Australia, that is demonstrable.
—That is straight rubbish. Don't repeat it.

—I hope that members of the Australian Labor Party will express that view to the people of Australia, because the people of Australia know the truth. The great situation is to understand quite clearly that in saying what I have said I have made no reflection at all upon the tens, and possibly even hundreds, of thousands of moderate trade unionists who are decent Australians and who go about doing their jobs. My attack is upon the extremists, the communists and the neo-communists who have no interest in the well-being of Australia.
—Like the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

—Mr President, if members of the Labor Party are standing up for the work of the Carmichaels, the Clancys and the Mundeys of this world, let them come out and say so. Having said that, I am talking about the militant trade unions, the extremists.
—Like the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

—Senator Button, no doubt, is defending the actions of the Carmichaels and others, those who have brought Victoria to the stage of such a lack of electric power that it is forced to ration electric power because it cannot build its Loy Yang power stations.
—Tell us about the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

—Senator Button wants me to talk about the air pilots because he does not want me to talk about the strikes at Loy Yang or Omega or about any of the other great strikes by the militant and communist unions that have held up the people. Let him go to Victoria, his own State. Senator Button, a Victorian senator, is laughing about the plight of the Victorian people who are to be denied their jobs in future because the Loy Yang project was delayed for five months or more and brought to its knees. The answer to Senator McIntosh's question is yes, I believe, as do the people of Australia, that the militant and pro-communist leaders are interested in their destructive ends and not in the welfare of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the other parts of the question, the fact of the matter is that the Government is here to govern and to look to the interests of the people of Australia. Whether actions are taken by national or multinational companies, the Government's job is to see that the development of resources in Australia gives a true and fair share-a maximum share-to the people of Australia and that the return from the development of those resources by multinational or national corporations or others shall be a fair one. That is what we intend to do. This Government does not exist to govern for any self-interest. It governs in the interest of the Australian people. That is why, out of some 80 years of federation, governments of our philosophy have been returned for 60 years. For 60 years out of 80 years the people of Australia, who are the final jury, have said that the government that will govern in the interests of the people of Australia is a Liberal government.

All the attempts to mouth attacks on us, to try to associate us with national or multinational organisations, are the essence of nonsense. When the Whitlam Government was in power it had opportunities to take actions. It did not do so. In fact, it brought about high inflation and loss of employment. It showed that it was governing in the interests of a minority and not in the interests of a majority. Three times since the people of Australia have kept it out of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Communications seen reports in today's newspapers which refer to comments made by the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Mr John Norgard? Can the Minister confirm or deny Mr Norgard's claim that the ABC has been told that its non-salary expenditure is to be cut by 3 per cent in real terms next year and that there will be a reduction of some 130 jobs by June 1982? Is the Minister aware that Mr Norgard has indicated that such reductions will result in substantial alterations to important television and radio programs? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government recognises the importance of a public broadcasting authority to Australia? If so, and in the light of the reports to which I have just made reference including the report of the reduction, does Government policy relating to the ABC reflect the Government's philosophy of freedom of choice in this case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Davidson has a well known commitment both to communications generally and to the electronic media in particular. I pay tribute to the work that he has done, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, in relation to television services and standards which should apply. I have had my attention drawn to an article, and I take it that that is the article to which he refers. It is not the practice of government to outline specific Budget provisions prior to the presentation of the Treasurer's Budget statement in August. The honourable senator, as a senior member of the chamber, would know this and that I cannot offer comments on what any particular appropriations will be or are likely to be. However, I can observe that the Government has made some general decisions on the need to exercise restraint on overall expenditure and that means overall expenditure across all areas of government. These decisions have application to all Government departments and statutory authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot imagine that there is any way of asserting or being able to prove that the ABC is being singled out for any kind of attack. I am able to say that Budget decisions in relation to the ABC have not yet been taken. In fact, I am advised that Estimates discussions on ABC funding for the next financial year are still continuing. The Government has asked the Commission to justify its claims for those areas in which additional funding is sought. I think, in the light of the constraints which are on a government before a Budget, that probably answers most of the honourable senator's concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows his answer earlier today to Senator McIntosh's question. When the Minister referred to militant organisations which disrupt the Australian economy and services in Australia, did he include in those organisations the Airline Hostesses Association, the Australian Medical Association and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots? I further ask the Minister whether, in referring to people laughing during his answer to Senator McIntosh's question, he appreciated the fact that people may not have been laughing at the points he was making but rather were laughing at him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it as a great compliment that those people who support the pro-communist, pro-militant and extreme trade union leaders should find cause to laugh at me. I notice that Senator Button laughed at me.
—I am laughing at you again.
—We all are.

—Yes, I noticed that members of the Australian Labor Party laughed. If members of the Labor Party find joy in the actions, shall we say, of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia that are being revealed day by day in terms of bloody murder and violence, if they find joy in the Builders Labourers Federation in its duress and standover tactics, and if they find joy in unions such as the Seamen's Union of Australia with its bad record of militancy, let them laugh and I will proudly accept their laughter.
—What has that to do with your being a galah?
—My remarks which Senator McIntosh quoted were remarks directed to extremist left-wing--
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw your interjection. It is unparliamentary.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I am perfectly happy for the Labor Party to demonstrate to the people of Australia how it regards as frivolous the destruction by the left-wing militant pro-communist and militant socialist unions. Let Opposition senators laugh and let them sneer; we will proudly go on.
—Keep the red flag flying.

—Indeed, the red flag! Let me simply say that some of those leaders carry the red flag and, if Senator Button wants to march behind them, it is for him to do so, but he must take the responsibility then for the way in which those kinds of unions are crippling the capacity of his own State to develop employment and employability.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether those particular unions that Senator Button nominated were in my mind when I mentioned extreme left-wing, pro-communist militant unions. The answer is no. But, if I were asked whether I regarded the actions of the air hostesses as being irresponsible, the answer would be yes. The fact is that unionism itself is a great and a proud thing for Australia. The trade union movement, when it conducts itself in authentic industrial activities, is a fine institution for Australia. But every trade unionist, in looking to his or her own self-interest, must ensure that he or she does not hold to hostage the rest of Australia to gain his or her own narrow ends.

The test is that a strike ought to be the weapon of last resort. When it becomes a weapon of first resort or when it becomes a pattern of common usage, it is a perversion of trade unionism and, whether or not the union itself is one that is normally behaved, the union stands censured. The fact is that the people of Australia showed by public opinion polls and by their response to the media that overwhelmingly they condemned the action of the airline hostesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer follows upon a series of questions that I have asked in this chamber about my concern regarding bank mergers. In view of the ramifications and difficulties and the possible entry of foreign banks, can the Minister give us an assurance that the Treasurer will not give his blessing or approval to bank mergers in Australia until at least after the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System are made known.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not feel that I am able to give an assurance that the Treasurer will not make decisions until such time as he has the report of the Campbell Committee. The Treasurer has made some statements in recent days with regard to proposals for bank mergers in this country and has drawn attention to the section in the Act under which his approval may be sought. He did not, at that time, indicate that he would withhold any such approval or consideration until such time as he had the report. He did draw attention to the report which we expect to receive and which may make comment or recommendations on such matters. I can only undertake to refer Senator Watson's question to the Treasurer to see what response he would make to the specific undertaking which has been sought.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen recent articles in a number of newspapers regarding disapproval by the Association of South East Asian Nations of our abstention from voting in the United Nations on whether the ousted Pol Pot regime should be represented in international forums? Further, is the Minister aware that the Singapore Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Rajaratnam, said not only that Australia was playing into the hands of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Vietnam and had swallowed a sweetened Soviet Union pill, but also that the Government was trying to placate Mr Peacock and the Australian Labor Party with its actions? Believing that the Government would not wish to appear as though its policies are being influenced by the Soviet Union, Vietnam, Mr Peacock or the ALP, are we likely then to see the Government resume recognition of the Pol Pot regime in an effort to earn the approval of the ASEAN countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of matters have been canvassed in the question by Senator Sibraa. I will refer them to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and obtain a response.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Recently the Government began an extensive review of the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System, NUMAS, in which the Australian community, particularly ethnic groups, was invited to submit comments as to the requirements to meet changing conditions. Will the Minister advise the Senate of the stage the review has reached? Can the Minister give a broad outline of the Government's intentions following completion of the review?
—We asked that in the Estimates Committee under your chairmanship.
—Why don't you give us a statement later?

—Honourable senators might get some more information. In a news release on 6 March 1981 the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs stated that submissions from individuals and organisations would be sought and that public forums would be held in each of the capital cities. These consultations have been completed successfully with the Minister and the Opposition's spokesman on immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Young, or their representatives, attending each of the eight forums. Approximately 350 written submissions have been received. The information from these consultations, plus results of studies undertaken or commissioned by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, are being reviewed by an independent committee of prominent members of the community with expertise in immigration matters. The committee comprises Professor Charles Price, Mr James Samios and Mr Justice Gobbo. The findings of the independent committee will then go forward to the migration policy task force of the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs, which will examine them and make recommendations to the Minister. After consideration of the review by the Government, the Minister expects to make a statement to the Parliament during the Budget sittings.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It relates to last Friday's closure of Professional Employment Offices throughout Australia, in accordance with the findings of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee chaired by Sir Phillip Lynch. Were representations made by private employment agencies to have the Professional Employment Offices closed? Does or did Sir Phillip Lynch or any member of his family have any financial or other interest in a private employment agency or like organisation? If so, what are the details of that interest?

—I was not part of the original recommending process of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee that recommended this. I was part of the Cabinet decision-making process. I can state that the Cabinet decision, which was made by the full Cabinet, was made without any representations from anywhere and, as far as I am aware, no Cabinet Minister had any vested interest or pecuniary interest in the matter. I ask Senator Colston, incidentally, by way of answer to the question-he may answer in a supplementary way-whether he has any reason to believe that Sir Phillip Lynch or his family has any interest in such a private employment agency. I think it important because the tendency to ask rhetorical questions which can imply certain things is, I think, a bad one. I do not believe that any Minister has such pecuniary interests. I will seek that out but, in order to help me in the search, perhaps Senator Colston could put a supplementary question. Has he any information that he can give me?
—Mr President--
—Are you asking a supplementary question?
—I am not quite sure how to phrase the supplementary question.
—It must be relevant to the first question.

—Having been invited by the Minister to ask a supplementary quesion, I ask whether the Minister can check the question that I raised. There were rumours around the Professional Employment Offices that were closing last Friday that either Sir Phillip Lynch or his family had such an interest, and it is because of this that I think the matter should be checked out. More importantly, if Sir Phillip Lynch or his family does not have an interest, it is correct that the rumour should be laid to rest.

—The important thing is that Senator Colston indicates that he has no direct information but that he has heard rumours. Therefore, on the basis of rumours which are spread and which are usually found to be utterly false, I will check the information for him.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether he has seen a request by the Wartime Seamen's Association that its members, because of their great contribution and outstanding service during the 1939-45 war, be given a service pension. Further, I ask: Can the Minister say whether the Government has given any consideration to that request?
—He has had a deputation from Senator Elstob and the Seamen's Union.

—Yes, I have seen the request to which Senator Young refers. I have had a considerable correspondence with members of both Houses and also from outside organisations on the subject of service pensions for merchant seamen. Of course I acknowledge the interest of Senator Bishop in this question and also Senator Elstob, both of whom have brought deputations to see me in connection with the union movement which is interested in this matter as well. The question of the service pension for merchant seamen is a new one and would necessitate a new policy proposal by the Government; therefore it is a matter for the Budget. Consequently, I am unable to comment on it. As to the general interest in this area, I hope Senator Young will acknowledge the very worthwhile assistance given last year by the granting of free treatment in repatriation hospitals to some merchant seamen who in fact had been prisioners of war.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CABINET MINISTERS: DISCLOSURE OF PECUNIARY INTERESTS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and refers to the disclosure of pecuniary interests of Cabinet Ministers. It follows responses by the Leader to questions from Senator Primmer and me on 1 and 2 April. On 2 April the Minister told me that all Cabinet discussions were completely confidential. On 1 April, in reply to Senator Primmer, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a well-accepted universal practice for a Minister, when a discussion is taking place in Cabinet on a particular matter, to indicate to Cabinet any pecuniary interest that he or his family may have. This is done and is accepted as being done.

I ask the Minister whether that confidentiality applies also to Bills which have been drafted by direction of Cabinet. I am referring to Bills which have been discussed by the Cabinet in a preliminary way and directions have been given to Ministers to bring them into the House. Is the same principle applied in that sort of secondary situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically two mechanisms are followed. One is that ever since the Fraser Government came to office each Minister has been required to write a letter to the Prime Minister-I think it is kept by the head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Sir Geoffrey Yeend-disclosing to the Prime Minister particular assets and interests. That practice continues. The information is known to the Prime Minister and, I understand, to Sir Geoffrey Yeend. The Prime Minister is in possession of knowledge as to which Ministers have particular interests. Equally, it is the practice-I believe one that is totally observed-that, whenever a debate, whether at the primary stage or otherwise, takes place and a Minister taking part has an interest, that interest be declared. The responsibility to do so would be upon the Minister at any stage; the onus is upon the Minister to disclose his interest. In any case the interest would certainly have been disclosed in the material provided to the Prime Minister. As I understand it, when we implement the recommendations of the Bowen report, it will be the responsibility, subject to penalty, of not only any Minister but also any honourable member of the Parliament, to indicate an interest prior to speaking and voting, so that the world will know the situation. I believe that that would be a good state of affairs. If Senator Bishop has in mind a particular aspect that might be worth looking at, I would be very interested to know it. The Government is eager to draw up rules of ethics on this matter that will be as tight and practicable as possible.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, follows somewhat a question asked earlier by Senator Jessop. Has the Government examined the possibility of establishing a list of essential services throughout this country, particularly those in the area of the Public Service, in which workers would not have the right to strike until all alternatives had been fully examined? If not, will the Government study that suggestion?
—I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Industrial Relations for his consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PROJECTS FOR ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and relates to the environmental health projects for Aboriginal communities that were detailed in the Minister's Press statement of 28 May. Can the Minister confirm that the majority of the $6.7m that is to be spent on these projects will go to local and State government authorities and will not be spent in a way which will equip Aboriginal people with the skills to handle their own environmental health problems? For example, is the Minister aware that in the Malan community at Lake Gregory in Western Australia, the State Electricity Commission is to undertake the electrification of the bore although this is an area where it takes months to have a generator repaired? How does this kind of spending accord with the Government's stated policy of Aboriginal self-management in health matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's goal in funding this program-we have been asked to stop calling it the environmental health program; Professor Hollows has said that it might be better to call it an Aboriginal public health improvement program, and I think that there is some value in his suggestion-is to provide circumstances in which Aboriginal health can improve. That goal is advanced by providing clean water and waste disposal facilities. The question of Aboriginal training in a whole range of areas-the training of Aboriginal health workers or of Aboriginal communities in other skills-is, I submit to the honourable senater, a separate issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of the projects listed can be carried out only by existing services-provided sometimes by local governments and sometimes by State governments. In some areas we have tried to have certain of these projects put in place by non-government contractors. To do so requires the use of heavy equipment and a considerable network on the ground. We have experienced great difficulty in that regard. I have no worry about asking State or local governments to help us put these projects in place. Our thrust towards Aboriginalisation, which was set out in the statement of last week, is particularly in the area of the direct provision of medical services. It is in the provision of Aboriginal medical services, or Aboriginal involvement in relation to other health services, that we are pressing now for greater Aboriginal participation. If, in fact, the only way to get water to a community in Western Australia is to use the Public Works Department of that State, it is in the interests of the Aboriginal community that we should do so. We will continue to pursue the goal of better health for Aboriginals. I take up the honourable senator's point that we must also pursue the goal of training in a whole range of areas, but I submit to her that that is separate from the issue of providing clean water and waste disposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: Was there a meeting in Sydney on Monday between Professor Fred Hollows, Mr Gordon Briscoe, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs? If so, can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of that meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a meeting on 1 June at Kirribilli House in Sydney. I noted the public comment following the meeting and I welcome this opportunity to clarify some of the decisions which were reached at the meeting. Firstly, it should be made clear that no resignations were received by anyone from Professor Hollows or from Mr Briscoe. The trachoma program in which Professor Hollows was engaged is carried out by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists funded by the Commonwealth Department of Health. I am advised by that College that Professor Hollows offered no resignation to the College at any time. In any event, I am delighted that, following the meeting, Professor Hollows and Mr Briscoe agreed that they would not pursue their resignations or, as it turns out, their intended resignations.
—Were you at the meeting?

—I was at the meeting. I am saying to honourable senators that some of the Press reports as to what went on at the meeting are not strictly accurate. I am delighted that Professor Hollows and Mr Briscoe withdrew their resignations from the health program because that will advance the provision of eye health for Aboriginal people. It was decided that further discussions should be held between those two gentlemen and me to try to resolve some of the other major issues raised at the meeting, which was in fact a very useful encounter.

ANSWER.PARA: It became quite clear that similar goals are shared by the Prime Minister, by me, by Professor Hollows and by Mr Briscoe in several important areas and that there is considerable opportunity for co-operation in those areas. In particular, there was agreement that there is a need to advance the training of Aboriginal health workers. That relates somewhat to a question asked a moment ago by another honourable senator. I will be holding early consultations with my colleagues to try to advance that matter.

There was agreement that there is a need to adopt a co-ordinated program in dealing with outstations and I will be holding early discussions with Professor Hollows and Mr Briscoe on that. There was agreement that direct funding by the Commonwealth of Aboriginal medical services will continue. That has always been the intention, but it was made quite clear at the meeting. Indeed, I later confirmed it with Mrs Naomi Mayers, who is a representative of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. It was also made clear at that meeting that the Government was turning to the National Aboriginal Conference for formal advice on health, although it was made quite clear that it is up to the NAC whether it wishes to use NAIHO or any other body from which it seeks its advice. A decision as to whether NAIHO will have a role to play in advising the National Aboriginal Conference will have to await consultations between those two bodies.

I conclude by saying that any further funding of the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program will be a matter between the Commonwealth Department of Health and the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. I understand that the College has some proposals before the Department of Health and that the College will make its own arrangements in due course with Professor Hollows as to how any program will be conducted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is prompted by a question asked about 10 days ago at the behest of Australian citizens of Argentinian, Bolivian, Chilean and Uruguayan origin who want an update of our posture when dealing with those governments which are known for their pro-fascist style of government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —About 10 days ago, I think, Senator Mulvihill asked about civil rights in Latin America. At that time I undertook to get up to date information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister for Foreign Affairs informs me that the regime currently in power in Bolivia has virtually abolished trade union rights. There is no right to strike and no collective bargaining. The activities of trade unions have been curtailed and their funds have been frozen. The regime has threatened a number of international labour organisations by arresting or mistreating their visiting representatives. Acts of violence against individual trade unionists have been reported by Amnesty International. Australia, along with many other countries, is a major contributor to a number of organisations in the United Nations system as well as to the regular budget. These funds are used for a wide range of activities including, for example, technical assistance programs to aid developing countries.

ANSWER.PARA: Bolivia, Uruguay and Chile are among the beneficiaries of this assistance. The Government does not contemplate imposing sanctions against these countries. The Government has, both by direct representation to governments and in appropriate international forums, expressed its concern for violations of human rights wherever they occur and believes that considerations about sanctions are most appropriately and effectively dealt with within those forums. At the latest session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, Australia supported a resolution appointing a special envoy to visit Bolivia. He will, we hope, report to the Commission, at its next session, on the human rights situation in that country. Further action by the international community will be considered in the light of the special envoy's report.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MALAYSIA: WITHDRAWAL OF AUSTRALIAN MIRAGE JET FIGHTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In view of the current visit to Malaysia of the Minister for Defence, can the Minister comment on the Malaysian Government's reaction to the proposed withdrawal of Australian Mirage jet fighters from Malaysia over the next two years? Does the Minister see any weakening of Australia's position in the five-power defence arrangements as a result of the Australian withdrawal?

—The Minister for Defence has only just been in Malaysia and, as far as I know, has not yet returned. I will refer that question to him when he returns. I think the honourable senator may get a better answer after the Minister has had those discussions and is in a position to report on the result of them.

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will recall that, as a former member of a Senate standing committee, he was party to a unanimous decision which set out the manner in which government should collect statistical data on Aboriginal health, unemployment, housing, et cetera. Can the Minister inform the Parliament why his Government has virtually abandoned all surveys but, in particular, those dealing with health and unemployment?

—I recall the committee on which I served. I recall the fact that Senator Keeffe was its chairman. I also recall another committee-a Senate select committee-which finished the work that had been left incomplete and which was chaired by Senator Bonner. I also recall the findings and I recall that they were unanimous. I remind the honourable senator that one of the recommendations brought down by the Government last week in response to the reports on Aboriginal health was that we should move to a system of uniform collection of Aboriginal health statistics. Indeed, the model put forward by Dr Smith is to be taken up as a matter of priority by the Department of Health. Not only do I remember the recommendations, but also we are seeking to implement them. In relation to the reference to unemployment statistics, I refer the honourable senator to the Hansard record of last week where I answered a question on that point at some length.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether the health statistical records will be collected by the Commonwealth or the respective State governments.

—At this stage I am not able to say. The Commonwealth Department of Health is charged with developing, as a matter of priority, a system for collecting adequate health statistics along the lines of the model suggested by Dr Smith. I am not quite certain of the role of the Commonwealth qua the States, but I will seek that further information for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether he saw the article in today's Australian entitled 'GA leaders step up fight against leap in charges'. The first paragraph of that article reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Prominent general aviation industry figures have ridiculed a study supporting Transport Australia's quest for a greater recovery of costs from general aviation.

Is the Minister aware of the widespread alarm and consternation in the general aviation community at the gross inaccuracies in this report? Will the Minister assure the House that no attempt will be made to implement any of the recommendations in this report until a competent inquiry is held to determine the true costs of general aviation in this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not seen the article to which Senator MacGibbon refers, which is in today's issue of the Australian. However, I am aware of the general concern felt by the general aviation industry as to the contents of the various reports. I am advised that the Minister will be considering the various views of organisations in the general aviation industry quite deeply during his total consideration of the matter. I am unable to give the assurance which Senator MacGibbon seeks. I will need to refer that part of the question to the Minister for his comment.

—Has the Attorney-General seen the report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald that the Security Appeals Tribunal, which was established a year ago, has received only two appeals in that period and that the lack of work is driving its permanent staff of one, Mr Fred Hawkins of the Attorney-General's Department, up the wall-according to Mr Hawkins. Can the Minister confirm the accuracy of this report, if not so far as Mr Hawkins's sanity is concerned at least so far as the number of appeals that are at issue? Will he acknowledge to the Senate that the main reasons for this shortage of appeals are, first of all, the existence of his own certificates, which foreclose the possibility of appeals in any cases which the Attorney-General does not want to go to the Security Appeals Tribunal, and moreover without his telling us whether he has issued a certificate; and secondly, the lack of retrospective application of the legislation establishing the security appeals procedure? We further acknowledge that the Opposition was dead right in its suggestions at the time that this legislation was enacted, that the procedures should not be limited in this way. Will he undertake to proceed posthaste to enact appropriate amendments to the legislation so that this security appeals procedure ceases to be the charade that it has obviously now become?

—I did see a reference in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald to the question of appeals to the Security Appeals Tribunal. I cannot confirm exactly how many appeals there have been or what lack of appeals there has been. I have no reason to doubt that that advice was correctly given to the reporter by Mr Hawkins. However, I will check it to make sure that it is correct. I certainly know that there have been very few appeals to the Tribunal. I do not propose to give any information in relation to some of the matters raised by Senator Evans. I think that would be in breach of the rule the Government usually adopts on these matters. I do not accept his suggested reasons for the lack of appeals. I think he might have regard to broader reasons as to why there may be few appeals. The reason is probably largely due to the sound administration of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.
—How do we know that if you will not tell us anything about it?

—I am suggesting that that is the most probable explanation for this. I do not believe this justifies any review of the provisions of the Act. I do not think there is any further comment I should make at this stage in relation to the question. However, I will check on the accuracy of the figures that Senator Evans has raised.

—by leave-During Question Time today Senator Carrick claimed that Labor members on this side of the chamber-to use his words-supported bloody murder. I take personal offence at that accusation. I place on record the fact that I have always been a law abiding citizen and that I do not countenance bloody murder under any circumstances.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PETER BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate on 27 May Senator Robertson referred to a situation which developed under the Community Development Employment Project at Bamyili in the Northern Territory. He asked whether if I would arrange for bridging finance for the project to ensure continuity of employment. The honourable senator will recall the circumstances in the question. In my reply to the honourable senator I confirmed that the Bamyili Council had spent in 11 months the funds allocated for the project in the 12-month period to 30 June. This meant that until the beginning of July no funds were left for the 63 people who were previously entitled to receive income under the project. I pointed out that the reason for the shortfall was the Council's management of the funds available.

INTERJECT.PARA: I wish to inform the Senate that within the last couple of days-I think it was yesterday-I approved an arrangement whereby funds available to the Bamyili Council this financial year will be topped up by $30,000. That is, the allocation for 1980-81 of $250,060 will be increased to $280,060, on certain conditions. The amount being provided will be deducted from next year's allocation. I am informing the Council that my Department will conduct a review of the whole CDEP project at Bamyili by 31 July. I am concerned to ensure that funds made available to Aboriginal communities are spent in a proper manner. I think the honourable senator was correct in saying that he was not worried about where the blame lay as long as the Aboriginal people did not starve in the meantime. I hope that we have been able to achieve that end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I wish to make a personal explanation. For some months now I have been concerned about the sensational nature of the media coverage of what has been described as the agent orange issue. I have indicated consistently that I believe there are great dangers in the manner with which these most important and sensitive matters have been presented. The nature of the coverage has distorted the debate to such an extent that I believe large numbers of veterans, their families and friends and the public are being caused deep and unnecessary anxiety. Furthermore, I have been at pains to suggest my firm conviction that the issues here are far wider and more complex than the very narrow focus of whether or not agent orange and other herbicides have had the claimed effects. I have been concerned also that the Government's comprehension of its responsibilities with regard to Vietnam veterans is acknowledged as genuine and sympathetic and goes far beyond a total reliance on the epidemiological study which is being mounted at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention, Mr President, to a segment on a television program entitled 11 AM which was shown on Channel 7 in Sydney on 26 May 1981 as an example of quite inadequate and inaccurate presentation which would continue to contribute to the public being misinformed on these issues. I had been advised some time before agreeing to be interviewed for this program that it was to be an opportunity to bring various areas of question up to date in the public's mind and I agreed to the interview on that basis. In that interview I answered quite frankly a number of questions and I had hoped that the import of my answers would receive proper coverage. What eventuated were selected statements from my interview, interspersed with comments particularly by Senator Chipp. I acknowledge his remarks to me earlier that, in fact, he did not know I was to appear on the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not informed that you were to be.

—Senator Chipp was not informed. I was not informed of his presence either. The report concentrated on the progress of the epidemiological study and Senator Chipp stated his belief that the study will never be completed in time, that thousands of veterans cannot be traced and that there will not be an attempt to trace them. In addition, he implied that the Government has no concern for the veterans and to use his words is playing 'a trick of the worst kind of proportions' on them. I think that these implications are quite offensive. In all fairness, I consider that Senator Chipp's remarks on this occasion may be the result of fairly drastic selectivity by the program's producers.
—Where have you been misrepresented? That is the point.

—I am coming to that. If not, however, they do indicate that he too has not fully apprised himself of the facts in this matter. The Government has never sought political mileage out of this issue and it ill becomes anyone to seek to do so. I hope that in future honourable senators will take the opportunity to reflect on the genuine effort that is being made to get to the bottom of the issue and to ensure that it is rationally discussed. Had the program not used my statements so selectively, many points which I sought to explain would have been clarified. I seek now to cover very briefly the main areas which were omitted from the program. I said that a pilot study was underway to test various approaches to the conduct of the major study.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The last thing I want to do is to deny the Minister natural justice, but I remind you that he obtained permission to speak on the grounds that he had been misrepresented. He has made that point. If he now wishes to proceed, as he obviously intends to do, by stating the Government's position about where it has been unfairly attacked, certainly no one on this side of the chamber would refuse him leave to do that, provided the opportunity is given to honourable senators on this side to enter what would then be a debate on the issue and not simply a personal explanation about how the honourable senator has been allegedly misrepresented. Mr President, I put it to you that the decision is now up to the Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As far as I am concerned, either course of action would be suitable to us. But if the Minister proceeds now to justify the Government's stand, I think that fairness demands that honourable senators on this side of the chamber be given an equal opportunity to speak to the agent orange and Vietnam veterans questions.
—When leave is granted for an honourable senator to make a personal explanation, naturally that applies to explaining how he has been misrepresented. The Minister should observe that practice.
—On the point of order, I intend to point out now where statements of mine have been omitted. I did not seek to debate the issue.
—The Minister may carry on.

—On the point of order, it is obvious now that the personal explanation has become a statement. We should be able to take note of the statement and to speak further on it. I take it that that is the position now. It is not a personal explanation. I do not want to inhibit the Minister from continuing provided that we now understand that he is making a statement and that we can take note of it when he completes what he has to say.

—When the Minister sought leave to make a personal explanation about some matter on which he was not properly reported, leave was granted for that purpose. The Minister should adhere to that ruling. The Minister may carry on.

—I said at the time that a pilot study was underway to test various approaches to the conduct of the major study and explained that scientific standards had to be met. I referred to the establishment of an interim counselling service for Vietnam veterans and the additional treatment in urgent cases which was announced in January. I indicated that repatriation benefits are already being paid to some 6,500 Vietnam veterans and I emphasised the need for a continuation of liaison between the Government and the veterans' organisations. I referred to my impending visit to the United States to study at first hand the manner in which these issues are being addressed in that country. This major effort has several aims which include an assessment of counselling and other support arrangements which have been developed for veterans, discussion with congressional personnel and representatives of the Vietnam veterans' community as well as appraising progress on the several studies now under way in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I wish for the record to clarify one statement which the program did cover and which draw an uncomplimentary remark from the compere. I said that the pilot study results will not be made available publicly because they will not mean anything to the average person. This was not a reflection of my views on the capacity of the average person to comprehend the results. It was a reflection of scientific reality. As I have indicated many times the purpose of the pilot study is solely to test the methodology to be used in the epidemiological surveys. The numbers involved are insufficient to produce valid conclusions concerning the health effects claimed. If they were sufficient, there would be no need to undertake more than the pilot study.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement on the same matter. I know the difficulties in which this places the Government. I do not want to prolong the matter but the Minister has introduced matters of disputation. I do not claim to be misrepresented by him but I ask leave of the Senate to make a very short statement on the same matter.
—Is leave granted?

—I speak to that point, Mr President. Nobody wants to deny the honourable senator leave, but we must get to a situation where we cannot use the grounds of a personal explanation for pursuing statements. I concur with granting leave at this time on the basis that it is an exception and that the statement is very short indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I thank Senator Carrick. I can understand Senator Carrick's reluctance to grant me leave. In fact, I have stated that if I were in his position I would be reluctant to grant leave. I was not aware that Senator Messner was asked to appear on the same television show or that his comments would be slotted in between mine, as they obviously were. I expressed great concern-and I did use these words-that the Government was using a trick of the worst kind on Vietnam veterans. It was for this reason: Recent research by two eminent Australian scientists, Selinger and Hall, had indicated that massive quantities of dioxin, of agent orange, were imported into Australia from 1970 to 1972. I was Minister for Customs at that time and I signed the papers. But that is another story. I have checked on the question and that is so. It is also crystal clear that massive quantities of the same chemical were used in Malaysia at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the whole basis of the Government's inquiry is to get a control group of veterans who served in Vietnam where defoliants, including dioxin, were being used and compare their health history and that of their children with that of another control group which allegedly had not been exposed to the same chemicals. Selinger and Hall have proved to my satisfaction and, I think, to all reasonable satisfaction, that it is now virtually impossible to get two different control groups so that a true comparison can be made. I pointed out that what the Government will have to do inevitably, in all good faith, in one year or in two, three, four or five years hence, is to say to the Vietnam veterans: 'Sorry, we couldn't get two separate control groups so as to prove anything'. Where I say that this is a trick of the worst kind is that the Government knows that now and it should not keep these veterans in some sort of hope that this inquiry will produce some form of justice for them. I believe the Government knows very well at this moment that the inquiry will prove absolutely nothing and that the Vietnam veterans will get absolutely nothing in the way of compensation. That is why I say that this is a trick of the worst kind.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Harradine proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Commonwealth Government to maintain economic justice for Australian families.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now almost nine months since that massive petition for the restoration of the value of the family allowance was presented in the Senate. That petition was signed by over 22,000 citizens of Australia, most of whom came from Tasmania. Since then I have utilised every available opportunity to press the Government to restore the loss to value of the family allowance and to index it. Today is virtually the last opportunity I will have to speak on this matter in the Senate before the significant date of 1 July.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard this matter as one of the most important matters facing the Government, the Parliament and the country today. I would regard it as a reprehensible circumstance if the Government failed to take urgent action to remedy the situation so far as families are concerned. There is an expectation amongst families that the Government will do something. That expectation was aroused by the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the people of Australia two days before the election. I shall quote from an article appearing in the Australian of 16 October 1980 which was headed, 'Fraser pledges to give back petrol price rises as rebates or family allowances: OPEC increases will fund tax cuts: Prime Minister says priority to return money to the people'. The article reads:

In a dramatic bid to counter the vote-winning Labor pledge of cheap petrol, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, last night promised to return revenue from increased petrol prices next year to the public in the shape of tax cuts or higher family allowances.

The Government has not done that in respect of tax cuts. It ought to have done that so far as the family allowances are concerned. As a result of the increase in petrol prices this half year alone it will recoup an extra $170m into the Federal Treasury. This money is coming in the back door and it is not flowing out the front door, as promised by the Prime Minister. But the issue goes far deeper than that. Families throughout the length and breadth of Australia are disconcerted, dismayed and certainly are disappointed at the failure of the Government to rectify the situation. There is a growing realisation that the Government is not supportive of the family. Why is this so? It is because families now are very much aware that the family support systems have been savagely eroded by inflation which has jumped by 60.9 per cent since the family allowances were introduced in 1976. The burden has fallen heaviest on the one income family which now pays $493 more in income tax than the two income family paying tax at the rate of 32 cents in the dollar. The Government made much of its increase in the spouse rebate to $800, but of course this should now go to $1,293.

I have a number of tables which I will seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard. I have shown these tables to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and to the Opposition Whip. As I understand it there is no problem about having them incorporated. The principal table has been prepared by the Parliamentary Library Service and it details the estimated amounts of the family allowance at each time if it had been subject to indexation on the same basis as pensions. The next table shows the loss incurred between family allowances currently paid and those which should have been applied had they been indexed on the same basis as pensions. The next table is a comparison of the old child endowment rebate scheme and the family allowances scheme. The next table shows the total amount of money saved by not indexing family allowances. The final table is the average amount of money lost per family by not indexing family allowances. Honourable senators will see, if I am granted leave, that the principal table was prepared by the Parliamentary Library and the others are ones that I have worked on.
Leave granted.
