TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. From the tables it will be seen that in fact an average of $710 has been stolen from the purse of each Australian mother because of the failure of the Federal Government to ensure that the purchasing power of family allowances keeps pace with increased prices. By refusing to index family allowances the Government has pocketed a cool $1.5 billion since May 1976. This also is shown by the tables which I have incorporated. This year alone a mother of four children will be denied $657.80 to which she is justly entitled. As a matter of economic and social justice she should receive an extra $54.80 per month in family allowances. This, I remind the Senate, is on the most conservative calculation based on the outmoded formula used for the indexation of age pensions. But where will the Government find the money to make restitution to each Australian mother? I pose that question because it is the sort of question that is posed by the Government. The very reason this question arises is to be found in what happened in 1976. In that year the Government decided to pay direct to the mother the new family allowances with the money it saved by terminating the old child endowment scheme and by abolishing tax rebates for the children of taxpayers who generally were the fathers.

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the 1976 exercise transferred money from the hip pocket to the purse. I certainly did not argue about that. Dutifully, the fathers in Australia did not complain about the fact that this occurred. Of course, the mothers were justly delighted. But I guarantee that had the taxpayers of this country realised what had occurred they would have had something to say about it. The Government, with great fanfare, declared that its new scheme was one of the most significant social advances in Australian political history. At the time I endorsed the new scheme but warned that unless it was indexed it could end up worse than the miserable scheme it replaced. I refer the Senate to the table which is entitled, 'Comparison of child endowment and family allowance schemes', a document prepared by the Parliamentary Library. From that document one will see that a family of four is now $352 per year worse off than it would have been had the old child endowment tax rebate scheme continued, the very scheme which the Government branded as hopelessly inadequate and which everyone else branded as hopelessly inadequate.

The Government must now surely be faced with the charge that it has played a massive confidence trick on Australian families. I appreciate that the Minister, Senator Chaney, has only recently been handed the portfolio of Minister for Social Security. I appreciate that the Minister, Senator Chaney, has had a long standing interest in this matter and indeed in the whole question of support for the family. The Minister, in a recent address to the Institute of Public Affairs, I think it was in Sydney, stressed the importance of the family and also its importance in respect of the care and nurture of young children and the care of the elderly and the sick. I do not wish the Minister to regard anything that I have said as a personal reflection on him because I know that he has a point of view on this matter. I hope when he speaks in the debate, that he gives some indication of the view strongly held by him.

I recognise also that the decision in 1976 not only transferred money from the hip pocket to the purse but also assisted approximately 350,000 families which were not being assisted and which had not been able to claim under the old tax rebate scheme. They were, of course, receiving child endowment payments but they were not receiving anything under the old rebate scheme. However, to suggest that the families of Australia are being adequately treated is a nonsense. To suggest that because 10 per cent of Australian families in some way were brought into the scheme and that that will suffice them and the rest of Australian families for the next five years is a total irrelevancy. In fact, had the old rebate system been maintained, its value would have increased by some 81 per cent.

Furthermore, justice delayed is justice denied. It is no good for the Government to think that just because it has got away with the abolition of tax rebates for children it can coolly pocket the money that it has saved. I remind the Senate that since May 1976 that figure would be in the vicinity of $1.5m. It is grossly unfair for the Government to complain of the social welfare expenditure cost of restoring the value of family support payments when it was responsible for transferring those payments from tax not collected and therefore not publicly noticed to the highly exposed welfare budget.

The Prime Minister's election promise of support for Australian families has not yet been honoured. I expected that something would be done resulting from the statement in the Governor-General's Speech to Parliament on 25 November 1980. We must bear in mind that the Government had been returned to office on the promise of the Prime Minister that he would support Australian families. The Governor-General's Speech, which of course was written by the Prime Minister, states at page 4 under the heading 'Caring for People':

In what I have said about unemployment, youth and the economy, I have stressed my Government's concern with the human dimensions of the issues involved. It believes that the only legitimate yardstick for assessing any policy is not conformity to an ideology, not the strengthening of the state, but the effectiveness of that policy in enhancing the lives of people. This is the fundamental concern of my Government. This concern expresses itself in a diverse range of measures to which my Government is committed.
The Speech continues:

It is evident in the commitment of my Government to a range of social security and welfare measures which will strengthen the family and through it the basic social fabric of this country. My Government has already introduced a number of measures designed to assist families. It will be looking closely at its policies with the objective of further enhancing the position of Australian families.

Australian families are getting sick and tired of waiting for the Government to come up with some economic justice for them. I conclude by simply reminding the Government that, as I see it, this is the last opportunity, that I will have to address myself in the Senate in this session to this matter of vital importance to the people of Australia. I regard the functions of the Senate to be manifold. We have an expressive function and a representative function. I have sought to honour my obligations to my electors by expressing their viewpoint on this matter over the past many years, but particularly since the last election.

This was a matter on which I stood for election and was elected. I remind the Senate that in Franklin where I live, in my electorate, I received more votes than the Leader of the Liberal Party team and the leader of the Australian Labor Party team. The people of Tasmania understood this issue to be of vital importance, and I am sure the people of the rest of Australia understand it as such as well. A number of avenues are available to me in other States; there are avenues available to me in this Senate. As I mentioned, I have sought to exert the expressive function of the Senate; but the Senate also has other powers, and those powers include the audit and control powers and, if necessary, the blocking or deferment of money Bills. The Senate does not have the power to amend money Bills. I have not given any assurance to the Government, nor to anybody else, on the way I will vote after 1 July. I believe it is premature to do so. But I state again that unless the Government acts quickly on this matter to restore economic justice to Australian families it will create a reprehensible circumstance in which action will be required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has raised a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Commonwealth Government to maintain economic justice for Australian families.

This matter has been raised for debate in this place by many honourable senators including me. Indeed, occasionally it has been raised by Government senators during debates on Appropriation Bills. I realise that in the strict time limits imposed on us in debating matters of public importance we are all limited in what we can say on what is a massive subject. I am sure this is the reason Senator Harradine narrowed down his remarks so much. I would not like anyone to get the impression that I or anyone on the Opposition side believe that the basic cause of economic problems of Australian families today is the failure to index family allowances alone, although I admit that Senator Harradine made a passing reference to the level of the dependent spouse's rebate.

The problems of families in this country-I assume that by 'families' Senator Harradine means adults, unmarried children or dependent adults consisting a group-go far beyond the Government's reprehensible behaviour in failing to increase family allowances and certainly, I believe, will not be solved merely by increasing those family allowances to the level to which they would have been increased had they been indexed. The problem certainly will not be solved by increasing the dependent spouse's rebate to the extent that he said it should be increased. Before we talk about families and before we consider family policy in depth, we really have to look at the sorts of people and groups involved. We have to be aware of the fact that people at various stages of their lives pass in and out of various types of family situations. We must look at families as a whole. We certainly must not make the assumptions which are so often made in debates in this place about the distribution of incomes in those families. If we consider the family as only the group with a working male head, a dependent spouse and dependent children, I believe that we can end up creating policies which are unjust and inequitable in our society. I believe that those who would try to make our society, through policy, conform to some preconceived idea of what the family should be, misuse social policy in that regard.

As Senator Harradine has said, the Government is prone to trumpet the virtues of what it sees as its policies towards families and has made many claims about benefits that it has introduced to support the family. In fact, as the honourable senator also pointed out, the family, by anyone's definition, has suffered economic disadvantage in the last five or six years, not only because of the Government's failure to increase the family allowances, certainly not only because of its failure to increase satisfactorily the dependent spouse's rebate, but also because of its policy not to increase other allowances paid on behalf of children-particularly pensioners' children-to a sufficient level and its policy of keeping down the real wages of low income families particularly, and of cutting down assistance to families by way of expenditure on education, social and immigration services and housing especially.

All these things contribute to the economic distress of the family. All, and the problems that they produce, must be considered as a whole before we suggest that, just by increasing the family allowances in the manner suggested by Senator Harradine, we can solve all our problems. No one denies the basic fact of the economic decline of parents in the community. Where people differ is as to the best way to attack the problem and, bearing in mind the limited resources available, how best to order our priorities. I repeat: To do this we must look at the facts where we can and at those who are worst off, and take action initially to correct the problems of such people. I do not believe that we should suggest measures which are inadequate for the worst affected and largely irrelevant for those who are not affected at all-the high income earners-thus spreading our resources too thinly. That certainly does not mean that I accept the Government's view that what we can spend in areas such as this is severely restricted and that our economic ills are due to such expenditure. International comparisons, as I have pointed out in other debates, will demonstrate that the Government's claim that such expenditure, particularly social expenditure, contributes as much as it says it does, or even at all, to our economic ills is nonsense. I believe that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in recent speeches about taxation and the welfare system has shown that he is coming around to realising this.

First, we should look at some of the facts about those who may be worst off in the community. I have before me a table-no doubt many will be presented this afternoon-which has been reproduced at regular intervals by the statistical service of the Parliamentary Library. It relates to the Henderson poverty line, which is really the only recognised parameter that we have for comparing people's incomes and trying to define in some inadequate way, surely, the level of poverty experienced. That poverty line, as Professor Henderson described it when it was first produced, is a rather austere one. The table compares the poverty line with the disposable income of various family groups in the community and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. It is suitable for incorporation and I have shown it to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table will be familar to people who have been interested in this subject. It was updated last year. It showed that all pensioner families, living on the pension only, were in fact below Professor Henderson's austere poverty line if they had one or more dependent children and that all single parent families with no income apart from the benefit, were well below the poverty line. I will not go through the figures to demonstrate that. The facts are well known.

SPEECH.PARA: Low wage families are also having a difficult time. Two years ago a single family with three children, which earned $200 a week, was above the poverty line. Now it is $2 below. A single income family with five children which earns $240 a week is now $9 below the poverty line. A single parent pensioner with two children is $19.45 below the poverty line. A family whose breadwinner is unemployed and which has two children to support, is $12.40 below the poverty line. The unemployed family with four children to support is $36.70 below the poverty line. Certainly, the chief cause of their financial distress is the failure to raise the level of the family allowances which, as Senator Harradine has said, has been frozen since 1976, despite inflation totalling more than 60 per cent since that time. The value of the allowance-has dropped by more than half. These people are all below the poverty line and, despite other measures taken by the Government in the interim, their position has been deteriorating gradually. It is a situation that this Parliament should not tolerate and it certainly provides the reprehensible circumstances to which Senator Harradine has referred.

In studying the family income units of this country, it is worth while to look at the survey of family incomes made in late 1979 by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It was then estimated that there was some 3,736,000-odd family units in the country. These were defined-as I defined them earlier-as comprising two or more persons living in a household consisting of a head and a spouse, if any, and any persons having the following relationships: Unmarried children of any age and any relations who were unmarried and had no dependent children in their care. The differences in income of the various income units are interesting. For the married couple income unit, of which there were some 3.3 million, the average income in those days was $15,000. For one parent income units, the average income was $7,320. For the single person income unit, of which there were 2 million, the average income was some $6,500. Of total income units which were dependent on benefits and not earning incomes, married couples made up 15 per cent; one person units, which included aged persons living alone and unemployed persons living alone, comprised 33 per cent. Single parent families comprised 48 per cent, or almost half of the group that was totally dependent on the Government.

The median total incomes of the groups in the community demonstrate other interesting points. A married couple with no dependants had a median income of $12,500. Married couples with one dependant had an income of $14,600. Married couples with two dependants had an income of $15,400. But when we come to the one parent family, those with only one child had a median income of $5,350. Those with two children had a median income of $5,330. This was lower than the income of the family with one child.

When we examine further the figures in this paper we find that the worst off are single parent families which are headed by a female. What we can see from the figures-there is no need to quote them further-is that those family groups which are by far the worst off in the community, are the single parent families which are dependent on the government for their income and the low income-usually single income-families of the community. Not only are they the worst off, but also many receive incomes that are below the poverty line. Many of them are in difficulty and have become even more so in the last five or six years. We must help and do something about supporting family structures, because a family, however it is structured, which is under economic stress tends to be under social and psychological stress; and problems within that family arise partly but largely out of its economic difficulties. When we try to help families we must look at what we have done in the past and at what is possible in the future. I believe we must try not to make the mistakes of the past which, as many people have demonstrated, have resulted so often in funds being spread too thinly or going in large quantities to the wrong people. We must look at some of the solutions that Senator Harradine has talked about and the way in which we should go about implementing them.

Of course, family allowances are of utmost importance. They are a recognition, however inadequate, that there is a cost to parenthood. As Senator Harradine said, they replace the tax rebate which had previously replaced tax deductions. If they are a recognition of the fact that parenthood costs, we see that they are an inadequate recognition when we look at the amounts that are paid. For the first child a family gets $23.85, for the second child $34.05, for the third child $40.80, for the fourth child $40.80, and so on. I believe those payments should have been indexed. I have said in this place, along with many others, that they should be indexed. I have also said that under the Government's fiscal policy I could not see how they would be indexed, and we on this side predicted that they would not be indexed. If we indexed them and if that was all we did-if we brought them up to the level they should be at had they been indexed since 1976-what sorts of increases would be introduced? I suggest that we would introduce increases which would be inadequate for low income families. We would introduce increases which would be largely irrelevant to the very high income families and of marginal value to some of the middle income families. If we increased the payments to a reasonable level-I am certainly not going to define 'a reasonable level' in this situation-the cost would be high, but the income would be still spread across all levels of the community and, I suggest, the low income people and those on single incomes would still be in the same relative position as they are in now; that is, at the bottom of the barrel on an inadequate level of income.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call a high income?

—I am not trying to make such definitions. I am merely pointing out that if we increased the payments by the amount that the honourable senator says they should be increased-I certainly do not argue that we should not do so; I am merely saying that that is not all we should do-and if we gave the same amount of money to my family on my high income as we gave to someone on a single parent's pension, we would not be really correcting the situation or giving justice to both of those families. We certainly would not be giving justice to the low income family. I am not arguing against Senator Harradine's proposition. I am just saying that it seems to me that he thinks that would solve all the problems. I am suggesting that, under the Government's present economic stringencies and in the unlikely event that the Government would provide an adequate amount to families through family allowances-I think Senator Harradine and I have to accept that that is unlikely-we may have to look at further measures, such as the family income supplement scheme that I and others proposed before the last election, to correct the difficult problem of the low income families in the community.
—It could be done by negative taxation.

—It could be done in all sorts of ways. I am merely putting that up as an alternative. We then have to look at other methods which have been suggested frequently in this place, one of which was adverted to by Senator Harradine; that is, increasing the dependent spouse rebate. The dependent spouse rebate goes to all who have dependent spouses, whether or not they have children. One of the difficulties with it is that it goes disproportionately to those on higher incomes in the community. Frequently they are people who have no necessity to work, which is another subject that Senator Harradine and I have spoken on in this place. I suggest that to use it as an anti-poverty measure will not succeed. To use it to keep people out of the work force will also not succeed in most cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe one of the main reasons that many women are in the work force is only partly to do with economics and is partly to do with social change. That is also another matter. I am not the only one who says that, and it is not only people on our side of the Parliament who say it. I noticed that Mr R. J. Tanner, a prominent member of the Liberal Party, a Sydney stock broker and a man who has many views on taxation, pointed out in the Canberra Times on 15 April that the dependent spouse rebate is a classic example of how a benefit is generally being claimed by the middle and higher income earner so that it is not helping the lower income earner but offsetting the progressive tax structure in a highly tangled and bureaucratic way. Time does not allow me to go into that in detail, but I commend people who use the proposition that the dependent spouse rebate in some way will overcome the economic problems of families, particularly families in need, to look at the problem more closely and to look at just where the dependent spouse rebate goes. In 1978-79 about 21 per cent of those receiving the dependent spouse rebate earned over $16,000 a year. It was in effect a transfer to families, which did not necessarily include children, whose income exceeded the median probably even for two-income families at that time. The rebate was not assisting the sorts of families which I believe Senator Harradine wishes to assist.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking of economic justice, not the question of poverty. That is separate.

—The question of poverty concerns some of us. I am concerned about economic justice too. But if the honourable senator puts up in this place a matter of public importance which talks in general about economic justice for Australian families, we have to talk about a little more than just an increase in family allowances, because an increase in family allowances will not bring the economic justice which they expect and which the honourable senator and I expect. We need more than just an attack on the family allowance problem. First of all, we need to provide work for families in the community, because increasing unemployment and the lack of adequate income are the greatest causes of economic injustice in this country. We need an increase in family allowances.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance submitted by Senator Harradine in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Commonwealth Government to maintain economic justice for Australian families.

There being a speaker from the Opposition, a speaker in the form of the independent Senator Harradine and a speaker from the Government, it is useful to find some common ground between the three parties in agreeing that some additional emphasis on families is necessary. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his policy speech before the 1980 election, said:
It is our belief that the strength of Australia depends on the strength of Australian families. Our programs of family support will continue.

Of course, Senator Harradine referred to a number of my speeches in which I had acknowledged the premier role of the family in Australian society and our need to ensure its good health. We went on in the 1980 statement to talk about a number of things that were needed for particular problem areas, including the fact that we would establish crisis accommodation for families in distress, the fact that we would initiate a new building program for homeless persons to help homeless youths in particular, and the fact that we would establish a national children's foundation to tackle the problems of child abuse. Those are particular matters which are perhaps outside the mainstream of the concerns expressed by Senator Harradine this afternoon. We find in the Governor-General's opening speech to this Parliament, when he set out the Government's program for the next three years, a quotation which again was referred to by Senator Harradine in his speech:
My Government has already introduced a number of measures to assist families. It will be looking at its policies with the objective of further enhancing the position of Australian families.

I think there is a deal of common ground and a common commitment to the broad scope of the proposition which has been put forward by Senator Harradine, namely the need for additional emphasis to be given and for the emphasis to be perhaps swung back towards the family. In those terms I think we are commonly referring to families which have the care of dependent children. However, I think a valuable point was made by Senator Grimes when he pointed out that the matter of the welfare of Australian families is broader than the cash benefits which are provided by government to families. I think Senator Harradine, by interjection, indicated that in a broad sense he agreed with that also.

The fact is that most of the families with which we are concerned-forgetting for the moment those who are at the most needy end of the scale and I will touch on them a little later-are part of the working community. Indeed, as many as half of the families about whom we are concerned-those which are supporting children-have not one working parent but two working parents. To a substantial extent the material welfare of those families is dependent upon the work opportunities which are there, upon the continuance of a healthy economy and upon the growth of employment opportunities.

In those terms, the real increases which have taken place in employment over the last year and a half and the more recent decreases in employment rates, which show that the growth in employment is catching up with the greater employment take-up, are matters which also have direct relevance to the welfare of Australian families. I make no apology for the emphasis which the Government has placed on sound economic management and controlling inflation as these are matters which are intrinsic to the general welfare of Australian families. I think it is quite clear that the Government intends to retain that as one of its major concerns. I believe that most Australian families are equally as vitally concerned with that central theme of this Government.

A second point I make very briefly, because Senator Harradine has directed this specifically to economic matters, is that the welfare of families in Australia is often a matter not just of economics. There are other substantial problems affecting Australian families-I think Senator Harradine would agree with this proposition-which relate to other aspects of Australian society, some of which I am concerned about and some of which I am sure he is concerned about. Although one might argue that some cases, for example, those associated with marital breakdown, which severely affect the economic and social welfare of families, are related to economic pressures which government ought to be helping to relieve. It is also true that among families of substantial economic resources there are many examples of hardship-material, spiritual and social-which ought to be of concern to us.

I draw attention to that because some of the Government's attention is directed to those areas through the Children's Services Program of family support which it is developing with State governments, still on a semi-experimental basis but on a basis which I think is directed at meeting the inability of so many modern families simply to cope and to be successfully functioning families. In addition, our support of the Institute of Family Studies mirrors a concern about that aspect of the situation of the family in Australia. I am not sure that the problems of families are any less in the areas that I have so quickly touched on than they are in the economic areas which are the main subject of the discussion this afternoon.

There appears to be some common ground between Senator Harradine and Senator Grimes in placing considerable emphasis on the problems of one income families. At different points in their speeches they made the point that they saw one income families as being a group in particular need of assistance. I mention that matter again because I think it is important to read the tables which have been put into the Senate record by Senator Harradine bearing that in mind. The tables, in fact, cover the range of families, rich and poor. They relate principally to the shift in the tax system and the benefits system in terms of the totality of benefits which are paid to all families with respect to the dependent children in their care.

There are tables which compare the old tax deduction and the old child endowment with the present family allowance and the reduction in value in the family allowance, given that it has not been adjusted since 1976. That is the main thrust of these tables. As I said before, they apply to families both well off and not so well off. In terms of the single income families about whom so much concern has been expressed this afternoon, it is important to bring into balance the increase in the dependent spouse allowance which has occurred within the same period. With respect to that category of families one has to make a $400 adjustment to the total position of those families. I am referring now only to single income families and only to tax-paying families.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would have been adjusted anyhow.

—There have been adjustments other than indexation in that area. It is affecting a group of families which were claimed by both Senator Harradine and Senator Grimes to be of particular significance. I draw the attention of the Senate and readers of Senate Hansard to the fact that with respect to the last two tables incorporated by Senator Harradine one is entitled to take into account the additional assistance of $400 a year which has been achieved with the doubling of the spouse allowance and which will be further increased with indexation post 1 July. It is quite compatible with the information in those tables also to include with respect to single income families the adjustment of the doubling of the dependent spouse allowance which has occurred since 1976.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that I think needs to be made about what Senator Harradine said is that he referred to the failure to adjust the family allowance in terms of the Government coolly pocketing the money. I simply want to put that comment in perspective by pointing out that right up to the current year the Commonwealth has continued to budget on a deficit basis. In other words, we are still expending moneys in excess of what is raised from the taxpayers of Australia. There is no peculiar pocket into which these moneys have gone. The fact is that general welfare expenditure of the Commonwealth has doubled in money terms since we took office and the expenditure of the Commonwealth has continued to outstrip the revenue raising of the Commonwealth. We are in a situation in which additional assistance to families is assistance which can come only from either increased revenues or savings which are achieved in other areas.

There is no escape from that fact, that simple truth, which members of the Opposition are able to avoid with a fair amount of success but which governments cannot avoid. In relation to the additional assistance which we are seeking to provide for families, and which is, of course, a Budget matter which has to be considered in the Budget context and on which any decisions taken will be announced in August when we resume for the spring session, it is a fact that any of the increased amounts which can be allocated or additional tax concessions which can be provided for families are matters which will affect the taxpayers of Australia. They will have to pay for the benefits where there is no other source for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are pocketing the money now.

—To suggest the money is being pocketed is to suggest that it is in some way being put away and is available to the Government. The fact is, as I have said before, that the Government is still in a position in which it is spending and paying more than it raises from taxpayers. I shall very quickly refer to the changes to assist families which have been made by the Government since it came into office. A good deal has already been said today about family allowances. The important change in 1976 was one which, I think, has been acknowledged in the debate that is, that the families at the bottom end of the income scale in Australia-those who are not taxpayers and those who are, therefore, not benefiting from the old system of tax deductions-were the substantial beneficiaries of the 1976 changes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fair to say that those who would in the broadest terms be described as middle income had little change. They lost a tax deduction. They gained a benefit. For the mother there was a shift from the pocket to the purse as was put earlier in the debate. But for an estimated 300,000 poorer families there was a substantial increase in the benefit available to them because they had not previously benefited from the taxation arrangements. The estimate of the number of children benefiting from that change is 800,000. The drift in benefits or advantages to families was raised by Senator Harradine in a question not very long ago. In response to him, I said it was not true that all families had seen a reduction in their financial assistance position from before 1976 to the present. I suggested that the poorer families had, in fact, benefited in a way which still put them ahead of the position pre-1976.

I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the assistance for children in low income families in March 1976 as against March 1981. That table shows that in all but a very few circumstances the direct assistance provided by Government via the medium of the family allowance increased in real terms over the assistance which was available pre-March 1976. I am not suggesting that that table is the answer to the points which have been raised, but it relates to those families at the poorest end of Australian society, for which we are entitled to have particular concern. I seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already mentioned the changes in the tax arrangements. The other matter I wish to touch on very quickly is that we have made changes which affect families with special needs. These include increases in the handicapped child's allowance and in the orphan's pension. These have been adjusted on a number of occasions. Sole parents have been assisted. These were groups recognised as being in particular need. Sole parents have been assisted by providing benefits to male sole parents as well as to female sole parents, by extending health benefits to them and by removing the six-months waiting period for the Commonwealth benefit. In the last Budget, additional assistance was given to pensioners and beneficiaries who had to care for children. So there have been a number of things done to improve the position of the family. Broadly, the Government accepts that there is a need for greater provision for families and that is a matter we have under examination. (Extension of time granted). I thank the Opposition Whip for the courtesy of granting me an extension of time. I have been racing and I think I can finish within the five minutes which was suggested. I was trying to put before the Senate a number of special measures which have been taken by the Government over recent years to improve the position of families which are seen as being in particular need. I mentioned sole parents and Commonwealth pensioners and beneficiaries who over recent years have seen an increase in the total assistance provided for them by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to acknowledge the reality of a number of the remarks made by Senator Grimes. It is true that in looking at the totality of assistance which can be provided by the Government to families, there is a need to isolate those groups in the community which can be seen to be particularly in need of help. I believe it is part of the obligation of the Department of Social Security and of my Ministry to ensure that we do, wherever possible, identify those who, more than normal Australians, need the additional help of government. I make that comment in the context of the general commitment which the Government has made to examine the position of families and to see what can be done about families generally. This is a matter of balancing competing interests and demands upon the Government. We will endeavour to do that in as reasonable a way as we can. I am afraid that I am going to waste some of the extra time granted to me because, as I said, I raced to cover the points I wished to refer to, not realising that I would have the courtesy of an extension of time. I now move:

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill authorises the Commonwealth to enter into a five year agreement with each State and the Northern Territory for the provision of home purchase assistance and rental housing assistance. The operation of the agreement in each State requires the formal agreement of the State Minister. The Bill provides for the Commonwealth to pay advances and grants to the States and the Northern Territory for home ownership assistance to people not able to achieve it through the private market and for rental housing assistance for people who for various reasons are unable to obtain adequate accommodation themselves. This Agreement will be the latest in a series of housing agreements stretching back to 1945, but it is the first time that the Northern Territory will be a party to a housing agreement common to all States. The 1981 Agreement follows detailed negotiations between the Commonwealth, all the States and the Northern Territory and consideration of more than one hundred submissions received in response to the Commonwealth's request for suggestions from the public.

Through this legislation, the Commonwealth has firmly committed itself to the funding of welfare housing, but the Commonwealth will not interfere in the method of delivering the assistance which States are best able to assess, plan and provide. This reflects the Commonwealth's belief that the states know best their own needs. The Agreement before the Senate represents a continuation of, and in certain areas, an improvement on, the significant welfare housing reforms introduced by this Government in 1978. These reforms followed comments by authorities such as the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty which found that assistance for welfare housing was not always directed to those most in need. The Henderson inquiry found that many people living in subsidised welfare housing were not poor, and many of the poor were not in subsidised housing. The 1978 Agreement addressed these problems through measures such as market related rents combined with rental rebates and escalating interest rates on home purchase assistance loans. Those reforms were aimed at tailoring assistance to people in need for the period of their need. At the same time the Agreement gave the States increased flexibility to enable them to design programs to meet their own particular requirements.

The current Bill further increases the flexibility given to the States and continues the process of ensuring that assistance is directed to people in need. The objectives of the programs, spelt out for the first time in the 1978 Housing Agreement, will not be changed. However, with the agreement of the States, three new objectives have been added. Firstly, the design, style and siting of public housing will, as far as is practicable, reflect the needs of the handicapped. This objective is particularly appropriate in this International Year of Disabled Persons and demonstrates the Government's concern to assist these people to live normal lives. Secondly, the States will also have regard to energy savings which can be made. Again this is appropriate in an energy conscious era. Thirdly, tenants of public housing will be encouraged to participate in public housing policies and estate management. This illustrates our desire that tenants have a say in decisions concerning the management of their homes.

As the Government has promised, this Bill provides for a base funding level of $200m for each year of the five year agreement. The States have sought a forward commitment for many years to enable them to properly plan their programs. It should be clearly understood that the $200m is a forward commitment for each of the five years and that total funding will be determined each year in the Budget context. Currently all funding is determined in the Budget context. The Bill appropriates an amount of $54m as part of the base yearly commitment in interest free non-repayable grants for rental housing assistance to special categories of persons listed in clause 38 of the Agreement. This is approximately the amount which is being provided to pensioners and Aboriginals in the 1980-81 financial year.

Grants for rental assistance for pensioners were first introduced with the States Grants (Dwellings for Pensioners) Act 1969. Pensioner housing continued to be funded under the Housing Assistance Act 1978 and grant funds for Aboriginals were also made available under the Act from 1979-80. These grants reflect the Commonwealth's special responsibilities to disadvantaged groups.

The Bill also makes it possible for additional earmarked funds over the $54m yearly base level to be made available from time to time for disadvantaged groups. Any additional categories of people to be assisted will be determined only following consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has announced as part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that grants to the States for Aboriginal housing will be integrated into the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. It is proposed that the transfer will occur from 1 July 1981. This will bring all Aboriginal housing payments to the States under the one Agreement. Aboriginal housing will continue as an identifiable program component of the new Agreement.

The remainder of the base level funding, $146m, is in the form of interest bearing repayable advances at the highly concessional interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent per annum over 53 years. This is the largest interest rate concession ever provided to States under welfare housing arrangements and further emphasises the Commonwealth's contribution to those in housing need. In 1973, for instance, the interest concession was 2 per cent; in 1978, it was 4 per cent. At current rates of interest, the Bill's provisions will result in an interest concession of over 8 per cent. Any additional untied funding will be as advances, grants or a combination of both. The composition will be announced at the same time as the level of additional funding is made known. A major feature of the new Agreement is the considerable degree of autonomy which States will have. They will have complete freedom of choice in allocating all untied advances and grants between home purchase and rental housing assistance. In the past the Commonwealth has laid down conditions as to the proportion of funds which should go either to home purchase or rental. This new provision will allow each State to allocate funds between programs to suit needs in that State. States will also have autonomy as to how they apply funds made available under this Agreement, provided of course these meet the purposes covered by the Agreement. The Commonwealth has created an innovative climate and States will be able, if they so wish, to provide a wide range of assistance in response to various needs. Under our federalism policies, the Commonwealth has removed restrictions on States but will not force them to introduce new forms of housing assistance.

Since the 1978-79 financial year, States have matched advances provided by the Commonwealth with funds from their own resources. These arrangements recognise the co-operative approach between the Commonwealth and the States to welfare housing. The matching arrangements, however, have operated outside the legislation. This Bill incorporates details of matching arrangements into the Agreement. The States will be required to match all funds except those earmarked for rental assistance to disadvantaged groups. However, such funds allocated by the States from their own resources need not be subject to the Agreement. The arrangements have been designed to give the States maximum flexibility in running their own welfare housing programs which complement programs under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. These arrangements will ensure a continuation of the strong joint effort by the Commonwealth and the States to provide housing assistance for the needy.

Honourable senators will be pleased to know that, as a result of these arrangements, over $630m was made available for welfare housing in 1979-80. This comprises Commonwealth funding, State funding and internally generated funds from program operations. This legislation also spells out the method of allocating funds between the States. The present method, based as it is on allocations made in the context of financial arrangements existing in 1973-74, is no longer relevant and has led to widespread inequities. For instance, in 1980-81 Queensland, with 15.6 per cent of the population of the States and the Northern Territory, is receiving 9.7 per cent of advances. New South Wales and Victoria also are receiving less than average per capita allocations. On the other hand, South Australia, with 9.0 per cent of the population, is receiving 14.2 per cent of advances and Tasmania, with 2.9 per cent of the population, is receiving 6.1 per cent of advances.

The Commonwealth considers that the distribution of housing funds on an equal per capita basis would mean a fairer allocation of funds between the States and would be more in keeping with relative housing needs. Accordingly this Bill incorporates a formula for the allocation of funds between the States, which moves towards an equal per capita distribution over a ten year planning period. All funds, apart from these earmarked for disadvantaged groups, will be distributed on the following basis: In 1981-82 they will be allocated in the same proportions as advances were allocated in 1980-81. Over the four remaining years of the Agreement they will be allocated on a basis that would progressively achieve an equal per capita allocation in the financial year 1990-1991, if the Agreement were to operate until that financial year. To provide protection for the smaller States and the Northern Territory a guarantee has been built into the formula so that no State or the Northern Territory receives less than 5 per cent of the level of yearly base advances of $146m. I must stress that the gradual phasing-in of an equal per capita allocation over the nine years commencing in 1982-83, and the protection offered to the smaller States, will result in South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory still receiving a higher than average per capita proportion of the untied assistance over the life of the 1981 Agreement. However, the share of funds received by New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland will gradually increase over the life of the Agreement.

The Bill provides for the funds earmarked for rental assistance for disadvantaged groups to be allocated amongst the States on the basis of their respective needs as determined by the Commonwealth Minister. This is a continuation of current practices. For example, pensioner funds are allocated amongst the States in proportion to the number of eligible pensioners receiving supplementary assistance. In order to allow funds to be paid out to States from 1 July 1981, there is provision in the legislation for an advance to the States of loans and grants authorised under this Act before the Agreement has been signed. However, if a State has not signed the Agreement by 1 January 1982, all such moneys are to be repaid.

I turn now to specific aspects of the home purchase assistance provisions. The arrangements for home purchase assistance continue under the new Agreement with one minor change from those in the 1978 Agreement. The 1978 provisions demonstrated our concern to encourage home ownership across the widest possible range of income groups. In 1978 the purposes for which home purchase assistance funds could be used were broadened to include a range of flexible practices including interest subsidy schemes and flexible mortgage arrangements such as low start loans. I am pleased to say that some States have introduced interest subsidy schemes. By attracting private capital for loans to low income earners, these schemes enable more families to be assisted with the same amount of Government funds. With the guarantee of continuity of funding contained in this Agreement, I am confident that we will see increasing use of these provisions.

A minor change relates to the interest rate charged on outstanding loans to agencies of the Home Purchase Assistance Program. The 1978 Agreement provided that the interest rate charged by the States to the lending agencies would escalate by one-half of one per cent per year until a level of one per cent below the long term bond rate was reached. This maximum rate is to be changed to one per cent below the Commonwealth Savings Bank lending rate for housing loans. The individual borrower when he is no longer in need of subsidy will be paying an interest rate akin to a loan from the Commonwealth Savings Bank.

The 1978 Agreement made several improvements to the provisions governing rental housing assistance. The purposes for which funds could be used were greatly expanded to include activities such as leasing dwellings and joint ventures with the private sector and with voluntary organisations. We are now adding another purpose, which is 'to provide rental subsidy for eligible persons renting private housing'. This addition is a further example of the flexibility being provided to the States under the new Agreement. It will mean that States will not need to build or otherwise provide dwellings but will be able to subsidise people renting privately if they wish.

The 1978 Commonwealth-State arrangements introduced a requirement that the States charge market related rents for public rental dwellings with rental rebates for people unable to afford them. The Commonwealth believes that the continued development of a system of income related rents with a ceiling set by the assessed market rent for a dwelling offers the fairest deal for families in housing need. Accordingly, the new Agreement refers to a policy of market rents, instead of the market related rent policy required by the 1978 Agreement.

For those unable to pay the market rent, rent rebates apply. The majority of those who currently receive rent rebates are age, invalid, widow pensioners, and single parent families. The Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty found that these were amongst the poorest groups in our society. Single income two-parent families where the breadwinner is on a low wage also benefit from these rebates. The market rent policy combined with rent rebates protects all of these persons from hardship. At the same time it ensures that those whose circumstances have improved pay a rent which reflects their increased capacity to pay. This ensures that subsidies are limited to those in need only for the period of their need.

The 1978 Agreement required Commonwealth and State governments to jointly seek ways of establishing a uniform approach to the calculation of rental rebates. Agreement has been reached on broad principles to apply. The formula should treat all tenants equally on the basis of their capacity to pay. Thus it should be income based, linked to total household income and treat tenants equally irrespective of how long they have been in public housing. Only such a system will be fair for all public housing tenants. To achieve equity between tenants living in different States, as well as in the same State, a uniform system across Australia is necessary. Hence the new Agreement requires that a uniform rental rebate policy be developed by the Commonwealth and the States and be applied for the calculation of rental rebates.

The 1981 Agreement will continue to provide for sales of rental dwellings to tenants and will continue the requirement that dwellings must be sold for cash. A cash sales policy ensures that the State Housing authorities are able to replace dwellings which are sold and so maintain the level of the public rental stock while still encouraging people who wish to purchase. Eligible tenants may receive a housing loan under the home purchase assistance program. However, States will be able to adjust the market value of a dwelling so that the sale price set for the tenant will allow for improvements made by the tenant before the purchase. This means tenants can be rewarded for the efforts they make. This Bill represents an important step forward in the implementation of this Government's housing policy. This policy is to:
Ensure that every household in Australia is able to obtain adequate housing within its capacity to pay;
Encourage home ownership across the widest possible range of income groups concentrating Federal assistance in the areas of greatest need;
Maintain and improve housing styles and seek the most effective use of the available housing stock;
Ensure stable economic conditions within the building industry;
Encourage research and innovation and, in co-operation with the States, develop imaginative housing programs for the underprivileged and disadvantaged.

In the 1978 Act we moved a long way towards achieving these goals and in the better direction of welfare housing assistance to those in need. The present legislation before the Senate builds on that achievement. The provision of a guaranteed base level of funding will enable the States to plan ahead with confidence. It should lead to further use by the States of the opportunities for innovative practices provided in the 1978 Agreement.

This legislation demonstrates this Government's belief that the State governments are best placed to know the needs of people in their State. The Agreement further increases the freedom of the States to tailor housing programs to meet their particular needs. No longer can any State say that it is restricted by Commonwealth direction. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of the first reading debate on this Bill, the Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1981, to raise some matters this afternoon which concern many pensioners throughout Australia. Before I continue with that matter I indicate that I believe I will be followed this afternoon by Senator Reid, who will be making her maiden speech in this place. Whilst other speakers this afternoon and this evening will probably congratulate Senator Reid on her maiden speech, at this stage I merely wish her well.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned, I wish to mention some difficulties and injustices which are being faced by some pensioners in Australia. These are pensioners who have investment incomes. Before their retirement, many pensioners set aside what they would describe as a nest egg; something to fall back on when the need arises, something for a rainy day. Some of them receive this nest egg as a retirement benefit. It is natural for these people, who have something they can set aside, to invest some or all of their savings. The problem is that some pensioners subsequently lose part of their pension because of the interest that they receive on those savings.

I wish to take the hypothetical example of a single pensioner who has $15,000 invested in, say, Australian savings bonds. The current rate for Australian savings bonds is 12.25 per cent. So a pensioner would receive about $1,800 a year or $34 a week in interest on an investment of $15,000. We all know that a single pensioner can receive up to $20 a week without losing any part of his or her pension, but once a figure of $34 has been reached the pensioner loses about $7 a week of his or her pension. Some may say that that is fair enough because a pensioner may earn up to $20 a week without any pension loss. They may ask why, if a pensioner is receiving $34 a week, there should not be some loss of pension. But is it fair enough? I wish to examine the question further.

Let us look again at that investment of $15,000 in Australian savings bonds earning 12.25 per cent interest. We must remember when we look at that 12.25 per cent that the inflation rate in Australia currently runs at about 9.4 per cent. So out of every $12.25 interest that a pensioner receives for every $100 that he or she has invested, about $9.40 is required to retain the purchasing power of the original investment. Therefore the real rate of interest that the person is receiving is not 12.25 per cent, but 12.25 per cent less 9.4 per cent-the inflation rate-which is about 3 per cent. What income would the pensioner receive if we calculated the interest on that $15,000 investment at 3 per cent? The interest would be about $450 a year, which is close to $9 a week. If we accepted that the person was receiving $9 a week in income, that pensioner would retain the full pension. I hold that pensioners have to count as income that part of their interest which is merely compensation to keep their principal in line with inflation. Because they have to do so, they are losing part of their pension. I do not really think that that is fair enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about taxpayers? Do you feel the same way about them?

—In reply to Senator Chaney, the same principle applies to taxpayers. Some of the solutions that I will suggest shortly could possibly be used in relation to taxpayers. This afternoon, however, I am just dwelling on the plight of pensioners. This is an extremely important topic for pensioners. They think that, once they reach their retirement age, they will be in receipt of an income, without any real hassle about money problems. But they find that, if they have some money set aside in this manner, they have to lose part of their pension because their interest rate is so high. I point out that the interest rate is high because there is a component in that interest rate which takes into account the rate of inflation. Not only that, but also, as Senator Chaney intimated, they have to pay tax on some of their earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the possible solutions to this problem? I do not think it is worthwhile just pointing out that pensioners have a problem without offering some sort of solution. Short of achieving a zero rate of inflation, I can offer three possible solutions which I ask the Government to consider. One solution would be to adjust the rate of interest received by pensioners by taking the level of inflation into account. Taking the example that I mentioned earlier of a person who had an investment of $15,000 at 12.25 per cent, which gave him or her $34 a week, we could adjust the interest rate by taking into account the rate of inflation. As I mentioned earlier, the adjusted interest rate would be about 3 per cent which would mean that the pensioner would receive about $9 a week in real income. That amount would be regarded as the pensioner's income and, therefore, the pensioner would not lose any of his or her pension. That is one possible solution.

A second solution, of course, would be to increase the amount which a pensioner may earn. Currently, as I have mentioned, a single pensioner may earn $20 a week without losing any of his or her pension. It is a long time since that amount has been adjusted. Lifting the allowable income to $30 a week would mean that the pensioner in the case that I have mentioned would lose $2 a week from his or her pension. If the allowable income were raised to $40 a week, no loss from that pension would occur. That example, of course, does not cover the position of the pensioner having to pay tax on any income that he or she might have.

I mention a third solution. The Government should give some consideration to the issue of what I call inflation adjusted bonds. At the moment, the interest rate on Australian savings bonds, which are issued by the Government, is 12.25 per cent. Inflation adjusted bonds are used in other countries. I have seen them used in New Zealand and in the United Kingdom. The general idea of inflation adjusted bonds is that, although a low rate of interest applies, the principal is adjusted in line with inflation so that it keeps its purchasing power. If the principal that a person has invested keeps its purchasing power because it is adjusted, there is no need for a high rate of interest. The effective rate of interest received by the person in the example I have given would be about 3 per cent. If the principal were adjusted in line with inflation, an interest rate of 3 per cent might be satisfactory. The beauty of that interest rate of 3 per cent is that the interest received would be the only amount taken into account for income purposes. Any so-called capital gain that might occur because of the adjustment for inflation purposes would not be taken into account as income. These types of bonds, in other countries where I have seen them used, are well accepted by pensioners who do not want to see the value of their principal eroded by inflation. Of course, in these circumstances pensioners are less likely to lose any of their pension entitlements than is the case with the interest and the type of bonds that are available in Australia. It is not just pensioners who find these types of bonds attractive. Young people who are saving for a home also find them attractive because any savings that they have are not eroded by inflation while they are trying to increase their savings to attain the goal of being able to put a deposit on a block of land or a home.

In conclusion, the problem that I have outlined this afternoon is a real one for many pensioners in Australia. They have set aside a nest egg, something that they have been able to save to help them in their retirement, and they like to invest this money in order to receive some interest on it. But the interest that they receive has a component for inflation, which component is counted as part of their income. Of course, the real solution to this problem is to have zero inflation but I do not really see that ever happening in the Australian economy. I have outlined three possible solutions and I ask the Government to take them into consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Reid, I wish to point out that this is the honourable senator's first speech in this place. I trust that the usual courtesy will be extended to her on this occasion. I call Senator Reid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I have taken my place in the Senate because of the sudden death of John Knight. Honourable senators previously have expressed far more eloquently than I the great sense of loss, both nationally and for Canberra, which came in the wake of this sad event. I wish to thank those honourable senators, on behalf of the people of Canberra, for their eulogies. I endorse them. I will not attempt to emulate them because I cannot. Instead, I will pay my own tributes to John Knight's memory by trying as well as I am able to continue with the kind of service and understanding that he brought to the career of Senator for the Australian Capital Territory. I ask for the assistance of honourable senators and for the assistance of the community in measuring up to this high ideal.

SPEECH.PARA: With the exception of Senators Ryan, Kilgariff and Robertson, each senator here represents a State whose interests will at times seem to conflict with what might be said to be the wider interests of Australia. Senator Ryan and I are perhaps the only members of this chamber who could claim to speak for the whole of Australia without being limited by the interests which impinge on State rights. I believe that from time to time it is reasonable to look at ourselves as a nation and to try to see ourselves as others may see us in comparison with their lifestyles. Viewed in this way, by any standard this is an extraordinary country. By good fortune alone we are blessed with mountains of mineral ores, bauxite, plus energy in coal, uranium and natural gas far in excess of our needs. Few countries are as favoured as Australia in this material sense and, of course, scarcely any have the wonderful choice of climate which is the birthright of every Australian. Australian travellers returning from almost any country might kiss the ground when they compare lifestyles abroad with what we have in Australia.

I will look broadly and briefly at some of the comparisons which may be drawn. Any recent visitor to the United Kingdom will tell one to treat an English pound as if it were an Australian dollar. Ask any tourist who travels by car from Italy to France how much it costs him at about 66c a litre to fill his tank with petrol compared with about 35.1c a litre for a trip from Canberra to Sydney. A person may rent a house or a flat in Canberra for $85 a week. In London or Washington a person would be lucky to find the same flat or house for $150 a week. We are constantly, and rightly reminded of Australia's unemployment rate of 5.6 per cent but, put another way, we now have rates of unemployment and inflation which are far lower than those of most comparable countries. In the United States unemployment is about 7 per cent, in Italy it is 7.6 per cent, and in Britain it is 8.8 per cent. Only in Germany and Japan, of the Western style economies, is unemployment below that which we have in Australia, and even this bears closer examination.

In Australia the average weekly wage is $290, which compares favourably with the European Economic Community countries and Japan, in spite of the fact that the actual cost of living in this country is less than it is in those. Consider the traumas when President Carter tried to fix a minimum wage of $2.50 an hour. Add to this the fact that we have weekend penalty rates which terrify employers from other countries. On Sundays many Australian workers can be found fixing a boat, on a golf course or lounging at a weekender. On any strip of coast within motoring distance of a city one will find at weekends thousands of Australians relaxing or trying to start the family lawn mower. Show me a society at any time where the way of life of the common man and his or her opportunities have surpassed our own. Of course there are richer societies, more sophisticated and cultured societies, stronger and more technocratic societies than ours in the Middle East, Europe and North America, but I doubt that many of us feel tempted to emigrate. Nor would many of us feel tempted by the attractions of living permanently in Japan. It is too crowded compared with life in Australia and is resource poor.

There are many countries where parents will not let their children walk to school. Here some of us still leave our cars unlocked and one still hears police urging people to lock their homes. This is a country where few of us have seen a revolver and we do not want to. Where else in the world is this sense of security taken for granted as part of a way of life, even in our large cities? Ask people from almost any country whether they view our hospitals, schools and welfare benefits with scorn or whether they marvel in wonder and envy at a country that provides so much for its people. Honourable senators might canvass the world to discover a society as free from corruption as ours. Compare, if you will, our Public Service. At all levels it would be difficult to find any other as untarnished by scandal and blessed with the same sense of purpose and integrity.

Australian tourists in Asian countries will be constantly asked by Asians how they and their families can come to Australia and make a new life for themselves. What appeal this country must have that refugees will risk death, coming in what can scarcely be called seaworthy boats, for the chance to begin life again in this country. By almost any yardstick we are a blessed country. Our cities are orderly and mostly well run. We have very few rich people and very few poor people. There is no privileged Australian aristocracy. Our racial problems are minor compared with those which presently afflict so many countries. Our educational facilities are freely available. Australians have the privilege of changing jobs and location and offering their services in the open market place sure in the knowledge that if they fail society will support them in a manner far better than that in all but a handful of other countries.

Our legal system at all levels is an example which is envied and, although most of us take it for granted, few countries have access to such a system or else find that it is almost beyond the means of an ordinary citizen. The history of mankind reveals few examples where the freedom to work or not to work exists, where there is no civil conscription and where goods and services are so readily available in the market place, as is the situation in Australia. Australia has no elite immune from the law or which takes for granted positions in society denied to ordinary working Australians. We come as near to the ideals of liberty and equality as any society. This is not to pretend that we have no problems and injustices or that we should not strive to do better to create a fairer society. We must be vigilant to preserve the best of what we have won. We must recognise that there will never be a time or a society when there are no underprivileged people.

One of the fundamentals of the philosophy of the Liberal Party of Australia, and a very strong reason why I support its principles, is the social and economic mobility we can enjoy in this society. A cursory study of the background of most of Australia's successful men and women will show that their parents were generally of humble origins, whose endowments to their children were a teaching of sound values rather than financial encouragement. Liberalism as a philosophy guarantees that personal effort and the willingness to take a risk allows each individual to find his place in society, rather than have it ordained for him by another individual or institution.

Canberra is the capital of Australia for all of us and not just for me and the people who happen to live here. It should be the centre and focus of the national pride to which I have referred. Canberra is amongst the world's newest cities. Perhaps as yet it has not acquired the greatness of some of the ancient cities but it is already making its unique contribution to the ancient civilising institution of city life. As such it is a successful experiment in creativity. Situated as it is in a panoramic valley ringed by mountains, it is maturing into a national capital of which all Australians should be proud. Some people may not be aware of how beautiful it is or why it is that so many people are happy to be able to live here. I am sad to learn how many honourable senators in this chamber know so little about Canberra. I will be delighted to show Canberra to any honourable senator who would like to know it better and I hope that some honourable senators will respond to this most serious invitation. I know that members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly-on both sides-also would be pleased to be honourable senators' hosts for a day to help them get to know Canberra better. Canberra has a way to go but time will take care of that. Canberra needs to become part of Australian folklore, not just an isolated outpost of government.

There is one aspect of the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions relevant to Canberra's maturing. The Review referred to the transferring of increased responsibility and functions to the States; that is, increased regional rather than national responsibility. I believe I would be remiss if I did not briefly relate this to the Australian Capital Territory. Honourable senators may remember that about three years ago, the people of the Australian Capital Territory determined at a referendum not to accept any degree of responsibility for executive authority in the Australian Capital Territory. There was one overwhelming issue which was decisive in this result: This was a fear, based on uncertainty, of the financial consequences of accepting any degree of executive authority. I accept that that fear was real and prominent at the time of the referendum. I have no doubt that in the foreseeable future the people of the Australian Capital Territory will have no hesitation in accepting their democratic right to determine their own affairs. This view, however, will be subject to reasonable and acceptable financial arrangements being reached which do not prejudice the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I would add that a report on all Australian Capital Territory finances from the Commonwealth Grants Commission is an essential prerequisite to such agreements being reached.

But however the problems of Canberra are looked at, they pale into insignificance by world standards. To those of us who live and work here the path ahead is clear-while Canberra remains predominantly a Public Service town it will remain different. I have great admiration for the Public Service but it is my wish and, I believe, the wish of most Canberrans that we develop a commercial base. We must face up to the problems and to the costs of an unhealthy dependence upon the public sector. Only with commercial development will there be economic growth, a growth of employment opportunities and a choice of employment. This is necessary for my children, for those now here and for honourable senators' children who may want to come here.

Encouraging National Semiconductor Incorporated to come to Canberra is the direction in which we must go but it is only a beginning. If honourable senators regard Canberra only as a collection of second and third generation public servants running Australia, isolated from the mainstream of public life, then a change is overdue. Honourable senators can change this outlook by encouraging the economic development I have referred to so that Canberra can, in the future, provide a similar range of opportunities as do Australia's other cities. Mr President and honourable senators, my appeal to you is to be supporters of the national capital and to encourage your electors to have pride in their national capital.

An essential component of the city of Canberra as perceived by the original planners of the city was a national building on Capital Hill. The Federal Parliament decided in 1977 to proceed with the planning, design and construction of the new and permanent Parliament House on Capital Hill. It should be completed by 1988 in time for the bicentennial celebrations. At this moment honourable senators may have noticed-I am sure my colleague has-that excavation work for the foundations of the building is well advanced. I look forward with considerable anticipation to the completion of this magnificent building and I trust most sincerely that progress with the new Parliament House will proceed according to schedule and without delay. I know that this building will accord with the requirements established by the assessors who chose the winning design in that it will express in a symbolic way the unique national qualities, attributes, attitudes, aspirations and achievements of Australians. It will be a great building for many years, and a building not just for Canberra but for the nation.

Mr President and honourable senators, as I said, do not knock Canberra because the problems we have, you can help solve. This Senate was established as a States House, but it has matured into an institution with, I believe, a truly national outlook. I am confident that honourable senators will equally recognise and assist Canberra in the process of its development as the nation's capital.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.
I take this opportunity to congratulate Senator Reid on her maiden speech.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance 1981, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 6 of 1981, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.
