Before I proceed to speak to my motion, I would like to offer my congratulations to my senatorial colleague from the Australian Capital Territory, Senator Reid, who has just made her maiden speech in this place. It is a very heartening thing, I am sure my colleagues will understand, for me to hear another senator come into this chamber to put forward the virtues of Canberra and to ask for a better understanding and a greater recognition of the many virtues of our national capital. I congratulate Senator Reid.

It is an appropriate juxtaposition that in the order of business today we have just heard the maiden speech of Senator Reid and I have just moved a disallowance motion which has to do, I believe, with a number of important things which Senator Reid touched upon in her maiden speech. Senator Reid, like her much loved and much respected predecessor, Senator John Knight, is representing citizens of the Australian Capital Territory because the Labor Government legislated to have Senate representation for the Territory, something which had been denied to citizens of the Territories up to that time. We legislated in that way because we are a democratic party and we believe that the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory, like citizens of any other part of Australia, ought to be able to elect their representatives to make decisions that affect their lives.

Just as we legislated for Senate representation for the Australian Capital Territory, and are very happy to have senators of the calibre of Senator Reid representing the Australian Capital Territory in this place, so we legislated to give the people of the Australian Capital Territory a voice in their own local affairs via the body which is now known as the House of Assembly. So that that voice could be heard it was our view that elected representatives of the people on our local body ought to be represented on local bodies such as the Australian Capital Territory Health Commission, so that the services provided by that Commission or similar bodies could properly represent the views of citizens of the Australian Capital Territory.

It seems to me that that point of view should be unarguable in this place. Unfortunately, that is not the case. Unfortunately, we have since had from the Federal Government and, in particular, from the current Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Michael Hodgman, a series of acts which have eroded the democratic rights of Australian Capital Territory citizens. The motion I have moved concerns just such a very serious erosion.

I now turn to the ordinance which I seek to disallow. The effect of the ordinance will be to remove the three part time commissioners elected from the House of Assembly from the Australian Capital Territory Health Commission; to remove the three part time commissioners elected by or representative of health industry workers, for example, doctors, nurses, and so on; to leave a commission comprised of three full time commissioners appointed by the Minister and to create a health services council to advise the Minister and the Health Commission. The council comprises six to 10 members elected by nobody, but appointed by the Minister. Clearly, these changes are unacceptable in terms of the democratic principle of self-management, participation and community representation. They are changes which ought not be made, and changes which I urge honourable senators to disallow at an appropriate stage of this debate. The Capital Territory Health Commission is vital to the provision of health services to the people of the Australian Capital Territory, yet major changes, changes which all citizens of the Australian Capital Territory who believe in the principles of democracy and public participation must find abhorrent, were to be made without any proper debate in the Parliament. The ordinance was simply to lie on the table and become law unless the Opposition and the Australian Democrats seized the opportunity to compel debate by moving for its disallowance. This is a most unsatisfactory situation for the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory-a travesty of democratic principles. I think my colleague, Senator Cavanagh, who will support me in this motion, will have more to say about the unsatisfactory aspect of the legislative procedures which currently prevail in the Australian Capital Territory.

I point out too that the Ordinance was signed on Wednesday, 25 March, by the Governor-General, gazetted the following Friday and the commissioners were sacked on the same day. This again demonstrates the speed with which the Government can move to gazette and implement an ordinance when it wants to. It is unfortunate that the Government finds it impossible to move with such speed on other more desirable ordinances such as the new sexual offences ordinance for which we have been waiting for a very long time and for which we will wait a long time further if the slowness of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in this matter is any indication.

The removal from the Capital Territory Health Commission of its elected community representatives is a retrograde step which ends 46 years of elected community representation on Australian Capital Territory health authorities. I point out to honourable senators that since 1935 the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory have had elected community representatives on their central health authorities. Honourable senators do not need to be reminded that that period spans a large number of conservative governments-Liberal governments-as well as the Whitlam Government. The Government, at this stage, is trying to throw out a practice of community representation which has been in operation in the Territory since 1935. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) has given the reason for ending this long-standing democratic process. In his Press release on the day of the changes and the sackings he stated:
The Jamison Commission of Inquiry identified inefficiencies in the organisational structure of the Capital Territory Health Commission.

The Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals argued against community participation in the Capital Territory Health Commission on the following grounds. It stated:

This Commission has been informed that blatant stacking of the membership-that is the membership of the Health Commission-has occurred when matters of major policy have been under consideration, and that political party views have been put forward under the guise of community representation.

That is a rather strange statement. It appears to be a reflection of the Government's displeasure at the political colour of the three part time commissioners elected by the House of Assembly-two Australian Labor Party members and one Australian Democrat. Rather than accept the wishes of the Australian Capital Territory citizens to be represented by democratically elected members of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, the Government seeks to remove them by ordinance which, of course, is a rejection of the principle of elected representatives and the principle of democracy. The second argument advanced by the Jamison Commission against community participation on the Capital Territory Health Commission is that State health commissions are composed of experts and bureaucrats and do not have elected representatives. This argument totally ignores the fact that the States have representative governments in the form of democratically elected State parliaments to ensure that State health services are provided to community satisfaction. The Australian Capital Territory, as we all know, is not in this position. We have no elected State government. We have only the elected body, the members of the House of Assembly, and they are the people who need to represent us on health bodies.

The Ordinance-this is a very serious point-also ends worker participation in the formation of health policy by removing worker representatives from the Commission. Established in 1975, worker representation reflected a philosophical commitment by the Whitlam Government that workers in an industry should have some say in the development and formation of policy in that industry. As a part of the Fraser Government's obsession with destroying all initiatives of the Whitlam Government, this worker participation is now to be terminated without any assessment of the contribution that it has made. However, one section of the health work force, and one that is consistently favoured by the Government, is to retain its guaranteed representation. The Ordinance provides that one of the three commissioners shall be a medical practitioner. Well and good, but what about the nurses and the other health workers? Why are they to be excluded and the doctors to be allowed to remain? The health services council, which the Minister for Health claims will ensure continued community and professional input for the formulation of health policies, is a farce. I point out to honourable senators that the six to 10 members of this advisory council are simply nominees of the Minister, to be ignored or replaced if they do not toe the Government line.

I conclude by making the point I started with. All we want in the Australian Capital Territory is the operation of democratic principles that operate in every other part of Australia. We want the electors of the Australian Capital Territory to be able to elect their representatives to have a voice in the delivery of services that affect people living in the Australian Capital Territory. That is a modest enough requirement. It is a requirement which is fully met in other States in Australia. The Labor Party, when in Government, acted to ensure the proper implementation of this democratic principle. We heartily oppose this totally unjustified attempt by the Government to destroy a community representation on the local health commission. I urge honourable senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly do? Did it try to give fair and proper representation to the people of Canberra or did they try to stack it with Labor Party supporters?

—Mr President, I was concluding my remarks but I will make a comment on the interjection. The Jamison Commission claimed that there had been stacking. What 'stacking' meant, apparently, was that the people who had been elected by the House of Assembly were unacceptable to the Government because they had different political views from those of the Government. The House of Assembly representatives were properly elected by the people of the Australian Capital Territory. That representative body then voted to send representatives to the Health Commission. The result of that democratic procedure was that two Labor Party people and one Australian Democrat were elected.
—And naturally they chose Labor Party people.

—It seems that we have a completely new version of democracy that Senator Lewis, by way of interjection, is trying to inject into Australia-that is, that ballots are all right, the principle of electing your representatives is all right, as long as they turn out to be Liberals or members of the National Country Party. We on this side of the chamber do not accept that sort of suggestion. I understand that the Australian Democrats similarly are committed to the principle of community representation. I understand that they will support this motion. I urge those Government senators in this place such as Senator Missen and Senator Puplick to consider the straightforwardness of my argument that we ought to have community representation. We ought to have worker participation in the policy formulation of the Capital Territory Health Commission. I urge all honourable senators to support my disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion of disallowance. Before I speak to that motion, I too congratulate Senator Reid on making her maiden speech in the chamber today. Although I cannot agree with her on the great prosperity of Australia, nevertheless, she has a belief and, I thought, very effectively conveyed it to us. Perhaps I have never seen the beauty of Canberra as she has seen it.
—We paid for it, though.

—Yes, we paid for it. That is perhaps one of the reasons I fail to admire such beauty. I am sure that if we keep democracy in Canberra, we can make it a lot better place. I was very impressed with the new senator's remarks to the effect that while Canberra rejected the concept of self-government and States rights, mainly for financial reasons, she thinks that today, without the financial constraints they would accept a democratic life and the right to control their own future. In one area, Australian Capital Territory people have had that right-in the area of hospital control. This is an attempt to take away that right, much to the concern I would say, of Senator Reid. I feel confident, after listening to her maiden speech, that she will support the disallowance of the ordinance.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Lewis, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, is to follow me in this debate. I think he will convey to us the discussions held by and the attitude of the Committee. I do not want to go into that area other than to say that the Committee had a responsibility to consider the question and its conflict with civil liberties. We had to consider whether the matter was of sufficient substance to warrant a resolution or whether we were opposed to the new principle. I am opposed to the Ordinance insofar as it takes away the present worker participation. I refer to the representation of the elected body, as imperfect as it may be, which does not have the powers that Senator Reid hopes it will soon have. Nevertheless, it is an elected body which the people of Canberra elect from time to time according to their political views. Naturally when that elected body has a predominance of members from a particular political ideology, people of the ideology will receive appointments. The same applies with appointments overseas by this Government; appointments have not been made of people from the Australian Labor Party. The same thing can be said; the composition of representation changes from time to time. The question of stacking does not arise. Appointments are made according to the majority in a particular house; it is the numbers game.

The Committee considered this matter. Only one member took the view that there may be a breach of the rights and liberties of the individual. I was not that member. I cannot see whether a hospital being run by a medical commission, a board or anything else has anything to do with the rights and liberties of the individual. I think the individual will receive the same treatment in the hospital. Senator Ryan expressed some remarks that I have expressed in this chamber. We want some mechanism whereby we can stop a Minister from acting upon a regulation because of its publication. It may be that one of the Houses of Parliament will reject it. As I mentioned before, there should be a safeguard. We must consider the matter in the affirmative. Trouble occurs because of the long duration between sittings of the Parliament. I think any regulation should at least stipulate a time limit. Perhaps it could be a short time. A copy of the regulation should be supplied to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Where an expression of doubt has been given, the regulation should not be effective until at least the Parliament has had the time permitted under the Acts Interpretation Act to decide whether it supports or opposes the regulation.

There is a greater aspect contained in this matter. Since I have been a member of this Chamber I have gone to some lengths to uphold the dignity of the Senate and to recognise its power. I admit that at times only Jimmy Odgers and myself thought anything of it. I think the Senate is an important House. At one time I was opposed to second Houses of Parliament, but I am more convinced than ever that they are essential today. I do not think some legislation that operates in Queensland would operate had it had the consideration of two Houses of Parliament. Therefore, the Senate has an important role. One role relates to the supervision of everything that is done by the other House.

I have always maintained in accordance with our Constitution that this House has only one superior, and that is the people of Australia. The Senate has a superiority, and is a higher court than any other institution in Australia. We have made mistakes. The attitude of the now Government members in 1975 discounted the theory I have mentioned. They said: 'The Senate is the superior court. It is more superior than the people. It is more superior than the people's elected House. The Government cannot govern because the Senate has decided that it cannot'. Although I do not follow that belief, I looked with pride and justification at the power of the Senate and the attitude that the honourable senators took at that time. I think they did worse in 1974. At least the Prime Minister did not resign in 1974. When we reassembled after the double dissolution, the Bills whose rejection by the Senate had resulted in the double dissolution were resubmitted, the Government having gone to the people and been returned. Rather than the Senate accepting the people's mandate, it voted against those Bills and threw itself open to be swamped by the numbers of a lower House to enable those Bills to pass into law in this country. One can be excused for believing that the pride of some members of this Chamber caused them to think that the Senate was even greater than the people. I do not accept that it is greater than the people, but I do accept that it is the greatest and most powerful institution in this country.

That aspect links up with the fact that a similar ordinance to abolish the elected members of the Canberra Community Hospital Board was thrown out by this Senate in 1967. The ordinance was brought in and thrown out. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) said: 'Well, the Senate did not reject it. It introduced another ordinance to supersede it. It took out the offending parts which the Senate was complaining about. Therefore, there was no necessity for the regulation'. I think it is belittling the Senate to say that the alteration was made without the power of the Senate. It was because of the power of the Senate to disallow that the alteration, to my mind, was made. Several honourable senators spoke on the matter and disagreed with the appointed board and said that the elected board, the people's representative, was democratic and better. On 26 September 1967, Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin said:

The Minister for Health (Dr Forbes) has asked me to advise honourable senators that in the light of the views recently expressed in this chamber concerning the composition of the Management Board of the Canberra Community Hospital, the Government has repealed Ordinance No. 28 of 1967--
That is the Ordinance to which the notice of motion for disallowance related-
and replaced it by Canberra Community Hospital Ordinance (No. 2) 1967 which was gazetted yesterday and tabled in both Houses today.
The Government has not been unmindful of the necessity for the Hospital Management Board to be representative of the people of Canberra--
The Government was cognisant of that and expressed a desire in regard to it-

and has had regard to a general opinion that representation should be expressed in the legislation itself rather than being left to ministerial decision. Accordingly, the new law provides that the board of five should include two elected members of the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council, elected by the Council for a term of 3 years.
That was the attitude of the Government then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you agree that it is pretty obvious that it would have been disallowed but for the Government substituting its new one?

—We will try to examine the situation. I do not think that the Government, having made an ordinance disallowing the appointment of board members, changed its mind without some pressure. Senator Sir Kenneth Anderson, who was the Leader of the Government in the Senate at the time, then said:

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest for the consideration of the Opposition that this matter may well now be redundant in view of the statement made by the Minister representing the Minister for Health.
Senator Cohen, who was then Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, said:
I suggest that the matter be allowed to be adjourned. We want to consider the position in the light of the statement made by the Minister.

In effect, what was being said was: 'If this does not meet the requirements of the authors of the motion to disallow, we will act accordingly'. Plainly, the threat was there. We note that on the following day Senator Murphy sought leave to withdraw the ordinance. Among other statements, he said.

I had given notice of a motion of disallowance of the Canberra Community Hospital Ordinance 1967. The motion was moved by Senator Dittmer and is pending before the Senate. The effect of the new ordinance that has been tabled is that the purpose of the motion to disallow has been achieved already. Assuming that that portion of the new ordinance stood no further purpose would be gained by the motion. The motion is not strictly ineffective because it could be required under certain circumstances. But the substance of the motion to disallow has been achieved.
Complete satisfaction was achieved. There was a complete capitulation by the Government to the expressions of the Senate, acceptance of its power. Senator Murphy added:

The position now is that the new system provides for three appointed members and two persons appointed by the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council. It is open to those in the community who might take objection to the new system to refer to honourable senators the points that they want to have considered or raised, or for any honourable senator to take steps to deal with the substance of the new ordinance. The ordinance to which objection was taken has been effectively removed. Nothing further is to be gained by the motion. Therefore I ask on behalf of myself, who gave notice, and Senator Dittmer, who moved the motion, that it be withdrawn.

I submit that this Senate-the highest power in the land-clearly has made a decision on this question, yet some flunkey of a Minister can bring in an ordinance and, merely by publishing it, dismiss overnight the board that the Senate protected. That can be done by the exercise of the power of a Minister. We have a responsibility to ensure that when the Senate has made a decision-I acknowledge its right to change its mind at any time-it should not be set aside by a Minister. Honourable senators should make the decision. I do not say that the ordinance is wrong. My contention is that, in view of the requirements of democracy and of workers' representation, it is wrong; that conforms to my belief. I do not see that the ordinance harms anyone greatly. The only persons harmed by it are we senators. We let a Minister come along and say: 'The Senate has done this, but I will do it my way' and then put it into operation the very next day. My submission to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is that, because of that decision of 1967, this proposal should take the form of legislation so that the Senate may have the right to indicate whether it has changed its mind or has held to its belief of 1967. That is the only democratic course that I can recommend. We do not do justice to ourselves or to the high ideals that Senator Lewis expressed today regarding this great city if we let this matter go without challenge or without voting it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak to this matter, I join other honourable senators in congratulating Senator Reid for her fine maiden speech. We thoroughly enjoyed it. Unlike Senator Cavanagh, I agree with all of the sentiments that she expressed concerning our great nation and this city.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, to speak to the motion of Senator Ryan for the disallowance of the Health Commission Amendment Ordinance 1981. While the Senate Committee was considering this ordinance in accordance with its usual procedures, it received a resolution of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly and a submission by five former part time commissioners which requested the Committee to examine the ordinance under the Committee's principles (B) and (C) to ensure that the ordinance did not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties and did not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administative decisions which were not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal.

The Committee acceded to this request and further decided to consider, under its principle (D), whether the ordinance contained matters that were more appropriate for parliamentary enactment. In accordance with the intention expressed in the Committee's 64th report, it sought the reaction of the House of Assembly and the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory to the applicability of principle (D) to the ordinance. It also sought the views of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) on the three principles and took note of a substantial number of submissions which sought withdrawal of the ordinance.

After considering the submissions, the views of the House of Assembly and the Joint Committee, and a detailed response by the responsible Minister, which incorporated an opinion from the Attorney-General, the Committee determined that the ordinance did not offend against any of its principles. However, the decision was not unanimous, as one member considered that it offended against principle (B) and another objected to it under principle (D). The Senate will appreciate that, in accordance with its terms of reference, the Committee did not review what it regards as policy matters, so the decision taken by the Committee does not determine the desirability or otherwise of the ordinance. However, the Committee was unequivocally of the view that the matters contained in the ordinance were of such importance as to warrant substantive debate in the Senate. Therefore, it welcomes the opportunity for debate which Senator Ryan's motion has afforded. The debate in this chamber on the disallowance motion is, of course, in no way limited to the criteria of the Committee. That will explain why some honorable senators who are members of the Committee agreed that members of the Committee should not move for disallowance of the ordinance but may speak and vote differently in this chamber today. That is the report that I make to the Senate as the Chairman of the Standing Committee.

I wish to add only one other matter. It is in relation to what Senator Cavanagh expressed today. I listened very carefully to Senator Cavanagh when he put his proposition to the Committee. At first it weighed heavily with me as a matter which might persuade me to object to this ordinance under the Committee's principle (D), or in any event to object to the ordinance as a senator. But I think the proposition put by Senator Cavanagh fails to recognise that since that Ordinance was set aside in 1966, an entirely new ordinance was passed in 1975 creating a new commission and that since that date the people of the Australian Capital Territory have had an opportunity to have self-government and have rejected the proposition. It seems to me, those two facts having taken place, that the argument which Senator Cavanagh put to the Senate this afternoon is no longer valid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the motion moved by Senator Ryan for disallowance of the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance 1981. To those people listening to this broadcast this might sound like a debate in reverse. In fact it is. It is one of those occasions in which the Senate looks at legislation with a view to undoing it rather than passing it. As we know, there is a device of government by regulation. It may surprise a great number of listeners to this debate to know that decisions can be made by a group of only three Ministers, provided they can get the concurrence of the Governor-General to sign an ordinance. The device is a regulation stemming from an Act of Parliament. But the actual thrust of the regulation need not be spelt out in the Act of Parliament. The group of Ministers might think: 'We have power under the Act already passed by the Parliament to do a certain thing. Now we will do it by regulation, by an ordinance, in this manner'. Therefore, acts can be performed by a group of three Ministers in company with the Governor-General. The Governor-General almost inevitably signs an ordinance if he believes it is a decision of Cabinet or of a responsible Cabinet authority and if he believes that the wording of the ordinance is in conformity with what Cabinet intended. In my experience as a Minister the Governor-General never canvassed the merits of the case at the meeting of the Executive Council when the ordinance was signed; nor did the Ministers. Once it is before the Executive Council it is signed as a matter of course.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case it was obviously agreed by the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, and, I am sure, by the Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, that the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 should be signed. That Ordinance removes the six elected part time community and staff representatives from the Australian Capital Territory Health Commission. The old Commission, before this ordinance had any effect, had nine representatives on it, six of whom were elected part time community and staff representatives. Three of those six were from the elected House of Assembly-fortuitously they were two members of the Australian Labor Party and one member of the Australian Democrats-and three were from the health professions, that is nurses, doctors and so on. I was quite taken with the way in which Senator Ryan described that as participatory democracy. In fact it is. Three people from the professions were actually on the Commission and responsible for such activity in Canberra. They were elected for three-year terms in July 1979.

The signing of the document at Government House on a day back in March, I believe, means that that is no longer to be the case. The Minister has said that those people are now to be replaced with people appointed by the Government. It is very clear that the Health Commission in Canberra was in fact an independent body in that it had nine representatives, six of whom were elected-three from the House of Assembly and three from the health profession-and only three of whom were appointed by the Government. It is equally clear from the date of the application of the Ordinance that it is no longer an independent body but is now a creature of the government of the day.

One wonders why the Minister made that decision. Was it because the former Commission was going against Government policy? Was it because it opposed cutbacks in staff ceilings? Was it because it resisted orders to reduce services in other health areas in Canberra? It did all those things and one must conclude that they were the reasons. I mention that so that people in the Australian Capital Territory can judge for themselves the reasons for the Minister's action. I must say that it is typical of the Government's callous disregard for democratic processes in general. As far as I have been able to ascertain, the part time elected representatives were regarded as doing an extremely good and professional job and the Commission as a whole was being run with commendable efficiency. The Australian Democrats see no reason whatsoever to dispense with the services of elected representatives and to replace them with people who will be mere ciphers of the Government, especially as they had only 12 months to go.

I add another reason why we object. It concerns a basic principle. It adds to what Senator Cavanagh had to say. The way in which this Government has acted is almost a contempt of this Parliament. It is the second time in the last few weeks that it has acted with regard to the Australian Capital Territory in contempt of the Parliament in this way. The Executive Council may pass an ordinance or a regulation which may be against what I believe in, but I would say that it has the right to pass it. But there is something different about an ordinance which may have escaped the notice of people listening to this debate. An ordinance has all the force of the law and can impact itself on all citizens of Canberra. Once an ordinance has been passed its whole effect can be nullified if either House of the Parliament disallows that ordinance by a simple majority within 15 sitting days of the ordinance being signed, proclaimed or whatever the word is. One would have thought that a government, being conscious of the democratic process, would have said: 'We will pass this ordinance but before we take any action stemming from it we will do the decent thing and ascertain whether the democratically elected people of Australia, namely, members of the House of Representatives and the Senate, will allow it to pass. In other words, we will see whether they move to disallow it'. But that was not so.

The very day after the Governor-General signed that piece of paper, the Government sacked the Commission. It was an identical action to what happened with that monstrous ordinance that the Government introduced some weeks ago to make a criminal offence of the laws of assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. Because of that hastily drawn up ordinance, people have been arrested and charged with criminal offences before the Parliament had an opportunity of saying yes or no on whether it agreed or disagreed with it. I would have thought that common courtesy demanded that the Government wait the 15 sitting days until either House had approved the regulations. I am surprised and amazed that the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Senator Lewis, did not refer to that in his response.

This can work two ways. I am conscious that very controversial legislation is before the Senate which will be debated after the suspension of the sitting for dinner. I refer to the conciliation and arbitration legislation. I remind the Senate of something quite exciting that can stem from that legislation. To give us power to have secret ballots under that legislation, I understand that the Government will need regulations. Regulations will have to be brought down after the passage of this amendment. There are not 15 sitting days left before this session of the Senate concludes. Some sitting days will still be left when Parliament resumes in August when a motion for disallowance of part of that conciliation and arbitration legislation could be passed. I remind the Government of that period of discomfiture it could suffer in that area in the future.

In conclusion I also wish to congratulate Senator Reid on a splendid maiden speech. I suggest and commend to her that a way in which she can write herself indelibly into the history books of this nation and this Territory is to support a motion for disallowance of an ordinance straight after having made her maiden speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the disallowance motion moved by Senator Ryan to the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance. I am not a representative of the people of the Australian Capital Territory but I feel a responsibility to speak on this matter because I have had many representations from people and organisations in this Territory. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I have had the responsibility of joining in consideration of whether that Committee would take action on this matter. As has been said by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Lewis, the Committee has not moved for disallowance. But as honourable senators will see from the statement Senator Lewis has made, the Committee was very strongly moved by the fact that there would be a debate in the Senate about this matter. Although we had different views on the extent to which the Ordinance may or may not have fallen within the various criteria the Committee has-I am one who thinks that the Ordinance fails to comply with the second of the principles of the Committee, namely, that it does trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties; but that is not a general view--
—It is a substantial view, though.

—It is a view which I hold. I feel that although people might not think that the right to vote-a right which has been held for some 46 years-is a matter that is often called a civil liberty, it is an essential part of the democratic process and one which has been enjoyed by people for a long time. Accordingly, I think it probably does come within that criterion of the Committee and possibly the fourth criterion Senator Cavanagh has spoken of. We have decided not to take action because we feel that the whole matter of policy which is involved in this area will be debated. Therefore, it is to that area that I will particularly address my views. I know that this matter arises from the recommendations of the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. I think I should read again recommendation 90. There is not a great deal in the report that speaks about this matter, but recommendation 90 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Capital Territory Health Commission be reorganised to separate major policy determination from the management of hospitals and other services. Policy determination to be the responsibility of appropriately knowledgeable Commissioners appointed by the Commonwealth Government. Management, maintenance and operations of hospitals and other services to be the responsibility of an Area Health Board, which may include elected or nominated representatives of local bodies.
One will note that representatives may or may not be included in that. Clearly, on matters of policy, it is proposed that the elected representatives be removed.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting, I was speaking on the motion which had been moved by Senator Ryan to disallow the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance 1981. I described the discussions which had taken place in the Regulations and Ordinances Committee about this matter and the fact that there is a debate in this chamber now which can deal fully with the policy which is involved in the matter before us, namely, the changes in the Capital Territory Health Commission arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I had quoted from the recommendations of the Jamison report as a result of which the elected representatives of the Australian Capital Territory, of the House of Assembly and those appointed to represent the staff concerned with health matters, are to be removed from that body. In that report it is stated that the removal of representatives results from the stacking of the representation from the House of Assembly. I do not know the details or the reasons for that because it has not been made clear to members of this chamber what is involved. I think the representation consists of two Australian Labor Party members and one Australian Democrat. While one might worry at the extent to which that is a representation which does not cover the field, that it is somewhat disproportionate, I do not know that that can be called stacking because it is apparently as a result of an election in the Assembly.

I am concerned to find among the representations that have been made to honourable senators about this matter, the information which Mr Peter Vallee, the President of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, has informed us of regarding the contacts that he made with Mr Jamison, who presented the report, when he asked Mr Jamison to supply evidence to support the allegations contained in the report. Mr Vallee has reported Mr Jamison saying to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, at a meeting on 2 March:

I rang Mr Jamison shortly after the report was made public and asked him what instances those charges related to . . . Mr Jamison replied 'Oh, surely, there is something in the report about that' and when I said that I had read it as carefully as I could and could not find anything, he could only say, 'You will have to take it at face value'. In other words Mr Jamison could not recollect one example to justify those serious accusations, not one.

He then talks about his discussion with the secretary who, likewise, could not produce any evidence. The evidence on which this decision is based is not public. It concerns me that a decision of such importance to people in this Territory should be based on such flimsy evidence.

In the course of discussion and argument in this matter some people have referred to the fact that self government was denied by the people of the Australian Capital Territory in 1978. It is certain that they had a choice and they voted against it. We heard today, in the excellent maiden speech made by Senator Reid her hopes that in the near future there would be an acceptance of self government by this Territory. I believe that one cannot take the decision by the people of the Territory as being any indication that they do not desire to have any other lower or lesser form of self government than they have had, in this case for 46 years, including the rights of health and the right to vote for people to represent them in this area.

Comparisons have been made with the States. People say: 'In the States you do not elect people to health commisions'. That is true; but in the States in this country there is self government; there are full elections; and those are not to be found in the Australian Capital Territory. I do not believe that we should inflict any further punishment upon the people of the Territory. I believe it was a foolish decision which was made in 1978 and I hope that if the people get a chance they will vote differently on another occasion. But that is no reason for denying them the areas in which they have some form of self government and some opportunity of expressing their views. In the last few days I received a letter from the Committee for Self Government in the Australian Capital Territory. It is signed by J. F. Ley and R. L. Chapman. In that document-which I will seek leave to incorporate-are set out arguments which I find basically sound and which effectively summarise the views which I have formed in discussion of this matter. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Committee for Self Government, in the ACT, P.O. Box 1062, Woden, ACT 2606 Dear Senator,

On behalf of the Committee for Self Government in the ACT we write to express our strong opposition to the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 (the amending ordinance) and to seek your support for a motion to disallow it.

The amending ordinance, which appears to be based on certain ill-founded recommendations of the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals (the Jamison Commission) has the effect of replacing the democratic and participatory structure of the Capital Territory Health Commission (the Health Commission) which has functioned effectively for six years, with a wholly appointed body of Commissioners which is not representative of, or accountable to, the people of the ACT, the registered doctors, the nurses or other employees involved in the delivery of health care in the Territory. Our Committee regards this as a rejection of basic democratic principles in relation to the rights of the people of the ACT.
Grounds for disallowance:
Our opposition to the Ordinance is based on the following grounds:

(1) Need for restructuring unfounded: (a) The criticisms made of the present structure by the Jamison Commission are unsourced and appear to be mainly based on a confidential submission alleging 'blatant stacking of the membership when matters of major policy have been under consideration' and that 'political party views have been put forward under the guise of community representation'.

The Jamison Commission cites no instance of such alleged 'stacking' or of the expression of so called 'political party views', and gives no indication that it attempted to verify these allegations. As to the claim of 'blatant stacking' it is surely not possible for such an event to occur, since only appointed or elected members have standing to participate in Commission business.

The claim that political party views were being put forward is surely one of a subjective nature, and without any details being given to support it, it is submitted that it should be viewed with scepticism. Perhaps it simply refers to occasions when members of the Commission have declined to accept uncritically certain policies of the Government in relation to hospitals in the ACT such as cuts in staff and resources-policies which have recently been causing considerable controversy across the country in view of opposition by both Coalition and Labor State Government's to the Commonwealth Government's proposed reduction in Federal funding of State hospitals.

(b) The Jamison Commission refers to the Health Commission as being-''unique in Australia because it has the dual role of assisting the Minister for Health to meet his statutory obligations for planning developing and administering public health services while also being responsible for day to day management of the various institutions and services''.

The Jamison Commission contrasts the Health Commission with health commissions and departments in the States and the Northern Territory which, it says, are responsible only for assisting the local Health Minister with the planning, development and administration of health services, and are staffed by officers specifically appointed by virtue of their skills in policy formulation, planning, both short term and strategic, and resource allocation.

In recommending that the Commission should have only this broad policy function and that it should consist entirely of appointed Commissioners ''with proven management skills chosen for their capacity to judge between the competing health needs of the services'' the Jamison Commission has failed to have sufficient regard for the fact that the ACT does not have a local representative government-the Minister for Health being a member of the Federal Government and not accountable to the people of Canberra in the way that a State or Northern Territory Minister is accountable to the people of his State or Territory.

The restructuring has the effect of making the Health Commission much less accountable to the people of Canberra in relation to fundamental policy and planning matters which involve issues that cannot be resolved simply on the basis of expertise and good management. Many matters require value judgments to be made and an appreciation by Commissioners of the real needs and wishes of members of Canberra's community. House of Assembly members and elected health workers, are much more likely to be aware of community needs and wishes than are appointed ''experts''. In view of the availability to the pre-existing Health Commission of expert advice from public servants employed by the Commission and the expert opinions of the elected medical, nursing and ancilliary employee Commissioners and the three appointed full-time Commissioners it cannot seriously be suggested that insufficient expertise could be drawn upon by the Commission.
(2) Removal of elected Commissioners regressive and undemocratic.

The removal of the elected Commissioners constitutes a major regression in the context of gradual development of more democratic and accountable institutions in the ACT and in Australia as a whole. It also contravenes at least the spirit of the outcome of the referendum held in the ACT in 1978 when a clear majority of electors voted for a continuation, for the time being, of the existing arrangements for governing the Territory-arrangements which included the structure and functions of the Health Commission. The Government has ignored the strong opposition expressed by the House of Assembly, which was elected by the people of the ACT only 2 years ago, to the removal of its chosen Health Commissioners and the other elected Commissioners all of whom had expertise in the delivery of health services. There has been no call from the ACT community for these fundamental changes to the Health Commission-only confidential, unsubstantiated allegations to the Jamison Commission by an unnamed individual or individuals.
(3) Grounds for disallowance similar to those on which Canberra Community Hospital Ordinance disallowed in 1967

In substance, the axing of the elected representatives in the Health Commission mirrors that imposed by the Canberra Community Hospital Ordinance 1967, which was disallowed by the Senate. (See in particular Hansard Vol. S.35 pp. 492-512). That ordinance provided for the removal of all five elected representatives from the 8 member Canberra Community Hospital Board, in the interests of ''good administration and cost efficiency''.

In supporting the motion for disallowance, a number of senators referred to the importance of the residents of Canberra, who had (and still have) no local government or State Government, being able to be involved in the administration of their community hospital through elected representatives. These speakers accepted that there should be a number of appointed members on the board, but emphasized the long history of elected local residents being members of the hospital board, and the importance in a democratic society, of having members of the community, responsible to the community, involved in decision making concerning the functioning of hospitals.
The issues raised by the amending ordinance are similar to those raised by the 1967 ordinance and it should be disallowed for the same reasons.
(4) Future Effects on Canberra Community Institutions

If the amending ordinance is not disallowed it will set a dangerous precedent jeopardizing the democratic elements in the few remaining statutory bodies in the ACT (e.g. the ACT Schools Authority and the Legal Aid Commission, (ACT)) which still remain community and worker participation.

The Committee for Self Government in the ACT calls for the amending ordinance to be disallowed and asks that the Minister for Health consult with the reinstated Health Commission with a view to resolving any differences which may have arisen in relation to the work of the Commission.
3 June 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. There are very valuable remarks in that letter which indicate that the Minister, being a member of the Federal Government, is not accountable to the people of Canberra in the way that the State and Federal Territory Ministers are to the people of their States or Territories. Mr Ley and Mr Chapman point out:

SPEECH.PARA: Many matters require value judgments to be made and an appreciation by Commissioners of the real needs and wishes of members of Canberra's community.

I believe that they are salient reasons why one should have, in an area like health, which is so close to the people, the knowledge that elected commissioners would have to offer. Reference has already been made in this debate to the fact that in 1967 an attempt was made by the Federal Government to remove the elected commissioners who were then exercising influence in the health area. Of course there was a debate. Senator Cavanagh has dealt with this matter at some length. It was pretty obvious to me, when I read the debate that the Senate would have disallowed the then move to remove the elected commissioners. Before that happened, the Government withdrew the ordinance and replaced it with another which was presented with a statement from Dame Annabelle Rankin on behalf of the Government and which effectively put an end to the debate. It is obvious that, on the only other occasion when this matter has been before the Senate, the Senate has indicated very clearly its belief in elected representation on health matters for the Territory.

Another question to which I must make reference is whether matters like this ought to be dealt with by an ordinance which can only be disallowed by legislation. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which I have the honour of being Chairman, presented a report in 1977 in which it set out the basis on which laws for the Territories ought to be brought in either by legislation or by ordinance. One thing that was said in that report was that legislation that was of a particular territory:
which is socially innovative or affects fundamental rights and liberties, if it is of the kind referred to in such paragraphs (d) and (e)
Those are ones that are normally made by Acts of a State or by municipal corporations-should be made by ordinance. We went on to say:

The Committee recommends to the Senate that if the Committee on Regulations and Ordinances reports that an Ordinance is of this nature, then such Ordinance should be made the subject of a substantive debate in the Senate.

I believe this is an ordinance which deals with fundamental rights and liberties. I believe what we really need here is not just a debate in the Senate where, unfortunately, all we can do is either disallow the ordinance or let it stand, where we have not the opportunity to amend it and where, therefore, the powers of the Senate are limited. We have a situation where we must decide tonight what is to be done. We have a situation where there has been no consultation with the House of Assembly as to the type of health regulation and ordinance that it requires for this Territory. The President has drawn our attention, as a Committee and as the Senate, to the fact that there has been no such consultation.

I have thought carefully about the situation and the matter which we have before us. I have certainly formed the view that I should vote for the disallowance of this ordinance. I believe that here we have rights which have existed in the people of the Territory for some 46 years in one form or another. Here we are hurriedly accepting a very small part of the Jamison Report. I do not know very much about Mr Jamison but I am not prepared to base my judgment on what is just to the people of the Territory on a throw-away remark or an undisclosed piece of evidence which Mr Jamison has used as the basis for his one recommendation of many. I believe that the regulation is unjust to the people of the Territory. I, therefore, propose to vote for disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will delay the Senate for only a couple of minutes to advert to the comments made earlier by Senator Lewis. Before I do so, however, I congratulate Senator Reid for her maiden speech. Senator Lewis outlined to the Senate, as I understood it, the principles upon which the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances makes its considerations. He included in those principles one which encouraged a substantive debate in the Parliament on matters affecting the Australian Capital Territory. I give my whole-hearted support to that principle. I cannot see how it has been transgressed in this matter. After all, the Capital Territory Health Commission was established by ordinance. I cannot see why it cannot be disbanded by ordinance. The powers of the Senate and the House of Representatives enable a substantive debate to take place on this matter.
—Should it be disbanded? That is the question.

—I am not speaking to that point at present. I have formed a conclusion about that from the debate that has taken place both publicly and in this chamber. I might say that I propose to vote with the Government on this proposition. Concerning the aspect of propriety, I agree that these sorts of matters which affect the Australian Capital Territory ought to be the subject of substantive debate in the Parliament. I believe that the powers of the Senate to move for the disallowance of such an ordinance provide the basis for such a debate. I only hope that this high principle will be maintained by Government spokesmen when the deregulation of shop trading hours is considered by the Parliament. That, again, should be a matter of substantive debate in the Parliament. Of course, it will not be a matter of substantive debate if it is included in an omnibus piece of legislation. I am being consistent at this point by accepting the statement of Senator Lewis that these matters ought to be matters of substantive debate. Equally, I hope that the Government and Senator Lewis will be consistent in their attitude when it comes to consideration of clause 90 of the omnibus legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have taken part in this debate, which is concerned with a motion to disallow the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance relating to the Capital Territory Health Commission. The Capital Territory Health Commission is concerned with the management of a very major public enterprise. The quality of its management is important to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. It manages several institutions, has many staff and is responsible for providing the health services for the whole Territory. The debate has thrown up several different ways in which one can approach this issue and in which one can attempt to resolve the difficulties of setting one desirable principle against another desirable principle. A balance has to be drawn somewhere. It is said that Georges Clemenceau once said that war was too serious to be left to the generals. I am not quite sure what he meant, but it could well be that in the conduct of health services it does not automatically follow that the health professionals are the people best able to make the management decisions which are needed.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue is really a simple one: Who should manage the Capital Territory Health Commission to bring the greatest good to the people of the Territory? The choice is whether the benefits which might flow from the community being able to elect its managers are such that they offset the benefits which might flow from the very best professional managers being chosen by appointment to carry out that function. Community input, of course, will not be lost even under the proposals which are before the Senate at this stage, as the Government, as I will set out later, has some means of ensuring that community input remains.

Since its establishment on 1 July 1975 the Capital Territory Health Commission has operated on the basis of full time and part time membership. The full time members-the Chairman, the Deputy Chairman and, more recently, a full time commissioner who was a nurse-were appointed by the Governor-General, while the part time members were included in the membership of the Commission to represent the community in which the health services were provided, the staff and the private medical practitioners who were providing the health services. At the time the legislation was drawn up in 1975 it was felt that the appropriate way to articulate community views was through the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly. I recall that Senator Chipp was a member of the Liberal Party at that stage and we considered this matter together. I think he will recall the lobbying that was done at that stage. Quite vigorous argument took place as to what was the best method of responding to the express wishes of some of the professional groups. The legislation at that time provided for an election to take place among the members of the Assembly to bring forward the names of three people to represent the Assembly on the Commission. It also provided for elections among the employees of the Commissiof who were appropriately qualified by their membership of various organisations and among medical practitioners. Since that time the Australian Capital Territory has been able to test by referendum certain principles of self-government. Other honourable senators have mentioned this fact in their contributions. In 1978 a referendum was held. Not just a narrow majority, but two-third of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory voted against the offer of self-government which that referendum held out. It was, to say the least, an expression of view which was significant if not decisive.

Our problem in approaching this matter is to try to ask what weight we should put upon the most thorough evaluation of institutional health services which has ever been carried out in Australia. Honourable senators are correct in saying that we should not assume that it is the only word or the last word. The question is: What is the correct amount of weight to be put upon an evaluation exercise, upon the judgment of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals in Australia and the various points which were made in that judgment concerning the Capital Territory Health Commission. It is true to say that, from the point of view of government, the operation of the elected Commission has become more and more difficult. It has even been suggested that it has become almost unworkable.

Over the years one of the major problems has been with the decision-making process, which is a very difficult process in the running of a large bureaucratic structure. It involves the capacity to make hard decisions and hard choices. Over the years it seems that it has lacked objectivity. It seems that there has been some inability to dead with the very real problems of divided loyalty which face those people who are called upon, on the one hand, to make hard management decisions and, on the other, to answer the interests to whom they have to respond at the time of an election. I will not go through the unsatisfactory features in detail except to quote from the report of the Jamison Committee of Inquiry, which reported as follows:
This Commission has been informed that blatant stacking of the membership has occurred when matters of major policy have been under consideration-

TALK.START.PARA: —I dealt with that in my remarks. There is no need to repeat that.
—I did not interfere with the honourable senator's speech and I will make my speech in my own way. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: And that political party views have been put forward under the guise of community representation. The Commission considers that such events must interfere with the efficient management of the health services in the Territory and is of the view that two major changes should be undertaken.

That is the problem. How does one balance up the need for the most efficient functioning of health services for the benefit of the people of the Territory against the benefits that are to flow from certain elected membership? These changes that Mr Jamison then proposed were in recommendation No. 90 of the report. That recommendation stated:

The Capital Territory Health Commission be reorganised to separate major policy determination from the management of hospitals and other services. Policy determination to be the responsibility of appropriately knowledgeable commissioners appointed by the Commonwealth Government.
Appropriately knowledgeable commissioners are not necessarily bureaucrats. The report continues:
Management, maintenance and operations of hospitals and other services to be the responsibility of an area health board, which may include elected or nominated representatives of local bodies.

I remind the Senate once again that this was an evaluation document which looked specifically at the operation of hospitals and health services in Australia. The problems arising from the conflict of interest which elected members had between their responsibilities to the organisation or group that elects them and their duties as commissioners led the Jamison Committee of Inquiry to conclude that the organisational structure of the Capital Territory Health Commission was inappropriate. I quote again from Commission of Inquiry's report which states:

The functions of planning, major policy determination and resource allocation, as well as the parliamentary obligations, should be dealt with by the Capital Territory Health Commission as a separate organisation, responsible both to the field and the Minister. There should not be elected representative members of this Commission, rather appointed commissioners with proven management skills chosen for their capacity to judge between the competing health needs of the services.
The inquiry further commented:

This Commission is unique in Australia because it has the dual role of assisting the Minister for Health to meet his statutory obligation for planning, developing and administering public health services while also being responsible for day to day management of the various institutions and services. In its first task it functions as an equivalent to the State health departments and commissions, but its second responsibility is normally delegated by the health authorities to institutional boards of directors which must work within the limits imposed by the policies of the respective authorities.

That is a fair analysis of the way in which the Capital Territory Health Commission is structured and it indicates some of the special difficulties which face those people who try to make it work. The report further states:
A number of witnesses have informed this commission both in public and private hearings, of the barriers to efficiency which arise from this unusual arrangement.

The Government accepted these recommendations of the inquiry. It was not something which we wrote. It was written by an independent inquiry which was made up of three people who spent a lot of time, with a big secretariat assisting them, examining the efficiency of hospitals and institutional care in Australia. The recommendations made were so critical of the present organisational structure of the Capital Territory Health Commission that the Government believes it would have been most irresponsible if it had not acted on the recommendations as it is now doing. It has been stated that the commissioners were sacked. The law making process of the Australian Capital Territory is provided by the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 which lays down that once an ordinance is published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette its effect is immediate. The moment this ordinance was published there were no offices to which the part time commissioners could continue to say they held. Therefore they could not continue to hold their old positions pending this debate in the Senate and determination of this matter tonight. The Government's goal is the fundamental one that all Australians should have proper access to high quality health care services. It is in the pursuit of high quality health care services and efficiently managed institutions that we have introduced these changes. We believe, in the light of the Jamison criticisms that the changes will lead to a more efficient operation of services and that means, for the consumers of health care-for you and me-that when we need health care if we go to the Australian Capital Territory we can expect to receive it more efficiently than we could if the old system were allowed to continue. The goal will be achieved only through good management of our health system.

The Jamison Committee of Inquiry showed that the Capital Territory Health Commission needed to be restructured in order to achieve maximum organisational efficiency. A few moments ago I referred to Mr Jamison's suggestion that there should be two levels of operation. To alleviate the problems outlined, the inquiry recommended the establishment of an area health board to take responsibility for the day to day management of the health services in the Australian Capital Territory. This is a model which has been developed for larger health services where several area health boards are responsible to a central health authority. Of course in the Australian Capital Territory there will only be the one area health board responsible to the central authority. Such a complex arrangement that might operate in New South Wales is probably too complex for the relatively small, compact Australian Capital Territory health service. So it has been decided that community and professional interests will continue to have input into decision making through the creation of a six to 10 member health services council-I think this will be of interest particularly in the light of the points made by Senator Chipp earlier as we do not wish to lose the voice of the community-whose task will be to advise the Minister for Health and the Capital Territory Health Commission on matters relating to the Territory's health services. I will turn for a few moments to the question of staff and union representation-this matter has been raised as well-on the governing boards. The Jamison commission of inquiry reported as follows:

The Commission does not encourage worker representation on boards of management and health commissions. The unique arrangement of the Capital Territory Health Commission with its system of elected and appointed members is seen to be antagonistic to effective policy making and resource allocation--
I repeat: 'Is seen to be antagonistic to effective policy making and resource allocation'. The report continues:
So changes to that structure are seen to be necessary.

Whilst the Government has accepted that a change is necessary, provision has been included in this Ordinance for management and unions to liaise by means of a staff council. The council will comprise five members appointed to represent Commission management and five members appointed by the union liaison committee. Staff consultation formalised through the staff council will still be a requirement of the Health Commission Ordinance and should therefore alleviate any concern by staff organisations.

It is nonsense for those people who oppose the changes to the Health Commission to talk about the removal of the voice of the community. Until they see who is appointed to the new positions created by this Ordinance that argument is hypothetical only. It will be the calibre of the people ultimately appointed to the positions that really matters. It will be the quality of management which flows to the people of the Australian Capital Territory-the benefits that flow to the consumers-which, in the end, is the overriding consideration. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) proposes publicly to invite expressions of interest from individuals seeking appointment to the health services council and from organisations wishing to nominate an individual for appointment to the council. The Minister also proposes advertising the two vacant commissioner positions widely in order to attract the best possible applicants. It is our concern to get the widest possible group of applicants from whom we can choose those best able to deliver efficiently the level of management which is required.

The key issue in this matter, as focussed on by the Jamison Committee of Inquiry, is the management efficiency of the structure. It is no good having a structure which looks good on paper if it cannot deliver the best service. It is, in the end, a value judgment which honourable senators have to make between the benefits on either hand as to which of these matters they think is more important. If this matter were of such concern to the House of Assembly, it really is surprising that the first meeting held by the Assembly to discuss this report was on 2 March 1981, almost two months after the report was released. The House of Assembly stated:

. . . the principal argument for the retention of elected representatives on the Hospital Board was the fundamental right of ACT citizens to have a voice in policies affecting the provision of health services in the Territory.

This statement has absolutely no substance as all members to be appointed to the health services council will be residents of the Australian Capital Territory. They will be providing a voice. They will be both experienced and knowledgeable in providing input to the health services council.

The structures proposed in the amending ordinance is designed to overcome the problems which have been outlined. It is recognised that the effectiveness of the new organisation of the Commission depends entirely upon the quality of the persons who are appointed to the remaining full time positions on the Commission and on the health services council. The advice provided on these issues will bring forward a group of people who will make the best possible decisions on health administration in the Australian Capital Territory as these people will be in the forefront of their professions. They will have in the forefront of their thinking and actions the overall efficiency of the Commission as an agency of government with defined objectives and, of course, they will have in the forefront of their attention the interests of the Australian Capital Territory community in general.

The history of the Commission has suggested that the representatives of the House of Assembly and of staff have largely represented sectional interests rather than the total community. Faced with some of the difficult decisions, they have found this to be a task which they have not been able to discharge easily. The staff representative representing about 3,500 people had a disproportionate say in the Commission's policy. Effective machinery will continue to be available to staff to have an input to policy making-for example, the staff council established under the Ordinance and about which I have spoken already. The establishment of the health services council which the Minister foreshadowed will allow for effective and broad representation of community views and this will influence the Commission and the Government in the determination of health policy in the Australian Capital Territory.

Certain honourable senators have raised the question of why the changes were made by ordinance. It has been suggested that the Government had attempted to smuggle the change through the Parliament in the form of an ordinance, not subject to debate in the same way as an Act would be. Some of my colleagues have referred to this at some length and in this respect I appreciate the contribution made by Senator Harradine. I think other honourable senators have already drawn attention to this matter. Honourable senators will know that there has been a lot of consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of the proper way in which some of these laws and rules should be made in the Australian Capital Territory. Without going through the matter in detail, I will just remind the Senate that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) advised in a recent letter that amongst the criteria suggested by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs there was this criterion:
Legislation which, in Australian States, would usually be made by Act of a State Parliament, should normally be made by ordinance.

We believe we have followed that course of action in this matter. I do not believe any issue of national importance or of a kind in which uniformity with the States is desirable has come up in relation to this Ordinance. No matter has come up which would justify the enactment of an Act of Parliament.

As I said when I began, the real issue is whether resolution of this problem will give to the people of the Australian Capital Territory the most efficient operation of their hospitals and health services. I appreciate that honourable senators who have taken part in this debate have expressed views which differ. But they differ in terms of the weight which people give to different questions of value. I ask all honourable senators to accept the fact that each honourable senator who contributed to the debate is trying in his or her way to contribute to providing the best outcome for the Australian Capital Territory. The Government seeks to have the Ordinance stand. We will oppose the motion for disallowance.

Before I conclude my remarks, Mr President, I add my voice to those who congratulated Senator Reid on a most splendid and notable maiden speech which she made today. I invite the Senate to reject the motion which has been moved.
Question put:
That the motion be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 June, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Reid on her maiden speech. I dare say we will hear more from her in the future. We are discussing the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1981. I refer to Senator Scott's contribution to the debate last night. Senator Scott certainly made an appeal for what he considered to be sanity in industrial relations. I think he was sincere and honest in trying to get some type of amiable relations. He referred to the necessity for the Government to consider references that were made to amalgamation. I remind Senator Scott that the Bill to prevent amalgamation of the unions came from the Australian Democratic Labor Party back in the 1960s. Fortunately, the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, which was formed by the Amalgamated Engineering Union, the Sheetmetal Workers Union, the Boilermakers and Blacksmiths Society of Australia and the Shipwrights Union, came into being before that Liberal-DLP inspired legislation went through to prevent the amalgamation of trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Whitlam regime, a Bill to amend the Act came before the Senate six times. The Act was to facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions. The employers' federation, the Chamber of Manufactures and the unions were in favour of it. Indeed, practically every senator on the other side of the chamber who spoke on this subject had very little criticism of amalgamation. Nevertheless, the pattern was set by a splinter party-not a middle of the road vote as some people seem to imagine there is when there is a third party in the chamber. It is not a choice between right and wrong and someone finding a balance. There are probably six rights and six wrongs and one choice. The DLP set the pattern and the Liberals have been stuck with it ever since. Senator Scott also said that we had the opportunity to try to solve industrial relations while we were in office. I cannot quite follow what he meant. I do not know how one solves industrial relations, but one certainly tries to make them as amiable as possible. I refer to the second reading speech by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). He stated:
