They are policies which encourage the democratic control of industrial organisations by their members and strengthen the rights of individual unionists against the central authority of officials.

I do not know what the thought behind that statement is. I will refer to it at a later point. There are one or two significant comments I wish to make on it, but not at the moment. The Minister further stated:

Section 45 allows the Commission to order a secret ballot of members where it thinks that the prevention or settlement of a dispute might be encouraged or assisted by finding out the views or attitudes of the members.

That shows the lack of understanding of what really goes on in a union. Just imagine if one were a union official and the union was on strike and one was quite well aware that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission intended to find out the attitudes of the union. The union is on strike for a particular sum of money which, unfortunately, seems to be the basis of most strikes. We should be striking more for conditions as well as for money. But if one is claiming, say, a $50 increase, the strike has been on for a few weeks and a secret ballot had been ordered, one would say: 'Look, the position is this: The Commission will look at the results and determine its attitude towards you people being on strike'. If there is a 100 per cent vote in favour of the strike, one gets a better chance of getting one's claim. This Bill has just not been well thought out at all. This matter really worries me. The Minister stated:
. . . the general public will be alerted to the true situation and may bring legitimate pressure to bear upon the organisation concerned to cease the industrial action.

Let us suppose that the result of that does not suit what the Minister obviously had in mind. Will the Government then seek public support for what could be considered to be a legitimate cause? Allowances must be made both ways. The Minister obviously has not done so. There is a lack of understanding about what happens with the so-called secret ballots.

I refer honourable senators to the meat industry dispute of 1970-71. The strike had been going for about three weeks when on Wednesday, 2 December, a secret ballot was conducted of members of the union employed at Midland, Robb Jetty and Anchorage Butchers Abattoirs in Perth under a recommendation of industrial commissioner Cort. The employers' representatives had rejected support for the proposal but, despite that, the Trades and Labour Council decided that if the Industrial Commission were to conduct a secret ballot the members should be encouraged to record their votes. The voting figures show that 456 voted against a resumption of work and 100 for a resumption of work. The estimates of the organisers at the time was that support for the strike was waning and that only about 60 per cent of the workers wanted it to continue. When the secret ballot took place the situation was completely different.

I refer now to a strike which lasted about six weeks in connection with the Alcoa organisation in 1980. It involved the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemens Association, the Australian Society of Engineers, the Electrical Trades Union and the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. Great pressure was exerted by the media. Threats were made about fines. After that long period the organisers reported that it looked as though the blokes were getting near the end of the strike. A secret ballot was held and 135 people voted in favour of continuing the strike and seven against. One could assume that the arguments from a trade unionist would be to stick to secret ballots, but that is not the point. The objection to secret ballots is that they are an unnecessary and unwarranted interference with internal affairs of unions.

While on the subject of strikes, let me mention a strike which received very little publicity. As I said earlier, strikes usually occur because more money or better conditions are being sought. Unfortunately, there are not as many for better working conditions and more money seems to be the main reason for strike action. The strike I refer to is a classic illustration of the tension in Australian energy politics. British Petroleum, backed by Esso Australia Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, literally burned $138,000 a month to prove a point to the men in Canberra. Over three months BP burned some $400,000 worth of liquefied petroleum gas rather than sell it to the gas and fuel corporations at what it regarded as a low price. The strategy of burning a product rather than selling it must rank as the most dramatic lobbying exercise carried out by big public companies for many years. At the same time it was a most successful strike. It was an act of vandalism. I never heard anyone on the other side of the chamber complain about that strike. Is there any legislation for secret ballots to be conducted among the proprietors of BHP before they go on strike? The would consider a secret ballot to be a completely unwarranted interference.

I return to the Minister's statement which I mentioned earlier about unionists being against the central authority of officials. Herein lies the thinking of the Government. I do not believe that it is sincere in what it is doing. I believe the bucking and questioning of authority in regard to strikes annoys the Government. I do not believe that the Government is genuinely concerned about the economy of the country. If it were it would take a look at the industrial accident rates in this country. A few weeks ago I asked a question of the responsible Minister after Sir Charles Court had suggested that the Premiers get together to analyse the effect on the economy of the 35-hour week campaign and strikes. I asked the Minister whether he would be prepared to take on board the effect on the economy of industrial accidents. About 33 1/3 more time is lost in industrial accidents than in industrial disputes.

The figures concerning industrial accidents in Australia are disgraceful. I doubt whether there is another country which claims to be a developed country which cannot collate its figures concerning industrial accidents and diseases. I look firstly at New South Wales where figures are compiled for time lost in excess of three days through industrial diseases and accidents. The figures apply only to compensation cases. In 1977-78 no individual statistics were taken for industrial accidents or diseases, but the State managed to calculate that the total number of weeks lost was 434,890. The latest figures for Victoria, which collates information on any time lost after seven days, relate to 1974-75. Some 159,863 weeks were lost in industrial accidents and some 13,072 weeks were lost through industrial diseases. A total of 172,935 weeks were lost. The list goes on. Queensland compiles statistics a bit more effectively than Victoria. Its calculations are based on time lost on anything over one day. The total comes to 195,341 weeks lost in industrial accidents and diseases. In South Australia in 1978-79 some 74,778 weeks were lost in industrial accidents, and some 4,083 weeks were lost due to industrial diseases. The figures do not include non-recurring accidents. No one seems to try to collate the figures for the cases which do not involve compensation. No one seems to care about them. These accidents and diseases have a far greater effect on the economy than strikes. Of course, it is not romantic to attack that aspect. It seems to be a lot more appropriate to attack anyone who questions authority, and that seems to be the case. If the Government were genuinely interested in the effect of such things on the economy it would be pulling its act together in relation to industrial accidents.

Let me turn to Western Australia. Some figures given at a conference in February of this year show that there were 89 industrial accidents per 1,000 workers. In the United Kingdom there were 44 industrial accidents per 1,000 workers and in the United States of America there were 22 industrial accidents per 1,000 workers. The figure for Japan was 8 industrial accidents for every 1,000 workers. Western Australia has twice as many industrial accidents as the United Kingdom. We have five times as many as the United States of America and 11 times as many as Japan. The emphasis seems to be on strikes and how the Government thinks it will be able to control them.

How interested is this Government in safety? The razor gang brought down some recommendations concerning industrial safety. It stated that the functions of the Department of Science and Technology which are concerned with the industrial physical working environment are being scaled down. The following bodies are being abolished: The National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health; the National Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Government Employment; and the Employee Participation Steering Committee. So the list goes on.

The only code of conduct that the Commonwealth seems to have on health is that which applies to the mining of uranium, and I honestly believe that in that respect it chose the lowest common denominator among the States. Now it appears that the Government is unloading upon the States its responsibility towards transport, which will be a big issue in regard to uraniun mining. It also proposes to unload onto the States the matter of the disposal of uranium. No matter where one seeks it, whether from the Parliamentary Library or the Bureau of Statistics, one cannot obtain a consensus as to what is actually happening or as to how bad the situation is. The figures that I have given by way of illustration apply to compensation cases only, yet the Government is concerned about the effect on the economy of lost time and proposes to resolve all this by the imposition of clumsy, awkward secret ballots.

I am not worried one way or the other about the results of secret ballots because government supporters do not seem able to appreciate that, as far as the AMWSU is concerned, you just do not go on to the job and tell the blokes to go out on strike. You report on the situation and the men will tell you if they will be going out on strike. When they feel that they have had enough they will tell you when they are going back to work. You may advise them but, in no circumstances, dare you tell them that you are pulling on a strike. In my own union especially, you will be in very serious trouble if you do. I was the President of the union and I can assure honourable senators that on no occasion during my years with the union did I ever hear of an organiser instructing the blokes to go on strike. It just does not happen.

That union, according to the Government, seems to be the big bogey-man but it is not, as was implied this morning by Senator Carrick, a communist controlled union. Fewer than 1/2 per cent of its members are communist and, brother, they certainly do not control it. They represent less than 1/2 per cent of the voices on the administration committee. As president of the AMWSU and the AEU in Western Australia, I can assure honourable senators that such members have an equal say with everyone else, as unionists. I resent the implication this morning of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick), in answer to a question, that such unions as my own were communist led. That is not true. There are communists in the union and long may they stay in it because they make a marvellous contribution to it in proportion to their numbers, but they do so as unionists. I am very much opposed to the conducting of secret ballots in the unions. I have made my reasons quite clear. They have nothing to do with the conducting of the ballot itself but rather that it is a clumsy, awkward procedure and an interference in the internal affairs of the union.

Government supporters should keep in mind that the unions do not have to be members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Continual meddling will force them outside it. If the unions want to amalgamate but cannot do so because of the stupidity of government legislation-the former Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peacock) supports my contention about the lack of understanding in industrial relations and the fact that we are heading on a collision course-I can well imagine that a collision will eventually occur when the unions try to form into industry, or larger, unions outside of the ambit of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If that happens, the Government will only have itself to thank for it.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a proposed amendment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Bill before us is notable for what it does contain and also for what it does not contain. Its basic aim is to toughen the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provisions regarding secret ballots with respect to trade unions going on strike. To many people it might sound superficially attractive to say: 'Let us take them on; let us give the rank and file a go in deciding whether or not to go on strike'. These are catchcries that are heard in the community particularly, I would imagine, in Victoria tonight, where one of the most mischievous strikes for some time has been called. I refer to the train drivers' strike, which marooned hundreds of thousands of commuters in Melbourne this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I am all for giving the rank and file a greater say, but the Australian Democrats have come to the view, as has the Labor Party, that these particular amendments to the Act do nothing to prevent wild-cat strikes or to inhibit the power of mischievous trade union leaders. In fact, as I hope to be able to demonstrate, they would go some way towards prolonging a strike or causing one in situations where a strike may well otherwise not occur. I would like to develop that theme in just a moment.

Therefore, I believe this to be a thoroughly misconceived piece of legislation. So that the Opposition to it might not just be seen as coming from political parties such as the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, let me say that, as I understand it, it is opposed by virtually every organisation that is involved in industrial relations. I challenge the Minister for Social Security (Mr Chaney), in responding, to name one responsible employer group which supports this particular legislation regarding the holding of secret ballots. I ask him, or the departmental advisers who are sitting next to him, to go through the whole gamut of the 346 unions-or whatever the count is-that we have in Australia and to pick out the most tame-cat, right wing union of all and name one which has said to the Department: 'Yes, we would favour this legislation'. I think that is a fair challenge to the Minister, who normally is excellent in responding to second reading debates. He has his advisers sitting next to him, and should therefore be able to pick up that challenge. I merely want the name of an employer group which has said to the Government: 'Yes, go ahead with this legislation; we want it'. Or the Minister need name only one trade union, no matter how right wing or tame-cat it is, which has made such a statement. I would be grateful to the Minister if he could provide that information.

It is hard to believe that the Government could introduce such ill-considered legislation in the wake of the resignation of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peacock. The Government's industrial relations reputation must surely now be at an all time low. This legislation, if it does nothing else, confirms the impression that the Government will do almost anything to foster confrontation between unions and employers. The only people whom this legislation will satisfy will be the Government's own hardliners. One of the reasons I advance for that charge is that the Government should have put into this legislation an amendment to make amalgamations of trade unions easier. That was an election promise. It had agreement from employers, from employees, from trade unions and from the community generally. But that provision is conspicuous by its absence.

TALK.START.PARA: —They backed off a fortnight ago from the original legislation.

—I thank Senator Gietzelt for that interjection. The Government backed off from the original legislation some weeks ago. I ask Senator Chaney to get another answer from his departmental officers. Is it a fact that the legislation to facilitate the amalgamation of unions has already been drafted? Was the legislation in existence and was it scrapped?
—You would like it confirmed.

—I would like to hear from the Minister whether the legislation to facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions was in existence. I would like to know from the Minister the reason it was not introduced. I do not believe he can supply the answer, although that is no reflection on him. I would like to speak briefly about the history of the legislation to facilitate union amalgamations, which is something that has been long called for to overcome the strife caused by the existence of too many unions. This matter is totally ignored by the present legislation.
—The figure is 316.

—I thank Senator McIntosh. I was slightly out in my figures. In Australia today there are 316 trade unions. Even worse, there are about 1,500 organised employer organisations which deal directly with organised labour. We wonder why we have strikes in this country, yet we have such an incredible number of trade unions dealing with and being dealt with by such an amazing number of employer organisations. We have chaos. Surely if anything is screaming out to be done, it is for there to be fewer trade unions. The Government had an opportunity to do that but for some reason did not do it. There is another reason, which other speakers have referred to, why there should be fewer trade unions. I refer to demarcation disputes. I ask one of my colleagues in the Labor Party to correct me if I am wrong. I am told that about 20 per cent of all time lost through strikes is caused not by bloody-minded unions or by employer lockouts but simply by demarcation dispute wars between different unions on the same job.
—There has never been a demarcation dispute in the AMWSU since it amalgamated.

—I thank Senator McIntosh for that interjection. Might I relate, by way of comic relief, the circumstances of a demarcation dispute that occurred when I was Minister for the Navy in 1966-67. The Australian fleet was about to engage in an exercise in the Pacific with the American fleet, the French fleet and the British fleet. It was a massive exercise. I think it was a South East Asia Treaty Organisation exercise, but that does not matter. It involved a naval exercise. Three of our ships were in Garden Island dockyard. They were undergoing the final touches of a refit before joining the naval exercise in which Australia was to play a significant part. One morning the Secretary of my Department came into my office and said: 'Minister, the whole of Garden Island dockyard has walked out-gone off the job-with three days to go before the exercise'. I said to him 'What is the cause of the dispute?' and he said: 'A toilet seat'. I was not amused by the rejoinder because it was not a time for a Minister who had to tell the Cabinet that he could not get the Navy's ships out for an exercise to be amused. But the Secretary's remark was absolutely right.

SPEECH.PARA: The dispute was caused by a member of a trade union-I believe he was a member of the carpenters' union-who had repaired a lavatory seat made of plastic. The demarcation rules said that lavatory seats made of plastic must be repaired by a member of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. For that reason the whole of the dockyard went off the job for about two days, if I remember correctly. I digressed to tell that story to show the stupidity that is being impacted upon our industrial scene by demarcation disputes which are essentially caused by too many trade unions. Yet the Government walks away from the situation.

I am admonished constantly by Churchill's warning to beware of the false analogy. I know that to compare industrial relations in Australia with industrial relations in West Germany could well lead to a false analogy for several reasons. Again I would be indebted to my colleagues in the Labor Party if they were to correct me if I am wrong. Whilst Australia has about 316 trade unions, West Germany has fewer than 20 for a population considerably in excess of Australia's population. Again I ask the Minister: Why was this earlier legislation not brought down? Who got to the Government and said: 'Do not bring it in'? It is a blatant breaking of an election promise. On 18 September 1980 the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Tony Street, announced his intention to introduce union amalgamation legislation. His words ring rather hollow now. I quote him:

The new amalgamation provisions are yet another demonstration of how the Government is meeting its responsibility to provide an industrial relations framework which takes account of the views of the parties and meets their needs, while paying due regard to the public interest.
During that speech he also said:
I might also add that this achievement shows that Government, employers and unions can work together and produce tangible results for the benefit of each other and the community.

In September 1980 the then Minister said, on this question of amalgamation of unions, that agreement had been reached between government, employers and employees.Yet this Bill does not include any such provisions. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his policy speech of 30 September last year, said:
For the future, the Government proposes to legislate to facilitate the amalgamation of unions where there is a 'community of interest'.

That commitment was repeated by the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peacock, on 18 November. The Government has thrown out of the window three years of co-operative work by the National Labour Consultative Council, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Council of Australian Government Employee Organisations and the Government. The NLCC arrived at a unanimous decision that legislation should be introduced to facilitate amalgamation and the Government has totally disregarded that advice. I ask: Why? The Australian Democrats condemn the Government for that notable omission. Instead of that amalgamation proposal, which all concerned unanimously agreed should be included, the Government has included in the legislation a provocative, useless and counterproductive proposal to tighten up the legislation in regard to secret ballots and strikes.

I will not go through the mechanisms in the amendments to section 45 of this Act which Senator Button did splendidly last night. Suffice it to say that they will complicate an already existing complicated procedure. It has been indicated that if employees are forced by some device to vote by secret ballot on whether to strike that could prolong a strike or cause a strike which would otherwise have been prevented by negotiation between the parties. It could tie the hands of trade union leaders into settling a dispute when the result of a poll might be announced which shows the rank and file to be in favour of continuing a strike or commencing a strike.

What would happen if a trade union threatens to strike or an industrial dispute arises concerning a trade union's wish to have, say, a $25 a week increase in wages? The trade union might not really want a $25 a week increase. It might not believe that an increase of $25 a week is reasonable. Let us assume that its bottom line figure is, say, $15. Let us assume further that management comes in and offers $10. Let us assume also that this device of voting on a strike by secret ballot is implemented and the union is forced to have a secret ballot on the matter. The question before the unionists voting on that strike is: 'Do you want to go out on strike for $25 a week more? I ask honourable senators: What red-blooded trade unionist would not vote 'yes' to that question? If during those negotiations management offers $17 a week more to the trade union-which is $2 a week above what the trade union really wanted in the first place-but the trade union members have voted 'yes' by secret ballot for $25 and have decided to stay out on strike until they get it, we have reached a situation of absolute absurdity.

The people who suffer most while chaos and dislocation occur are the trade unionists, industry and commerce whereas the strike could well have been settled amicably and sensibly by negotiation a long time before. Why has this legislation been brought in? I ask the Minister to request his departmental advisers to say which employer group asked for this legislation on secret ballots? Did any trade union ask for this legislation? The second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) states:
. . . frequent requests from members of organisations-and from the public-

Is that true? Was the Minister, Mr Viner, telling the truth? If he says that in his second reading speech I, as a senator, am entitled to know: What members of organisations? What organisations? What members of the public? How many asked for this tightening up of secret ballots?

I come to a matter even more serious. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will have to guide me as to whether I transgress Standing Orders. I ask the Senate and people listening to the broadcast of these proceedings: Did the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Viner, tell a lie when he introduced this Bill? Talking about the secret ballot provisions of the Bill, he said:
Following consultations with the major employer and union councils in the National Labour Consultative Council, the Government is now in a position to proceed with the proposal.

That proposal was for secret ballots. I remember the definition of the truth and what is a lie under British justice. When someone is asked to give evidence in a court, they are not asked just to swear that they will tell the truth. They are asked to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. I wonder whether Mr Viner's statement satisfies all three components of that definition. I repeat that he said:
Following consultations with the major employer and union councils in the National Labour Consultative Council, the Government is now in a position to proceed with the proposal.
It could well be argued by an expert in semantics or casuistry that he did not say that the major employer and union councils gave approval. He said:
Following consultations . . . the Government is now in a position to proceed with the proposal.

I would have thought that the 99 people who understand the basic English language and who read that passage would understand that the Minister had consulted with major employers and unions and that, after consulting with them, they had given him the go-ahead to produce this legislation on secret ballots. When the Minister responds, I ask him to argue that point with me-that a responsible person would not form that conclusion.

At the risk of breaching Standing Orders, I say that that is palpably and provably untrue. No major employer organisation, and no major trade union council-and certainly not the National Labour Consultative Council-gave approval for this amendment to the Act. Is an omission to say something pertinent to a statement a lie? What the Minister omitted to say was that this proposal had been totally opposed by the unions and the employers who, believing the legislation to be unworkable, had expressed considerable reservations. He did not have to say, because the amalgamations provisions were shelved, that those provisions had bipartisan support from the unions, the employers and, before his ministerial demise, Mr Peacock.

I will conclude by reading from a newspaper which can hardly be described as rampant left wing. It can hardly be described as a champion of the labour movement, the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Democrats. In fact, it could well be described as one of the great champions of the Liberal Party in this country. I am referring to the newspaper, the Australian. Its editorial of 18 May, speaking about this legislation, stated:

The Federal Government's latest package of industrial relations legislation introduced into Parliament late last week may help to placate its restive backbench but will do nothing to enhance its already dubious credibility in this highly sensitive area.

The legislation, to toughen Conciliation and Arbitration Act provisions on secret ballots, was part of a two-pronged industrial relations initiative in the Government's policy for the 1980 Federal election. The other prong aimed to ease union amalgamations-seen as a step toward industry unions, something long called for to overcome strife caused by too many unions.

But, in the wake of an upsurge of industrial unrest, particularly the Qantas and air hostesses strikes, and the resignation of the Industrial Relations Minister, Mr Peacock, the government hard-liners flexed their muscles. They did not like either piece of legislation much: the secret ballot legislation was not tough enough-they wanted the ballots to be compulsory-and they feared easier amalgamations would lead to more powerful militant unions.
So, to avoid a backbench revolt, the Government, already on the ropes for other reasons, quietly shelved the Amalgamations Bill and tightened the secret ballot provisions.

Also, the Secret Ballots Bill will do nothing to improve relations between the Government and the Arbitration Commission. It ditches traditional appeals procedures and presumes the commission president will be prepared to overrule lightly decisions by his deputies. It also shows the Government has dismissed the possibility that a ballot could endorse a strike and give it legitimacy.
The result will be an inevitable clash with the unions and the Labor Opposition-and proof the Government's industrial relations policy is one of muddle-headed confrontation.

To someone who just tuned in, that was not the Labor Star, the Communist Weekly or even Mr Santamaria's thoughtful newspaper. That was the Australian newspaper, whose sentiments in that editorial the Australian Democrats heartily endorse and, in doing so, condemn this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this amendment to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I am disappointed with the information that Senator Chipp gave to the Senate and to the people of Australia about demarcation disputes. The information is not correct when one has regard to the details supplied by and readily available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics in respect of disputes relating to trade unionism. I will deal with that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say firstly that I am opposed to this legislation because I believe it to be window dressing. I consider that the principle of orderly industrial progress requires that members of registered industrial organisations should take their part and play their role within those organisations. The imposition from above of this type of legislation will not do any good for the industrial situation within Australia. These matters were canvassed thoroughly in the debate in the House of Representatives on Tuesday of this week as well as in the debate on this matter in this chamber last night and today. I would not grace the proposals with any respect at all because I believe that they emerged from a complete misunderstanding of the requirements for orderly industrial progress in this country. As I mentioned, that requires the positive contribution of union members to the debate within their own organisations.

The question of secret ballots for union elections is a quite different matter from the question of secret ballots in respect of strike votes. One can only consider them-I do so because I have had a great deal of experience of them as Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council-in respect of disputes which affect the building and construction industry, particularly those construction sites in outlying areas. Presumably if there is a strike ballot in respect of a proposition to go out on strike there has to be a strike ballot in respect of a proposition to come back to work. Anybody who has been involved in these disputes would know that half the labour force is gone by the time the fellows have been corralled into a meeting in order to put a proposition to them after lengthy negotiations with the employers. I am not fussed at all that the employers are not enamoured of this proposition. I take note of what comes from the employers, particularly if it comes from the bureaucrats within employer organisations. I also consider what may motivate those suggestions.

That leads me to my description of this proposition. The words 'window dressing' are apt to describe this legislation. Public relations must have prompted the secret strike ballot and, indeed, the union amalgamation proposals. In my view neither proposal has a firm or solid industrial base. Although the Government is pressing forward in its intention to push through this strike ballot proposal, it has decided to put its amalgamations proposal in cold storage. Let me put to rest some of the comments that have become accepted wisdom in respect of the amalgamations proposal. One of them is that it will do away with the problem of demarcation issues. Let us not forget that the original push for easier amalgamations came from the Communist Party. I quote from the directive to Marxist operators within the trade union movement, contained on page 45 of the Communist Party handbook entitled 'The Trade Unions'. It states:
One of the bigger tasks in the Trade Union Movement of the country is that of the establishment of industrial unions.

Then, of course, came the entry of the giant United States corporations into Australia. They are used to dealing with the United States industry unions but are completely oblivious of the historical basis for Australian trade unions and completely oblivious of the Australian arbitration system. These organisations are not interested in the long term industrial future of Australia. Then we had the academics who suggested that amalgamations would fix up the demarcation disputes within Australia. Senator Chipp mentioned that demarcation disputes represented 20 per cent of all union disputes in Australia. I shall quote Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. Trade unionism is a classification which is used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to describe disputes relating to demarcation matters, intra-union and inter-union demarcation disputes. It refers also to union membership disputes and sympathy strikes. In 1977 these represented 4.8 per cent of the total number of workers involved, directly or indirectly, in disputes in Australia. In 1978 they represented 3.7 per cent of all workers involved in disputes in Australia. By 1979 they represented 1.9 per cent of all workers involved in disputes in Australia. The figure of 1.9 per cent is nowhere near 20 per cent. I do not know where Senator Chipp got the figure of 20 per cent from. This is the type of misinformation that is encouraging the drive for mergers and for monopoly control in the trade union movement. I oppose monopoly control within the trade union movement as much as I oppose monopoly control in industry. For example, I oppose monopoly control in the banking industry. I oppose the push for easier mergers within the banking industry.

What was the proposal? The proposal was to reduce to 25 per cent the current requirement of 50 per cent of the membership to vote on the issue of amalgamation, meaning that only half of that number, namely, 12 1/2 per cent of a union, would need to vote in favour of amalgamation. That is contrary to the principles enshrined in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act for rank and file control of the organisation. Not only that, but also the electorate which was proposed was not to consist of all of the union members, but only the financial members. I can understand that only financial members ought to receive the privilege of voting in a union election, but if I have an equity interest in a particular union and if for one reason or another I happen to be unfinancial, that should not deny me the right to express my opinion as to whether that organisation, to which I owe certain arrears in dues, should exist. I should certainly have a right to say whether I pay my dues to that union or to some other union to which my union has been amalgamated without my consent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were a year behind in your dues you would not give them a vote, would you?
—I have never been--
—No, but the people you are talking about would.

—I understand your point. This legislation proposes to reduce the electorate from membership of a union to financial membership of that union. I agree, because it is in the rules of the union to which I belong, that only financial members should be able to vote for elected officials in a secret ballot, but unfinancial members have an equity interest in the organisation. They have an obligation to pay their arrears under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to--

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. A number of speakers have canvassed not what is in the Bill but what is not in the Bill. There may be some excuse for that in light of the fact that the second reading speech mentions what is omitted from the Bill, but we seem mainly to be debating subjects which are not before the Senate. There is no mention of union amalgamations in the legislation which is before the Senate.
—You can please yourself. I have finished.
—I was merely going to suggest that honourable senators direct their remarks to the Bill.

—I call Senator Harradine. Considerable latitude has been given throughout the debate. I suggest to the Minister that it is a little too late now to raise a point of order. Does Senator Harradine wish to say anything further?
—No, I have finished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry if I stopped Senator Harradine in the middle of his last sentence but in light of the hour and the purpose of the legislation I thought we should try to confine the debate to the major matters which are before us. Senator Harradine and a number of other speakers, including Senator Button and Senator Chipp, have made much of the failure to bring forward legislation on amalgamation. Indeed, it is perhaps my fault in that I did not take a point of order at a much earlier point in the debate. There is no secret about this matter. The second reading speech which is before all honourable senators and which was laid down in this place last night, and of course, in the House of Representatives some weeks ago, specifically refers to the Government's continuing commitment to the introduction of legislation with respect to amalgamation. I refer honourable senators to that speech and to the reasons which have been given for the Government not proceeding with such legislation at this stage. In my second reading speech I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government parties wish to consider the full implications of such a criteria for amalgamation and its relevance to meeting the objective of encouraging the formation of industry based unions before proceeding further with any such amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is canvassing a matter which is not covered in the Bill. I had a number of remarks to make about the matters that were dealt with in the Bill. The Minister raised the point of order and sat me down. Although I had a number of matters to mention in relation to the Bill, I decided to sit down. The Minister is engaging in hypocrisy if, after trying to sit me down, he is now going on to deal with the question of community interest, with which I was going to deal, and with other matters with which I was also going to deal.
—Senator Harradine, you were at liberty to continue with your speech after the point of order had been decided, so I do not see that there is a point of order before the Senate.
—In view of the Minister's untimely intervention, I decided not to continue.

—I am sorry that Senator Harradine appears to be piqued by the fact that I drew attention to the fact that this matter was not covered in the Bill. As you say, Mr Acting Deputy President, it was in his hands to decide whether to continue his speech. In any event, I simply refer honourable senators to the passages in the second reading speech which are consistent with the views which were transmitted to the parties to the discussions which are being held on this legislation. The Minister wrote to Mr Polites on behalf of the Confederation of Australian Industry. He wrote to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and to the Council of Australian Government Employee Organisations in similar terms, indicating that the Government had decided to defer the introduction of the amalgamation proposals which had been the subject of consultation at the meeting of the National Labour Consultative Council held on 9 February 1981, and indicating again that the Government parties were anxious to consider the full implications of the community of interest criteria for amalgamation and its relevance to meeting the objective of encouraging the formation of industry based unions. I say no more than that the sorts of concerns which were being advanced by Senator Harradine reflect in many ways some of the concerns which are felt about union amalgamation and which have required the matter to receive further consideration. There is no secret about the Government's stance on that matter. It was made clear in the second reading speech. It has been made clear to the parties which are involved in the National Labour Consultative Council. Therefore, I do not think that any further debate is required on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is directed to widening the availability of secret ballots which are to be made available at the instance of members of organisations which may be affected by industrial action. Again, the second reading speech makes it quite clear that there is to be merely an extension of the provisions which already exist to have a secret ballot of members where this might be relevant to the prevention or settlement of a dispute. The Bill builds on the present provision in the Act, which has been contained in the Act, in one form or another, since the 1920s. It will enable a prescribed minimum number of employees at a particular place of work who are members of an organisation which has called for industrial action to apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a secret ballot. That matter seems to have caused considerable concern among some members of the Opposition, who seem to think that the fact that employees might have an opportunity to make their views known about the rightness or wrongness of industrial action will be in some way destructive. In fact, again, the benefits of the legislation and the view of the Government have been made quite explicit in the second reading speech. The benefits will be to give employees at a particular place of work the right, under the protection of the law, to determine for themselves whether or not to participate in industrial action. Why the extension of that right should be seen in destructive terms would, I think, be a mystery not only to Government senators but also to the members of the public who are concerned about strike action on so many occasions.

Senator Chipp mentioned in his speech the present industrial action in Victoria and in my State of Western Australia. At the moment, industrial action is causing very great inconvenience to most of the citizens of Perth. The passage of this legislation will ensure that individual unionists at a work place will have the right to make their views known to the Commission and to seek a secret ballot. Again, that is a matter for which I thought there would have been general public support.

A number of other matters have been raised. For example, great concern has been expressed about the fact that these are time consuming procedures which will be difficult for people to operate. I think that matter has been adequately dealt with in the debate elsewhere. In particular, I commend to the attention of honourable senators the speech made in the other place by Mr John Spender Q.C. on the operations of the legislation and the choices that are available to workers and the Commission if they seek to avail themselves of this legislation. Members will be able to apply for a ballot as soon as a direction has been given or a request made by the organisation to engage in industrial action. The industrial action need not to have commenced. This will be particularly relevant in relation to prospective or continuing industrial action such as that undertaken, for example, in relation to the 35-hour working week.

The fact that an application is made does not mean that in every case a secret ballot must be held. That is a matter in relation to which, first of all, we have a conditions precedent as to the number of persons who might apply and then certain discretion is vested in the Commission as to whether a ballot is to be taken. There seems to be an extraordinary desire on the part of those honourable senators opposite who have had trade union experience to ensure that rank and file members do not have this opportunity. I think that is a matter which those people who listened to this debate might well have noted.
My attention was drawn, during the course of the debate, to something that was said as long ago as 1927 by Latham when he dealt with similar legislation in the Parliament. He said:
These provisions are in pursuance of a definite undertaking given by the Prime Minister in his policy speech at the last general election.
That situation is true here also. He continues:
They constitute a faithful performance of that promise.

That is true also. On the one hand, we are being damned for not introducing legislation, for wanting to consider further some of the legislation that was referred to in the policy speech last year and at the same time damned for meeting another promise which was made at the same time last year. Latham went on to state:
They-
Trade unionists-

are entitled to have the control of their organisations restored to them and if they do not wish to control their own affairs they need not use these provisions. The opportunity for self-government is given to them, the rest remains with themselves.

These are provisions which will be used only if trade unionists wish to use them. That is a matter which all the talk of honourable senators in this place who have had some trade union experience should not be allowed to cloud. Why is it that they are so concerned to deny the right, to trade unionists at the work place to seek a secret ballot of their fellows? Why is it that that is something from which they resile so strongly? I suggest that the very vehemence of their arguements will be seen by many people in Australia as a reason for proceeding with this legislation.

Again, concern was expressed on the part of Senator Button, who led for the Opposition, about the wide definition of industrial action. It appears to me that that simply ensures that the application for a ballot will not be restricted by some restrictive approach to what sort of disputes ought be subject to ballot and to the opinions of members. The definition is intended to cover all forms of industrial action. There is no implication, as was sought to be drawn by Senator Button, that those forms of industrial action are undertaken as a matter of practice without support of the membership. However, the fact remains that the legislation will give the opportunity to union members to reassess their attitudes to engage in industrial action if they wish to avail themselves of the opportunity. That simply means that there is a wide right vested in the members of organisations. On that basis, it does not seem to be a matter on which there can be any objection to the legislation.

Senator Button and Senator Chipp were exercised about the employer view of this legislation. Senator Chipp, in particular, issued various invitations to me to comment on that aspect of the legislation. There is no basis for the assertion that employers were opposed to the legislation on secret ballots. At the National Labour Consultative Council meeting on 9 February 1981, when the Government's proposals were specifically considered, the spokesman for the Confederation of Australian Industry said that it had no objection to the proposed legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the spokesman?
—Two representatives were there. I think Mr Polites was one of them but the indication I have is that there was no objection to the legislation.
—Are you saying that George Polites said that?

—I said that there was no objection to the legislation. Those are the words that I used. Again I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that there is very widespread public support for the proposition that secret ballot should be compulsory for union members when they vote on whether to go on strike. Eighty-one per cent of the people asked said that secret ballots should be compulsory for union members when they vote on whether to go on strike. This figure compares with 78 per cent of people who held that view in March 1976. Seventy-five per cent of Australian Labor Party voters said that the secret strike ballot should be compulsory. Of course, this Bill does not go so far. It simply opens up the possibility of secret ballots being held. I repeat: Why is it that the Opposition is so terrified of people at the work place getting the opportunity to vote on a strike matter?

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to two other matters. Senator Button made much of the competence of the previous government in industrial relations as against the incompetence of the present Government. He was concerned about the inability of the present Government to deal with the labour problems of this country. I sought figures regarding the number of working days lost over recent years. These statistics will be as well known to Senator Button--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister should at least be relevant in his reply. I did not mention the previous government. If the Minister wants to reel out these Liberal Party figures about industrial disputes, by all means he can do so but he should put them in an honest context, if he does not mind.
—Order! Senator Button, the time to object to a matter such as that is at the end of the Minister's speech. There is no point of order. I call the Minister.

—I do not intend to quote Liberal Party figures. I intend to quote figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Last night in his speech Senator Button was extremely disparaging about the ability of the present Government to deal with the labour difficulties which are faced by Australia. I again wish to put before the Senate the statistics of the number of working days lost. In 1973-74, 5,426,200 working days were lost; in 1974-75, 3,957,300 working days were lost; in 1975-76, 2,517,700 working days were lost; in 1976-77, 1,573,000 working days were lost; in 1977-78, 1,912,300 working days were lost; in 1978-79, 2,729,100 working days were lost; and in 1979-80, 3,320,600 working days were lost. The fact of the matter is that if honourable senators look at those years of Labor government they will find a very much higher level of working days lost. I simply draw that to the attention of the Senate in the light of the remarks made by Senator Button yesterday about the present Government's record in industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp placed great stress on a passage in the second reading speech which read as follows:

Following consultations with the major employer and union councils in the National Labour Consultative Council, the Government is now in a position to proceed with the proposal. The Government would have presented the secret ballot proposals in the summer session last year . . .

The suggestion from Senator Chipp was that the statement that there had been consultations with the major employer and union councils amounted to an implication that the legislation had the agreement, the consent, or whatever, of major employer and union councils. The statement is no more than that there was consultation with those councils. That is a matter which is supported by the fact of a meeting of the National Labour Consultative Council and the subsequent correspondence with the NLCC. I entirely reject any suggestion that any implication is to be drawn that the trade union movement had given its assent, or approval, to this legislation. I think that is a very forced reading of what appears in the second reading speech and I do not believe that the implication drawn by Senator Chipp can be drawn. I thank Senator Scott for his support of the legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Certain offences in relation to members of organizations, &c.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The provisions of clause 3 amend section 5 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. What they do, in fact, is provide that an employee shall not be victimised-I think that is the correct expression-in his employment or discriminated against in his employment on account of that employee having proposed an application to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for an order under section 45 for the holding of a secret ballot and that an employee shall not be discriminated against by reason of the fact that he has proposed an application to the Commission for an order under section 45 or by reason of the fact that an employee has participated in, or proposes to participate in, a secret ballot ordered by the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me about the provisions of this amendment is that clause 5 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, as I understand it-perhaps I do not, but I have no doubt that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) will enlighten me if that is the case-is designed to facilitate the organisations of employers and employees for the purposes of the good workings of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. There is an implicit recognition in clause 3 of this Bill that this legislation will cause trouble between employees and employers. I think that this amendment to section 5 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is implicit recognition of that.

Section 5 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is concerned to protect an employee who takes part in industrial action from victimisation by an employer. It is concerned to ensure that an employer should not threaten or dismiss an employee or alter his position to his prejudice because the employee is a member or an official of a union. It is also concerned to protect, in certain circumstances, an employer who may be a member of an employers' organisation. The amendment contained in clause 3 carries the very clear implication to me that it is quite likely, in the view of the Government, that an application under section 45 for a secret ballot carries with it the seeds of industrial disruption in certain plants or factories. I say that it does. It effectively means that an employer may discipline a person in his employment because he has taken advantage of this legislation which the Government has provided. That is an extraordinary insertion in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It is quite a departure from the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the traditional understanding as to the meaning of clause 5, which is designed basically to protect employees in circumstances of victimisation by employers.

The first point I make is that it is an unusual departure and it carries certain implications, in my view. The second point I make is that the ramifications of applications, as they used to be made to the Industrial Court under section 5 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and as they would now be made to the Federal Court of Australia, are just enormous. Very few proceedings are taken under this section, and they are not taken lightly by people because the onus of proof is very high. It is a very difficult onus of proof to satisfy in proceedings under section 5 before the Federal Court of Australia. I ask the Minister whether he sees any lesser implications in the provisions of clause 3 of the Bill. If so, I would be pleased. Also, has the Government considered the ramifications for an employee in the circumstances of taking action against his employer because he allegedly has been victimised as a result of the implications of this legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I supplement the remarks of my leader, Senator Button, on slightly different grounds. I refer to the question of disruption. A situation arose in the Melbourne tramways union not so long ago when a girl named Barbara Briggs, for the sake of television notoriety, created pandemonium in that union, being in it for a short time and breaking all the conventions. She was not an employer's plant or anything like that. She was just a girl who had, to say the least, a very chequered career elsewhere. She was odd. For a couple of weeks there were all sorts of problems in the Melbourne and Metropolitan Tramways Board. There was no doubt that the authorities did not want her. Nobody wanted her. She is unheard of now. She was one of those people with odd delusions of grandeur. She wanted only to get television coverage for a week, and she got it. There was the situation with a man named Koch in another industry. I will not deal with him too much. Notoriety was what he wanted. Later he was involved in some domestic dispute and he is no longer on this earth, but he was an odd man.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that these strange people are in abundance. They have their moment of glory in the defiance of authority and conventions. If an employer or an industrial officer seeks out one of these people and says: 'We will have chaos for a week or a fortnight', surely he has the right to cull him out before he becomes, wittingly or unwittingly, with his exhibitionist tendencies an industrial saboteur. That is an aspect in addition to what my leader said. I would like to know about the protection of the employer and the industry.
(Quorum formed).

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the point raised by Senator Button. I think it is a very pertinent one. The implication he sees is that an employer may have some resentment towards an employee on this question. I think it is plain from clause 6 of this Bill, taking it in conjunction with section 45 of the Act, that this legislation does not have the purpose of preventing or stopping an industrial dispute. Its purpose is the protection of scabs, and that is all. This is shown in clause 6. One can do nothing about those scabs after the dispute is over. But which employer would want a scab on his books? That is the whole basis of this matter. As I have said, clause 6 is not designed to prevent industrial disputes; it is designed to permit a person to scab. If a man who has an engineering firm wants so many fitters-he already has five and they take action under this legislation and scab against a union direction-where will he get the complement of fitters he wants? Of course no employer wants a scab on his books. Only the Government wants scabs. As I said, I will have more to say about that in connection with clause 6. I think it is significant to point out in regard to clause 3-the Government realises this-that there is a resentment of employers against employees who use this section of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall deal firstly with the point raised by Senator Mulvihill, which I think stands on its own from the points made by Senator Button and Senator Cavanagh. He raised the problem of the odd case, of the person who might be seen as being within a union simply to cause difficulties and to act as an agent provocateur. He cited a couple of examples which he would put in that category. I think the answer to that lies in the clause referred to by Senator Cavanagh, clause 6. If one examines proposed sub-section (3B) in clause 6 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill one will see that a minimum number of people is required to bring an application for a ballot. It provides in (b):

SPEECH.PARA: the number of the applicants is not less than-
(i) 250 or a number equal to 5% of the number of members of the organization employed by the employer at the place of work, whichever is the lesser number; or
(ii) 4, if the lesser number referred to in sub-paragraph (i) is less than 4.

In a very small shop it would be possible to get down to the minimum of four people required to bring an application under this legislation. However, there is normally a requirement of 5 per cent or 250 as mentioned in the sub-clause. In other words, a single person who is simply trying to create difficulty would have to get the co-operation of his or her fellows to achieve the undesired result which is referred to by the honourable senator. I think, therefore, there is protection with respect to that.

It seems to me that the point raised by Senator Button and supported by Senator Cavanagh was really answered by the content and tone of the comments made by Senator Cavanagh. He made extremely disparaging comments about scabs and the attitude of unions and employers towards them. I suppose that that spirit which at times infects the industrial relations of this country and which I think is found repugnant by most Australians and certainly by me is one of the reasons for section 5 being in the Act. Protective provisions are provided in section 5 to prevent an employer dismissing an employee or injuring him in his employment because of his trade union activities. That is something that would be generally agreed as being undesirable.

Senator Cavanagh has made it quite clear to the Committee this evening that anyone who goes against what he sees as the trade union can be classified as a scab and made subject to some sort of action or another. One can imagine circumstances where a trade union may well put an employer under considerable pressure to damage an employee because he has done no more than exercise his right under this legislation to seek a ballot which will determine the view of his fellow trade unionists with respect to the dispute. If there is an extension of the sort of protection offered in section 5, it is because circumstances can be envisaged where there would be potential for victimisation. I think, therefore, that the provisions are required. Looking at the existing provisions of section 5, I doubt that there is protection in the provision as it stands. (Quorum formed). I had almost completed my comments. I was making the point that the amendments simply extend the same protection to members of organisations as are presently extended by the section but cover the new circumstances which the Bill brings into operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not satisfied with the answer. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is trying to cloud the issue. He is not correct in what he says. The very reason for section 5 at present is mostly to protect an employee because of his union activities. Nothing in section 5 protects an employee because he is scabbing. I can understand that the word 'scab' is repugnant to Senator Chaney, but it is an acceptable word in the glossary of the trade union movement. Senator Chaney said that the matter relates to clause 6. Section 45 (1) and (2) of the Act states that where the Commissioner thinks that the prevention or settlement of the dispute would or might be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views or attitude of members he can call a ballot. The Commissioner has to think that the calling of a ballot would prevent the settlement of a dispute or might encourage or assist in the acertaining of views or attitudes of members. Sub-sections (1) and (2) of section 45 relate to the Commissioner calling a secret ballot because he believes it is in the interest of settling a dispute, but clause 6 does not relate to a vote by members who are on strike. Proposed new section 45 (3A) (a) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where-the members, or members included in a section or class of the members, of an organization or of a branch of an organization are directed or requested by the organization or by the branch to engage in industrial action;
Firstly, a request must be made. Proposed new sub-section (3B) provides:
An application shall not be made under sub-section (3A) unless-
(a) all the applicants are members of the same organization employed by the same employer at the same place of work;

This matter would not relate to the question of a ballot, if one were available, in relation to the Australian Telecommunications Commission. If any benefit is to be obtained in the Commissioner's mind a ballot would be called for under sub-section (1) and (2) of section 45 of the Act. It may be that someone working at the Canberra transmitter station applies for a ballot. The people involved would have to be members of the same union. The provision relates to a small class of people who are working for the same employer at the same location. The people working in the transmission station in Canberra would have to decide whether they would go out on strike. The union may continue on strike without any direction being given to it. The fellows at the Canberra transmission station would be exempt from any action because they stayed at work. That is an outline of the provision.

The real definition of a scab is a worker refusing to use his strength in an industrial dispute to better his conditions under the direction of his union. That scab will never be accepted again. He will not be wanted by private employers. This aspect is better illustrated in metal trades disputes. There are thousands of metal trades employers throughout Australia. The proposed new sub-section defines the number of applicants as four persons or 5 per cent of the number of members of the organisation. It would be easy to get four members to make an application for a ballot in a small industry. They would want immunity and the right to continue to work. They have to be in the same organisation, work for the same employer and be at the same location. It may be that fellows at the Forwood Down company at Woodville in South Australia do not want to work but at Mile End they do. It may be that one section of employees wants to scab on the union. This provision gives protection for those scabs. It shows that such people need protection. Clause 3 is being inserted because the Government realises that the boss would not have his job when the dispute was over. A penalty is inflicted on the employer if he dares do anything to the scabs he does not want. This will possibly break him financially because of his inability to recruit other labour.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clause 5 agreed to.
Clause 6 (Secret ballot may be ordered).

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) whether he has any information, perhaps from the Industrial Relations Bureau, which will provide an estimate of numbers of industrial stoppages instigated, as it were, by a committee of management or officials of a trade union, as against the number of industrial stoppages instigated by the rank and file of a trade union-with a request for the stoppages communicated to the committee of management. It is an important question of fact in respect of which one cannot really rely on an Age public opinion poll such as might be conducted to ask whether we were in favour of something like motherhood.
—We are.
—Yes. I ask that seriously because it is tremendously important. It goes to the assumptions underlying this section entirely. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it can be shown from this clause that what I said earlier is correct. I asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) whether section 45 (1) and (2) of the principal Act permit the Commission to call a ballot to assist in preventing or settling a dispute or to encourage a settlement. That could apply to the full membership of the organisation if my interpretation is correct. Under proposed new sub-section (3A), reference is made only to a strike that the employees are directed or requested by the branch of a union to engage. The proposed new sub-section is to have no effect when there is a disagreement at the work place and, without the intervention of the union, the members themselves deciding to go on strike. The strike could be about any question. Therefore, the provision has limited application.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new sub-section (3B) provides:
An application shall not be made under sub-section (3A) unless-
(a) all the applicants are members of the same organisation employed by the same employer at the same place of work;

That illustrates the point that I made earlier. It is not a ballot to try to settle a dispute, but one which is restricted to certain employees-perhaps the fitters and turners-of one organisation, at one location, working for one employer. In the case of a big company such as General Motors-Holden's Ltd, a ballot cannot be conducted unless it is restricted to, say, the fitters and turners, who are members of the Metal Trades Union, to the members of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia or to the members of the Electrical Trades Union. It cannot be an all-in ballot. In every industrial dispute there are one or two men who do not want to strike. They may be offered a reward to slander their organisation. As a result, a vote can be taken with that situation prevailing. Many smaller manufacturing and engineering firms have few employees but it is necessary to get only four who will say that they do not want to strike. Whether the result of the strike will apply to four men only is another matter that we must examine later.

My whole point is that this clause has no purpose in preventing or settling an industrial dispute. Under it there is no possibility of taking a vote of the union generally. It is to relate to employees in a particular factory who are members of a particular organisation and who are working for a particular employer. It relates to employees who want to buck thousands of members of their organisation and not go out on strike. The Bill will give them immunity to do that. That is my complaint.
Proposed new sub-section (3C) provides:

(3C) A person shall not join with other persons in making an application under sub-section (3A) if the application includes a statement that, to his knowledge, is false or misleading in a material particular.

I believe that that requirement would cause many employees to hesitate, but subject to its being complied with and the application being received from the required number of employees we find, under proposed new sub-section (3D), the following provision:

(3D) Subject to this section, the Commission shall, upon an application made to it under sub-section (3A), order that a vote of the members to whom the application relates for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not they support the industrial action . . .

My point is that sub-clause (2) of section 45 provides that if it would assist in settling the dispute, 'the Commission may'. But under proposed new sub-section (3D) we are told that when the scabs make the application 'the Commission shall'. There is no let-out, even though the taking of such action may be detrimental to the settlement of the dispute. The Commission orders that a vote of the members 'to whom the application relates' shall be taken for the purpose of ascertaining their views. What is the meaning of the words 'to whom the application relates'? Surely it can only relate to those who signed it. It need only relate to the 5 per cent who have appealed to the court for protection-the scabs. It cannot relate to the other 95 per cent of employees in the factory. Unless the Government can provide some other explanation of the words 'to whom the application relates' I cannot see them relating to anyone other than the persons who have made the application.
Proposed new sub-section (3E) provides:

Where the Commission, in considering an application made to it under sub-section (3A), forms the view that the cessation or prevention of the industrial action, or the settlement of the matters giving rise to the industrial action, to which the application relates would not be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views or attitudes of the members to whom the application relates, the Commission shall-

In effect, the application then referred on is refused. Therefore, although sub-section (3D) provides that the Commission shall order a vote, sub-section (3E) seems to be contradictory in that it provides that the Commission may refuse to grant the application.
Under proposed new sub-section (3J) the following is provided:

Where, in considering an application made to it under sub-section (3A), it appears to the Commission that, in the circumstances that have given rise to the making of the application, it would be appropriate to make an order for a secret ballot under sub-section (1) or (2) rather than under sub-section (3D), the Commission may make such an order under sub-section (1) or (2) . . .

Under sub-sections (1) or (2), the Commission must be of the view that to grant the application would have a beneficial effect in settling the dispute. Therefore, if the Commission cannot make an order under sub-sections (1) or (2) that it is not of the opinion that to grant the application would settle the dispute, it will make an order under proposed new sub-section (3J), which has nothing to do with preventing or settling strikes. If the Commission can do it, it will do it under sub-sections (1) or (2). It will be only when the Commission cannot grant the application, when it is not of the opinion that to do so will have no effect on the strike, that it will give permission for the applicants to continue to work. I think that is all I can say with regard to clause 6. It becomes clear that its purpose is not the prevention of industrial disputes. Its simple purpose is to protect scabs who want to buck their union and continue in work at the time of an industrial dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the difficulties seen by Senator Cavanagh do not exist when one looks carefully at the sub-sections to which he has referred. For a start, he is concerned at the possible conflict between proposed new sub-section (3D) and the proposed new sub-sections which follow. I draw his attention to the opening words of the proposed new sub-section (3D), which are: 'Subject to this section'. So what is written in proposed new sub-section (3D) is subject to what is written in the subsequent provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that, subject to existing section 45, the requirement is that the Commission shall, upon an application in accordance with proposed new sub-section (3A), order that a vote of the members, and so on, be taken by secret ballot. So there is a mandatory requirement, subject to the later provisions. But it is very important to see the extent to which that mandatory requirement is affected by what follows. In the immediately following new sub-section, proposed new sub-section (3E), we find the following words:

Where the Commission, in considering an application made to it under sub-section (3A), forms the view that the cessation or prevention of the industrial action, or the settlement of the matters giving rise to the industrial action, to which the application relates would not be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views or attitudes of the members to whom the application relates, the Commission shall-

It then goes on to say that the Commission shall refer it to the President or, where the presidential member is the President, refuse to grant the application. Quite clearly the words I quoted are clear and express, that is, if the Commission forms the view that the cessation or prevention of the dispute would not be assisted by ascertaining views, the application is refused. I think the basic concern expressed by the honourable senator in his comments in Committee on these proposed new sub-sections, that this provision is not related to the settlement of disputes, is met when one looks carefully at the provisions of proposed new sub-section (3E). I think it is also relevant to refer to the other proposed new sub-section referred to by Senator Cavanagh. That is proposed new sub-section (3J). Of course, that proposed new sub-section extends the authority of the Commission to take action other than ordering the more confined ballot which may have been sought in an application under these proposed new sub-sections. It provides:
Where, in considering an application made to it under sub-section (3A)-
That is this new provision-

It appears to the Commission that, in the circumstances that have given rise to the making of the application, it would be appropriate to make an order for a secret ballot under sub-section (1) or (2) rather than under sub-section (3D), the Commission may make such an order under sub-section (1) or (2) instead of making such an order under sub-section (3D).

Senator Cavanagh then referred, I think quite rightly, to the existing secret ballot provisions which relate to the existing power to order a general ballot. I think the pattern overall is quite clear. Whilst one is endeavouring to give to members of a union who are affected by a direction to take industrial action the opportunity to have a ballot which will ascertain the wishes of the unionists who are involved at a particular work place, the fact is that the Commission retains powers which enable it to direct its attention--
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again rise to point out the fact that no quorum is present for what the Government considers to be important legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.
