TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was just concluding with respect to what Senator Cavanagh had put with respect to the proposed new sub-sections in clause 6 was that the requirement that a ballot should be ordered in circumstances in which the requisite number of people has sought one had to be read down by the discretions which are subsequently vested in the Commission to take into account the need to achieve a settlement of the dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button raised with respect to the same clause concerns which related to whether I had information from the Industrial Relations Bureau on the number of disputes caused by union managements as against those which came from the rank and file. I am not able to give him such statistics. My advice-it would be my understanding of the situation-is that disputes sometimes emerge on the shop floor and sometimes go to a particular shop floor through the union management. But in that regard I point out that we are dealing here with provisions which are not mandatory but which simply provide people on the shop floor with the opportunity to seek a ballot if they wish to do so. Of course, the extent to which this provision is availed of will depend in part upon the circumstances in which an industrial dispute arises and upon the inclination of the workers involved. The important point is that they are being given an additional right to an expression of opinion with some protection of law. It is a right which will be there for them to avail themselves of if they wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Committee or to belabour this question. I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for his reply. I started by saying that this clause provides protection for scabs. The Minister has confirmed that with greater clarity than I am capable of. As I said, sub-sections (1) and (2) relate to a settlement of the dispute. The Minister has now pointed out that proposed new sub-section (3D) is mandatory in that in effect it says: 'Subject to this section the Commission shall order a ballot'. We have to look to this proposed new section to see whether there is a let-out for the Commission so that it does not have to order a ballot. The Minister has correctly pointed out to me that there is a provision in proposed new sub-section (3E), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . forms the view that the cessation or prevention of industrial action, or the settlement of the matters giving rise to the industrial action, to which the application relates would not be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views or attitudes . . .

If it would not be encouraged, the Commission has the right not to order the ballot. Otherwise, it has the right. But that relates to encouraging or settling the dispute. We are talking about the dispute for which there is no encouragement of the operation of the Commission. If it will encourage a settlement of the dispute it will not grant the ballot. Proposed new sub-section (3J) reads:

Where, in considering an application made to it under sub-section (3A), it appears to the Commission that, in the circumstances that have given rise to the making of the application, it would be appropriate to make an order for a secret ballot under sub-section (1) or (2) rather than under sub-section (3D), the Commission may make such an order under sub-section (1) or (2) . . .

The only exemption the Commission has from the mandatory clause for making an order is in a case in which a ballot is a possibility of settling the dispute. Therefore, the Commission uses proposed new sub-section (3D) on the occasion when it has no other resource to prevent the dispute. The Commision has an obligation to grant the ballot, knowing it has had no assistance in settling the dispute. Therefore, the main aim of the clause is not to prevent or settle disputes. The main aim of it is the protection of scabs. The Minister did not reply to that. The Minister did not give me any information on that and I would be very pleased if he could enlighten me. What is his definition of 'the members to whom the application relates'? Does it refer to those who have made the application or is it meant in a wider sense?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall very quickly refer to the point raised again by Senator Cavanagh. In fact, I think the position is the reverse of the views he has expressed as his penultimate point. Proposed new sub-section (3E) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the Commission . . . forms the view that the cessation or prevention of the industrial action, or the settlement . . . would not be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views or attitudes . . . the Commission shall-
In other words, the matter which is squarely to be in the mind of the Commission is whether the application would encourage or assist the settlement of the action. That is squarely the matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Commission is not of that view it is compelled under (3D) to grant the application.

—No. If it is not of that view it does not grant the application. Therefore, I think the position is the reverse of what has been put by Senator Cavanagh. I think the second query Senator Cavanagh made related to proposed new sub-section (3D), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether or not they support the industrial action to which the application relates . . .
Does that relate to the final inquiry Senator Cavanagh made?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—It is part of the whole framework which is provided by this proposed new sub-section. If the honourable senator refers back to proposed new sub-section (3A) he will see that there is a reference to members who are directed or requested to engage in industrial action. We start with the proposition that members have been directed or requested to engage in industrial action. The application is an application for a ballot with respect to that industrial action. That is the starting point. Under proposed new sub-section (3A) there is provision for a direction or request from the organisation to engage in a particular industrial action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will end my remarks on this point. Senator Chaney has said that under proposed new sub-section (3E) the Commission does not have to grant the application. I agree with that. It applies if the Commission thinks it will not assist in preventing the industrial dispute. When the Commission does not have that alternative it operates under proposed new sub-section (3D) and it is mandatory for it to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 7 (Conduct of ballot).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a couple of questions that I would like to ask in respect of the provisions of this clause. The first part of clause 7 deals with the method of conducting a ballot if one is requested under the circumstances described earlier in the Bill. Firstly, I am concerned to know whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is able to give us any approximate estimate of the time which would be taken in conducting a ballot of that kind. Secondly, if there is a reconciliation of the dispute, can the Minister give us an estimate of the time involved in unlocking that dispute, assuming as one can only assume that the ballot procedure has to be used to unlock it as well as to get it going.

SPEECH.PARA: Another query I have relates to the proposed new section in clause 8 headed 'Commission to have regard to result of ballot'. Proposed new section 45B states that after a ballot has been conducted in accordance with an order under section 45, the Commission shall have regard to the result of the ballot. I think I can understand what might happen if the ballot is against industrial action, but what would happen if the ballot is, for example, 98 per cent, as it has been, in favour of industrial action? What does the expression 'the Commission shall have regard to the result of the ballot' mean? If one looks at the context of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the Commission is given on most matters pretty clear guidelines about what it does to handle particular situations. What on earth does the expression 'shall have regard to the result of the ballot' mean if the membership is shown to be almost totally in favour of industrial action? What is the Commission supposed to do? Is it supposed to pore over the resolutions for days?

TALK.START.PARA: —Drink a quick glass of water.

—Senator Martyr has interjected with the suggestion that the Commission should drink a quick glass of water. I do not know whether that is a profitable suggestion. Seriously, what does that expression mean?
—Where would it leave Mr Viner on television if he faced one of those?

—That is right. The third point I raise relates to proposed new section 45C of the Bill. I put it in these terms: This is a right to work Bill. It is a right to work Bill as against the decisions of the committee of management of the union. Presumably, the scenario is that the union says: 'You shall not work because the union thinks you should get $10 a week extra'. The unionist, as an individual employee, as against the union claims the right to work and he says: 'I am not going to have one of these ballots because I want to continue working. I do not want to support the union's claim for a $10 a week increase. I am quite content to go on working'. In the normal situation in most plants to which this legislation refers there are numerous unions involved.

SPEECH.PARA: What happens if the employee who claims the right to work under this legislation goes back and says: 'Here I am. We have had the ballot. I am excused. I have a right to continue working', and the employer says: 'I am sorry, there is no work for you. Because other unions are involved in the stoppage, I will have to stand you down'? That is a very common industrial situation. What is the Fraser Government going to do in pursuit of this legislation to ensure the right of that employee to work, as against the right of his employer? How good is the right to work, which this legislation guarantees in terms of the provisions of clause 45(C)? The answer is that it is no good at all because Mr Viner will not pay employers large amounts of money so that they can pay the wages to ensure the right to work in that very common industrial situation, which could arise. That is what is silly about the legislation, because it is not directed at real industrial situations. It is, as Senator Harradine put it-I forget his expression-political stunting or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Close.

—Close, thank you. The Minister might remind me in his reply. Those are the points I am concerned about. Firstly, how long would the first ballot objecting to the course of conduct of the union take? Secondly, if the strike had to be unlocked, how long would it take to unlock it? Thirdly, what does the expression, 'shall have regard to the result of the ballot' mean? If the ballot is totally in favour of a strike, what on earth is the poor Commission expected to do? Fourthly, what happens in a quite common industrial situation, in view of the right to work implications of this legislation, if the employer says: 'Because of other circumstances I cannot guarantee you the right to work. Even though you have been through all of this ballot procedure and come back here and said that you are prepared to work, you have not got a job'. What is the Government going to do about that?

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has raised a number of queries in the context of clause 7. The first of those was with respect to the timing of the ballot. There is no simple, absolute answer covering the variety of circumstances that could come within the purview of this legislation. Obviously we could be dealing with different sized groups involved in smaller or larger concerns. The practical requirements of conducting a ballot will vary from case to case. The honourable senator's concern is expressed in the context of something which he raised during the second reading speech, from my recollection, which is the problem that people might be locked into a situation by a ballot. My understanding of the history of those cases where ballots have been held is that quite often a ballot has been part of the process which has led to resolution. Under this legislation the holding of a ballot does not take from the Commission or from the parties the opportunity to go on dealing with the dispute. The purpose of this legislation is simply to give members the opportunity, if they wish, to express their views through a secret ballot on the question of whether they are in favour of industrial action directed or requested by their organisation. That is not a condition precedent to engaging in industrial action. There is no requirement that having voted in favour of industrial action, the member need vote in a subsequent ballot against industrial action before that action must come to an end. There is nothing to prevent the Commission from continuing to deal with an industrial dispute which is subject to industrial action while a ballot is in progess or when the results have been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: In the discussion on the previous clause we went through the fact that in those cases where the Commission thought it was inimical to the settlement of the dispute, it is not required to proceed with the ballot. The legislation is not imposing an inflexible framework upon a dispute situation. It has been drawn in a way which allows the Commission to take into account what seems to be settled in the Committee debate as being the primary concern to see that the dispute is settled. It would be the view of the Government that the process is no more hamstrung than it is in, say, the present dispute which is of concern and which was mentioned in the Senate today with respect to Telecom Australia, where because, as I understand it, there has been a union initiated ballot of members, that is not something which locks the parties out of negotiations or excludes the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This is simply adding a further mechanism to those which are available to the people who are involved in the dispute. It is one which we believe will be useful to those people who are of the view that there may be within their work place an opposition to industrial action which has been directed.

As far as the last point raised by Senator Button is concerned, the legislation is not put forward on the basis that it solves every industrial problem. I do not believe that it solves the problem which is raised by Senator Button of the worker who, through no fault of his own and through no fault of the Commission but only through the fault of unionists in perhaps other organisations, is refused the opportunity to work. This legislation does not, and I do not see how it could, deal with the practical problem raised by Senator Button. That means that in certain cases where there are a plethora or a group of unions involved and where there is no opportunity to work, that the mere holding of a ballot is not going to create that opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of the Minister's answer really goes to the question of what the credibility of this legislation will be. I have in mind somebody who genuinely wants to work. He seeks a ballot on the first occasion. He may get into the situation I have described. He then asks himself: 'What on earth is the good of all this to me? Why should I take part in any more of these ballots?' That seems to me to be the real situation which is likely to arise. I also ask the Minister whether he has any comment to make about the question I asked, which was what the Commission has to do when it gets a result that the members of the union want to strike? What does the expression, ' . . . shall have regard to the result of the ballot' mean?

—I think it would be accepted by Senator Button that those words cannot mean that the Commission is blindly bound to follow the results of that ballot. I think that it is probably beyond power to have a provision which meant that. It is simply an expression which is meant to bring out the Government's view that it is important that the views of the members concerned, the people who have sought and obtained the opportunity to vote, shall be taken into account. The Commission shall have regard for that view. It is not, as I understand it-I think we are excluded from giving legal opinions in this place-trying to simply say that the decision of that vote takes the place of any decision the Commission might take. It is simply something which, in the words of the Act, the Commission shall have regard to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to mention new sub-section 45 (3B). Is that yet to come?
—We have just passed that. Perhaps, Mr Minister, you could give some response to Senator Mulvihill.

—I wish to ask a question relating to clause 6. Proposed new sub-section 45 (3B) fixes the minimum number of applicants as the members of an organisation at the one place of work. The Minister will note the word 'organisation' is used in the singular. I wish to relate that provision to the trade union combinations that could be involved. At a big railway workshop, the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, the Australian Railways Union, the Australasian Society of Engineers, the Federated Moulders (Metal) Union of Australia, the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia and the Electrical Trades Union of Australia could all be involved.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of a big construction site, the Builders Labourers Federation, the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, the Australian Workers Union and the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia could be involved. Seven or more unions could be involved at a site. Yet this clause refers to the minimum number of applicants being the members of an organisation. Does that mean that the members of one of the unions involved who met the requirements of the Bill could institute this ballot action? If the answer is yes, does that mean that a ballot would be taken of only one-seventh or one-fifth of the unions involved? Does the reference to a minimum number of applicants mean that parallel action would have to be taken by rank and file members of each of the related unions I have mentioned?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are really back to dealing with clause 6. I take it the Minister will reply to Senator Mulvihill's question.

—The interpretatin which Senator Mulvihill spelt out in his question is, I think, correct. Proposed section 45 (3B) set out in clause 6 specifically relates to a particular organisation; so at a site at which a number of organisations were represented, a ballot would be taken of the relevant organisations and not of the others. In the light of the sorts of comments made by Senator Button in relation to a subsequent clause, that might be regarded as being somewhat irrelevant. But Senator Mulvihill will be aware of situations in which the real problem is that one trade union might seek to take industrial action because it is seeking to extend its right to do certain work done by the members of another union. It may well be very relevant to a dispute of that sort that would occur on a multi-union site. The ballot would apply only to members of a particular union who were concerned about a direction to take industrial action.

—The only point I make is that if workers were doing excavations, the Builders Labourers Federation would be the key union involved in a safety issue. But if the issue involved a site allowance or something like that, each union would probably take the plunge and become involved in the matter. I take it that the Minister is saying that if five unions felt that none of their rank and file wanted to be involved in a ballot, if they were united on their course, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commissioner dealing with the matter, even if other unions returned to work, would still have to negotiate with the five unions which were still on strike and were maintaining a solid front. I take it that that is what the Minister has implied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If more than one union wished to be involved, members of each of those unions would have to make applications.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
(Quorum formed).
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is being asked to give its assent to the Roads Grants Bill 1981. It is being considered in the same way as a number of pieces of legislation have been considered by the Senate-that is, in a rather cursory way. We have been inundated with an amount of legislation which has had the effect of preventing the Senate from giving proper consideration to these matters. As has been the case with many of the Bills with which we have been dealing this week, this is a disgraceful piece of legislation insofar as it sets out to deny the rights of the States so far as road grants are concerned. It puts a nail in the coffin of the co-operative federalism which was so much a feature of the Government's so-called approach to Commonwealth-State relations, particularly as it has been expressed so many times in this place by Senator Carrick.

SPEECH.PARA: This piece of legislation represents a censure on the character approach of the adviser who was appointed to assist the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to express the very principles of co-operative federalism. It shows the falseness of this Government and the fallacious approach that it has to its relationship with the States and the Territories. Once again, this Government expresses in this Bill its intention to look after its powerful friends in the private sector. Once again, this goes hand in hand with the Government's abrogation of its national responsibilities and its obligations to the States, and with the false notion that somehow or other small government is good government. Anyone listening to this debate, whether in the Parliament or outside it, will appreciate that in this legislation the national Government is dictating to the States and refusing to carry out its proper role of responsible government.

In the past five years the Fraser Government has been gradually reducing in real terms its funding to the Australian road network but this year it has gone one step further in its futile attempt to ultimately destroy any viable public sector in the Australian economy. It ignores all of the advice that has been given to it by its advisers, including the Australian Bureau of Road Economics and other organisations. One of them, the National Roads and Motorists' Association, has been reported in this evening's newspapers as pointing to the defects that exist in this legislation. This Government has finally succumbed to those forces in the Liberal Party which are forcing their ideological stance on both the Government and the community. We see here another expression of the conservatives winning the battle in the Liberal Party against the liberals. Simultaneously, that battle shows an attack on the rights of the States by lumping them with the costliest areas of public expenditure without giving them the financial and leadership assistance which, the Opposition believes, a national government has an obligation to do. It is imposing a costly form of arrangements upon the way in which our road programs will henceforth operate. It is another example of the dictatorial way that the Fraser Government operates in its relationship with the States.

As the Bill provides some federal funds, the Opposition, whilst it is critical of the nature of the legislation, does not intend to oppose it. At the conclusion of my remarks, I will move an amendment which summarises our basic objections to the provisions of the Bill. Also I will move an amendment in the Committee stages for the retention by the States of their discretionary power to select those national roadworks for which public tenders should be invited. The main purpose of the Bill is to provide, in 1981-82, $685m to the States and the Northern Territory for road works and for the first time it provides minimal levels of advance Commonwealth national road funding in 1982-83 and 1983-84. The Bill retains the same relativities of funds between the States and the Northern Territory and between categories as in 1980-81. However, there is no commitment on the part of the Commonwealth to maintain these relativities over the rest of the five-year plan to 1984-85. We object to this but we realise that the Government has the authority temporarily-for at least another five or six sitting days in the Senate-so there is not much point in objecting to what is proposed in this legislation.

Let us look at the monetary rise in grants. In 1980-81, there was an 11 per cent increase; in 1981-82, there is a 9 per cent increase; in 1982-83, there is a scheduled increase of 7 per cent; and, in both 1983-84 and 1984-85, the scheduled increase in grants is 6 per cent. In real terms this demonstrates a continuing but diminishing Commonwealth responsibility for road funding. The Minister for Transport will be empowered by this legislation to declare as developmental roads which he considers to be of national importance. These include those that develop particular industries or energy resources, including roads that aid interstate or overseas trade and commerce or help tourism.

The Bill also reduces the number of road categories from four to three and, therefore, it is an important piece of legislation. It amalgamates urban arterial and rural arterial roads into one category of arterial roads. The three categories remaining will be national roads, arterial roads and local roads. The legislation also involves the Minister consulting with those States on a new formula for the distribution of Commonwealth funds to local government. In the absence of an agreement with any State or the Northern Territory, the existing practice whereby the Minister approves a program of local road allocations from States will be followed. As far as I am aware, the formula approach has been adopted by New South Wales and discussions are in progress with Tasmania.

The most important, destructive and undesirable change for which this legislation provides is that all grants for national road construction will be conditional-for the first time, as a direction from the Federal Government-upon the States calling public tenders for road works. This differs from existing, established procedures and all past existing legislation whereby the States have had discretion to determine which national highway construction works will go to tender and which will be built by State road authorities. So here we have a piece of legislation which interferes with the rights of States and which, for the first time, directs the States and puts conditions upon the manner in which they will carry out road construction. As a result of this proposal, there is unanimity among the States that this requirement is an unwarranted imposition upon them.

Without any economic justification whatsoever, without any request from the States, without any advice from people who advise the Government on questions of road works, this Government has made a decision which changes the established practices. Rather than reduce costs, as the State Ministers have said, all States are adamant that this will cause massive disruption to road works and public road construction forces, retrenchments, an increase in red tape, greater supervisory costs and will replace existing flexibility and efficiency with an inflexible requirement. Therefore, one expects that in these circumstances the Senate will exercise its powers of review and say that, as this is a States House, it will give some consideration to the States views. It matters not whether they be from Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia or New South Wales, the State Ministers for Transport are opposed to this legislation. I quote from the New South Wales Department of Main Roads report, which states:

There is no evidence that indicates that there would be more roads built or more effective and efficient utilisation of road funds by the complete use of contractors. It has been the Department's experience over many years that the letting of comprehensive roadworks contracts has not resulted in any great savings . . .
Of course that view is also expressed by other main roads authorities and construction authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Gietzelt but this is an important Bill and a quorum is not present. I draw attention to the state of the Senate.

—The Government's excuse for this change of face and for this new attitude is that it is about saving money and reducing taxes. The Opposition says that this is a sham and inexcusable in respect of what this legislation proposes to do. This Government has taken an ideological position and it is pressing it in the interests of its big money backers. The legislation has nothing at all to do with the ordinary men and women of this country. To find evidence of this Government's hollow philosophy in this regard, one has only to turn to the annual report of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Direct construction by Governments has continued to be a major problem for the industry . . . the national office has devoted a great deal of time to the preparation of draft legislation and to papers for general use. In addition, representations have been made regarding significant volumes of Federal Government work that are still carried out by 'day labour'.

Of course, what we are now seeing in this legislation is that 'draft legislation' being considered by the Senate today. Yesterday, citizens attempted to present a viewpoint to this Government and we saw what happened in King's Hall-the use of brute force to remove people who had a point of veiw which was not acceptable to the Government. But it is obvious that the big business backers of this Government are able, not only in respect of this legislation but also in respect of a whole range of legislation which this Government is currently ramming through this Parliament, to have their presence felt, to have an influence in the drafting of legislation. In fact, they are responsible for the very piece of legislation which we are currently considering. The Government is willing to gamble-and it is a huge gamble-with the jobs of many thousands of people and with taxpayers' money in the faint hope and the false hope that its ideology is correct. If the Government wanted to know the facts, why did it not undertake a study into the subject before gambling with taxpayers' money, with motorists' lives, against an article of conservative dogma, which is what this legislation seeks to do? That course was recommended by the now defunct Bureau of Roads to an earlier conservative government way back in 1969.

I point out to honourable senators that every State in the Commonwealth, without exception, is against this Government's proposal to abolish the traditional discretionary power of the States to decide on which projects tenders shoud be invited. At present, private contractors get at least 50 per cent of all the national road construction work anyway, but the road constructors, of course, are not satisfied with this. Their powerful lobby represents itself in the inner sanctums of this Government and legislation is prepared to suit their economic desires. The Australian Labor Party is not opposed to the selective use of contractors, but it is opposed to the Commonwealth dictating to the States. It is opposed to the Commonwealth saying that the States shall not have the power to have a discretion in these matters, that the States should cede control over the mix of contract and day labour work to a very imperfect market situation, to a procedure whereby a Federal official will stand guard at the opening of the tender box to prevent illegalities.

The States have had decades of experience in road construction and in determining the most appropriate and balanced mix for each type of job. This has resulted in the effective use of available funds and resources and the heavy taxpayer investment in costly road plant and skilled professional experts. The Commonwealth now wants to change this and is about to replace this flexible approach, this correct approach, with an inflexible blanket requiring forcing tenders to be called for all national road construction purposes. Instead of road construction expenditure being dictated by need, by efficiency, by local demand, it will be dictated by a desire for private profit, as determined by this legislation, by the Fraser-Anthony Government. Private enterprise will get the pick of the work and the State road authorities will fill in the gaps.

We will have the ludicrous situation whereby the States will design national road projects, do the survey work, prepare the project specifications, draw up the tenders, administer the procedures, submit their own tenders to themselves, assess all the tenders and then give the work to themselves or to a private contractor and, in any case, supervise the quality control of construction. Of course that is the general experience of people who know anything about the way in which State public works programs are carried out or the way in which local government programs are carried out. The Commonwealth's contribution to this will be to ensure that a Federal officer is standing at the opening of the tender box so that the States do not tamper with the tenders. So much for this Government's professed belief in the principles of co-operative federalism! So much for this Government's concern for the rights of the States! So much for this Government's professed belief that the States should have the right to determine their own works programs!

The new procedures will involve the States in a mass of red tape, an increase in State supervisory work, a wasting of public money in needless administration, delays, large scale disruption of State road works, thousands of retrenchments and the under-utilisation of their already existing road plant equipment. I am advised that in New South Wales alone, for example, 790 men will be affected. They work at the following 17 Department of Main Roads depots throughout New South Wales: Thornleigh; Bowenfels; Picton; Bellambi; Singleton; Waratah; Glen Innes; Tenterfield; Armidale; South Tamworth; Holbrook; Tumut; Goulburn; Gundagai; Yass; Karoing and Wyong. In all those places the jobs of the men working for the Department of Main Roads, which hitherto has been an important integral part of decentralisation, are now at risk. Large scale hardship will be the result in these rural areas and there will be an undermining of provincial communities. The very essence of decentralisation is at stake in this piece of legislation.

I am told that in Tasmania, for example, some 474 men could lose their jobs as a direct result of this piece of legislation. In that State very few road contractors have the capacity to build national roads, so if the work is to be done by private enterprise, almost inevitably it will have to be done by firms operating from the mainland. This is being done by a government which claims to have respect for the States and which claims to support the principles of decentralisation. This will involve a loss of jobs in Tasmania and a loss of influence by Tasmanians over their own State's affairs. I would expect, therefore, that Tasmanian senators would support their State as, indeed, I would expect the honourable senators who will follow me in this debate from the other States to have some regard to the criticism by the Opposition of this piece of legislation.

No State supports the proposition. No State supports the legislation. The Local Government Association does not support it either. The Local Government Association resolved unanimously at its last conference:
That the Conference endorse the recent action taken by the Executive-
That is, of the Association-
in informing the Minister for Transport-
That is, the Commonwealth Minister for Transport-
that it is the ACLGA's view that each local government authority should retain absolute discretion as to whether its road programs be put to tender or carried out by day labour.

The Association clearly sees the dangers to taxpayers and to ratepayers in the Commonwealth's policy of compulsory preference to private road contractors. The Government is imposing this system on the States, yet no State or local government instrumentality wants it. Why then are we being forced to consider this piece of legislation? Because it ignores the elected representatives of the people in all those areas. The views of the elected representatives of the people are being set aside to permit a private lobby to wax fat on public money. So much for the Government's professed belief in the right to freedom of choice! It is not there for the States. It is not there for local government and it is not there for the citizens. The Government should admit the truth of its ill-conceived sell-out and should not continue with this hyprocrisy. But, of course, we know that in this place for the next five or six days the Government will use its numbers to carry legislation. Thank God that as from 1 July 1981 those numbers will so change as to permit this House to have a review role and not a role of automatically acting as a rubber stamp for the Executive, for the Fraser-Anthony Cabinet. The Government clearly considers that the Australian people's interest in these matters should not be tolerated. It selectively imposed rigours of competition only to serve to concentrate benefits to the contracting section of our society-the powerful-while wage earners and small businessmen and people in decentralised areas have to pay for this pampering and the so-called qualities of free enterprise which corrupt and which are corrupting the way in which the Fraser Government operates.

On top of all this ideological undermining we also have the Government's continued inability and unwillingness to grasp the essential importance of a good main roads system in this country. The Motorists association, as I said the other day when speaking to a report, has been wringing its hands in despair for years at the steady decline in real terms in road funding. It is the public which suffers in terms of road accidents and deaths, dangerous and unsatisfactory road conditions, loss of time in travelling, loss of income and increased costs in energy and for repairs. But the Government claims that it is interested in conserving fuel, and that it is concerned about road safety and the basic interest of the Australian people. Let us look at what the National Roads and Motorists Association in New South Wales has said about this. That body recently carried out a survey on the new Liverpool to Mittagong freeway which was a product of capital expenditure allocated during the Whitlam period by the then Minister for Transport, the honourable Charles Jones. The survey showed that following the construction of that 64-kilometre road there would be an estimated saving in one year of 370 serious crashes, including 150 casualty crashes, with 300-odd people injured. This type of expenditure is therefore of great value in eliminating some of the needless fatalities and crashes that occur in this country.

Some people may well come up with varying figures as to what our road accidents cost the economy as a whole. A figure has been suggested by those who have some interest in the area of road safety. A figure of $1,000m has been mentioned as a cost of fatalities and accidents in this country. That figure has been used by those involved in this area for the last seven or eight years. Consequently, one is entitled to say that, taking into account inflationary factors, this figure would be closer to $2,000m. In the April/May issue of Open Road, the NRMA journal-no one could say that is a journal that is any way influenced by my side of politics-it states:
The NRMA estimates that completion of the F3-
That is the Sydney-Newcastle expressway-

Should result in an annual saving of 21 lives, 420 injuries and a cut of 920 in the number of recorded crashes. This estimate is based on current crash figures, and on studies which show freeways to be up to five times safer than conventional two-lane highways.
The paper goes on to state:

There should also be enormous saving in fuel each year. A car with a fuel consumption of 11 litres/100 kilometres . . . could save up to $1.30 on a trip from Wahroonga to Newcastle. This saving, spread across the estimated 12,500 vehicles which make the trip daily, could produce savings worth about $4.5m a year.

So the saving, on those figures alone, almost pays for the construction costs of the roads that we are concerned about. An extract from An Assessment of the Australian Road System 1979 shows quite clearly that this Government's allocation to roads is declining as against the States' allocation to roads. For example, in the period 1979-80 to 1983-84 the Commonwealth's annual growth rate is estimated at 5 per cent, the State annual growth rate is estimated at 11.1 per cent and the local growth rate is estimated at 9.5 per cent. That estimate is based on current prices. The 1976-77 prices show a decline in the Commonwealth's average annual growth rate of 1.4 per cent, while the States had an increase of 8.5 per cent and local government had an increase of 8.1 per cent. On these figures alone, it can be established clearly that the Commonwealth is not playing its part as far as road funds are concerned. (Quorum formed). On behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(1) the Bill fails to provide adequate funds to the States and the Northern Territory for desirable road construction and maintenance;

(2) the abolition of the discretionary power of the States to determine which national road works should be offered to private contractors by public tender is contrary to the national interest and will create disruption and dislocation of State road authorities, leading to inefficiency, waste, inflexibility and the loss of employment;

(3) the amalgamation of the former categories of Urban Arterial roads and Rural Arterial roads into a single category of Arterial roads will lead to an inequitable distribution of road funds between urban and rural areas; and
(4) the Government has again failed to use an expanded road construction and maintenance program to provide safer roads and more jobs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Roads Grants Bill. It is significant because of the influence on the legislation from the Advisory Council on Inter-government Relations. It is probably the first time that that body has seriously influenced any of the legislation before the Parliament. I believe it is important that we should recognise it on this basis. It is important, accordingly, to consider that that body comprises members from both chambers of the Parliament, and from both major parties, members from every State Parliament, from all parties, and local government, both city and country members, and other citizens as well. I have only recently joined the Council so I have had no part in the preparation of its report, but I recommend to all senators that it should be read, starting with Senator Gietzelt. It is important to see how much of that report has wound up in this legislation and the thinking behind it. Of course, that report was written with the consensus of Federal, State and local government.

SPEECH.PARA: Of all the things that we agree on there is really only one clause-recommendation 28-that Senator Gietzelt referred to in his speech. The same applies to the Bill before the Senate. Senator Gietzelt spent the whole of his speech talking about one clause and systematically ignored the rest of the Bill. I think it is important that we look at what has happened in this regard and at the way the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations has worked on the matter. The ACIR is conscious that it is primarily concerned with the relationship amongst governments, and that is the basis under which this report and others have been formulated. Within the main objective, the Council has attempted to describe role and relationship, identify the problems, develop and analyse the possible alternative relationship processes and recommend on possible optimum relation processes. These are the sorts of things that have gone into this legislation. They show through very much.

The Council came up with four items in its conclusion. Firstly, the Council saw a need to provide an environment conducive to forward planning, Secondly, it took the view that all three spheres of government have an important role to play. Thirdly, it stated that each sphere of government should have clearly defined functions and responsibilities. Fourthly, it suggested that the determination of the classification should involve all the governments concerned. All these aspects are now part of the Bill. The Council considered, in clause 28 of the report, that the States should be responsible for the physical construction and maintenance of national highways. That is the major difference to be seen from all the work that has gone into the legislation.

The Council, at clause 302 of its report, concluded that in general the relationships between the three spheres of government in the roads field were sound. The Council secretariat was impressed by the obvious desire to achieve as harmonious a relationship as possible. From the way Senator Gietzelt was carrying on, it sounded as though this had been done under great difficulty; but this is not so. The composition of the Council is something that has to be seen to be fully understood. All the members present were from different parliaments and of different political persuasions and views. There were no reporters and no advisers present. The meeting was very open and great credit should be paid for the way it has been set up.

One of the important issues of the Bill is that the categories of roads have been reduced from eight to three. Everybody wanted the number of categories reduced. We are now down to the categories of national, arterial and local roads. The quotas, which have been a difficulty in the past, have now disappeared. Funding has got under way. It is well started. There was an 11 per cent increase this year and there will be a 9 per cent increase next year. If Senator Gietzelt had read the relevant announcement, instead of saying how much the figures were reduced, he would have said that these national road appropriations for 1982-83 and 1983-84 should be regarded solely as a minimum planning base at this stage. The amounts currently specified in the Bill will be substantially supplemented when subsequent amendments are made to the legislation to appropriate funds for the balance of the five-year program. That aspect seems to have escaped his view at this stage.

The problem that existis is that there is complete panic in Tasmania. The Tasmanian Minister has gone completely berserk. He has developed a complete paranoia in regard to responsibility on this matter. He has stirred up the total work force. The work force is sound, solid and completely reliable. With a whole series of radio, Press and television and telex messages all over the place he has got the work force in a total panic. Be it on his head; he will have to answer for this. He has managed to stir up all these people with a remarkable shortage of facts. It is all over the question of calling tenders for national highways.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the whole you do not approve?

—On the whole, I do not approve. Meetings have been held all around Tasmania. There have been letters, telegrams all sorts of things. People have come to my home and to my office. I have been able to talk to a lot, but not to as many as I would like. I am still trying to catch up with the correspondence to give the people more of the facts. The theatricals that have been going on will take a long time to unlock.

SPEECH.PARA: The main roads Department labour force in Tasmania is first class and works very well. I have no doubt that if the time comes it will show that it is as efficient as can possibly be expected. It will show that it is as effiicient as any other work force in the road area. I am surprised-in fact, I am terribly disappointed-at the lack of confidence the Tasmanian Government has in its own work force. I think this fear is completely unjustified. I regret the men who are involved in these meetings and in writing letters have purely and simply been used as bait on a rather poor party political hook. If the Tasmanian Main Roads Department does not win all the contracts, it will be for one of two reasons. It will either be that the figure presented by way of tender is absolutely hopelessly loaded with overheads or it has been put together by incompetents. If we have to listen to this fear about mainland contractors swamping Tasmania, we must consider some aspects. Incidentally, the public contract basis in Tasmania is not 50 per cent; it is 100 per cent for main roads contracts. That is the way it is. I see no reason why it will change. I do not think anybody has yet come up with one fact to indicate that it is likely to change.

If a contractor from the mainland is attempting to undertake a job in Tasmania, he has to pay freight and incur costs in respect of the time involved in locating equipment and getting it to Tasmania. He has to pay fares and accommodation for administrative officers and other members of the work force. He has to hire specialists such as surveyors and engineers locally. Private contractors have to make an allowance for depreciation of equipment which the Department does not have to do. The department does not have to pay payroll tax, sales tax or workers compensation insurance. If it cannot obtain jobs with that type of advantage, with local knowledge and an experienced crew it is an absolute disgrace. I hope that what comes out of this is that the Department and the Tasmanian Government will be able to look at their own affairs, study overheads and also look at the ratio of administration to work force. I hope that benefit will come out of that examination. I deplore the stance that has been taken by my own Tasmanian Goverment and the attitudes that have been expressed in putting this absolute fear into ordinary decent working men all round Australia when there is absolutely no cause for it. There is nothing to indicate that there is any basis for fear. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Roads Grants Bill 1981. (Quorum formed). Before referring generally to the Road Grants Bill, I wish to comment that tonight we are witnessing in the Senate another scandalous situation. It is 15 minutes past 12 on Thursday morning--
—Mr President, the Deputy President stated that a quorum was present. Could I ask whether a quorum is present at this moment?
—A quorum is present.

—Again I will endeavour to commence my speech on the second reading of the Roads Grants Bill. Tonight we are witnessing a scandalous situation. It is now 17 minutes past 12 on Thursday morning. We are dealing with a very important Bill and no doubt the Government hopes that, by keeping the Senate here at this late hour, opposition members will be restricted from making the comments that they should make. We have witnessed this sort of thing before. The Government seems to be in greater disarray during this session of Parliament than it has been since it came to office in 1975. We all know the reason. Government supporters are running around like headless chooks because of their problems not only in Canberra but also in all of the Liberal States. No doubt, when I refer to some of the things that have been said by the Ministers for Roads in non-Liberal States I will throw a cat among the pigeons. I refer particularly to Senator Bjelke-Petersen because I intend to quote what Mr Hinze, the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police has said. I will be very surprised if she does not take some notice of his pleas.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt has moved on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to the motion for the second reading. I will not take the time of the Senate to repeat it. It will be available in Hansard. I note that Senator Archer of Tasmania was somewhat critical of Senator Gietzelt for dealing at length with one clause of the Bill. If the legislation is passed-I hope that it will not be-it will make it compulsory for all State road authorities to let their work out to tender. Senator Archer may not think that that is a very significant provision but it is very important to a great many State Ministers and to people who have placed great faith in State road construction authorities over the years and have applauded them for the work that they have done, as I have myself in South Australia in particular.
In the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) the following appears:
The Bill provides that grants for national roads construction works will be conditional upon tenders being called and dealt with in accordance with approved arrangements.
Our intention to include such a requirement in future roads legislation was foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his 1980 election policy statement.

What a pity that so very few of the things that were foreshadowed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975, 1977 and 1980 have not been put into effect. Most of his policy promises have been broken, but the Minister for Transport has latched on to this proposal, which he says was forecast by the Prime Minister. He claims that the Bill merely honours that election undertaking.
The Minister went on to say:
The matter has also been discussed at some length with State Roads Ministers at meetings of the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

Anyone who was not aware of the real situation could be led by those remarks to think that the Minister had obtained the full agreement of the States Roads Ministers. As my colleague Senator Gietzelt has pointed out, the Minister has obtained the agreement of not one of them; all are opposed to the Bill. The Minister added:

The Government considers that only by the creation of a competitive environment can it be sure that maximum value is being obtained from its very substantial outlays on national roads. State and Northern Territory road authorities will not be precluded from undertaking works using their own day labour forces. It will be open to State authorities to submit bids for the works in competition with private contractors. The requirement will apply to all works commencing after 31 August 1981 for which tenders have not already been called. Detailed administrative arrangements are still to be finalised in consultation with the States.

The Senate is being called upon to pass a Bill in respect of which the Minister has stated that he has had consultation with the States, but then adds that the detailed administrative arrangements are still to be finalised in consultation with the States. We find a complete contradiction in those paragraphs of the Minister's second reading speech. After being led to believe that the Minister has reached agreement with the States, we are told that final arrangements cannot be worked out until he has had consultations with them. To find such wording in second reading speeches presented by this Government is not new.
I am especially interested in the following comment:
It will be open to State authorities to submit bids for the works in competition with private contractors.

In my own State of South Australia, Mr Tonkin became the Premier of the Liberal Government in 1979. (Quorum formed). Since the 1979 election in South Australia, when a change of government took place, we have seen a rapid deterioration of the work force in the Highways Department of that State. The Department has a very proud record. Similarly, the work force of the Engineering and Water Supply Department has been severely run down. The Minister points out in his second reading speech that State authorities will be able to tender for their own works, but we have to realise that all of the specifications and designs for road works will be drawn up in the offices of the respective Ministers in the States. The State authorities will then have an opportunity to submit a tender. In South Australia, where the Government is deliberately running down the State work force, an effort will be made to ensure that the tender by the State authorities is so high that they will not get the work. The Government there will want to pass it on to some of its wealthy friends, the private contractors.

I have no doubt that those contractors will be all alerted to the fact that the State tender will be very high. Then, in turn, they will put in higher tenders than they would submit normally. Thus, instead of getting cheaper work, we will get dearer work, carried out by private contractors. I am reminded of a cartoon in the Canberra Times yesterday, based on the arguments abroad now about public funding of elections. The cartoon depicted Mr Fraser with his arm up, standing above Mr Lynch and talking about corruption. We see Mr Lynch with a bag alongside and smoking a good cigar. Private enterprise is seen shovelling dollars into the bag; he is the bag carrier. Similarly, under the system proposed in the Bill, we will find private enterprise contractors shovelling dollars into the bag for the election campaign funds of the Liberal Party. At the same time, our State work force will be run down. Already in South Australia we find private contractors given work without having the necessary machinery to perform it.

So what happens? They are hiring it at very cheap rates from the State Liberal Government to carry out the work. They are wearing out the machinery. We are losing expertise. When we get back into government at the next election we will have no proper machinery because it will all be worn out and we will have no expertise. It will cost us many millions of dollars to build up the proper equipment necessary to carry on the good work that was carried out in South Australia under the previous roads Minister, Mr Virgo, and to replenish our skilled work force. Then we will be accused of not being able to handle the finances of the State. Those are the tactics of Liberal governments everywhere. That is what they do.

I sound that warning. I am not the only one who has sounded it. It has been sounded by Mr Hinze, who referred to the great rundown of the work force. I sound that warning. That is what is happening in South Australia. It will go on happening. Every week people coming to my office in the town of Murray Bridge say that to retain a job in the Engeering and Water Supply Department or the Highways Department they have to travel up to 200 miles to work on Monday morning and 200 miles home again on Friday night. That causes not only great expense but also social problems. We are going to see broken homes because mothers are at home all week trying to look after children while dad is away in a camp somewhere doing the work. Yet the Liberal Party says: 'We look after people. We are conscious of the problems of the work force'. It is no more conscious now than it ever was.

I want to quote some of the things that have been said in this regard by not only the Premier and Ministers in New South Wales but also by some of Labor's shadow Ministers and some Liberal-Country Party Ministers. A couple of weeks ago in the Adelaide News there was a big headline which read: 'Tonkin warns cuts may cost SA jobs'. The article read:
The retrenchment of some State Government workers was not ruled out today by the Premier, Mr Tonkin.
He sounded the warning following tight restrictions on Federal funding of the State.
That is what we see in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?

—Mr Tonkin. He was in Canberra at the weekend. He is the man who threatened to cut off natural gas from South Australia to New South Wales if New South Wales did not do certain things. Then he retracted that. I saw him on television when he said that that was a publicity stunt. But today in the South Australian Parliament he made the same threat. He is a great fellow. Tomorrow he will probably say: 'That is the second phase of my publicity stunt'. Let us look at what Mr Hinze said. An article in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 21 May reported him as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the other Ministers 'to a man'-
Those are the Ministers whom he contacted all round Australia-
were aghast at the dictatorial attitude by the Federal Government in relation to proposals for roadworks funding recommended by the razor gang.
'I have written to all Queensland Federal members and senators-
Senators, mind you-
asking them to keep the State's interests in mind when this legislation is being debated. If they do this they will have no option but to reject the legislation outright?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—That is what Mr Hinze said. He is the man whom Senator Messner accused last week, in answer to a question in Parliament, of bellyaching.
—He is a big man.

—He certainly has plenty there to ache. It is his business what he puts in there. I am concerned about the words he utters from his mouth. No doubt those words are directed at the Queensland senators, as he said. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is one of them and her husband happens to be Premier of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —The late hour of the night is getting to me. He would certainly never be Premier of that State because there is no gerrymander there. Under a democratic election system he would never be the Premier of any State. I am sorry I made that mistake. However, he is the Premier of Queensland. (Quorum formed). As I was saying, Mr Hinze comes from Queensland where he is the Minister responsible for roads. He has called on all Queensland senators in particular to oppose this Bill. Mr Hinze is the man who has said he will take over the premiership from Mr Bjelke-Petersen in a very short time. No doubt he has had consultations with his leader, who in turn would have had consultations with his wife and impressed upon her the need to oppose this legislation. I hate to think what might happen if Senator Bjelke-Petersen does not cross the floor tonight to oppose this legislation, when she goes back to Kingaroy on Saturday morning. We may not see her back here next week. A report in the Courier-Mail of 24 May about Mr Hinze reads:

SPEECH.PARA: 'As Main Roads and Local Government Minister for this State, I will not allow local authorities to be thrown to Canberra's bureaucratic wolves' he said.
Mr Hinze said there had not been enough consultation with the States on the legislation, and all States were strongly opposed to the Federal Government's attitude.

They are Mr Hinze's words. Yet Senator Baume, in one part of his second reading speech, said that there have been consultations. Then he said that when the legislation has been passed he will sit down and have the consultations. So we do not know who to believe. I think this would be one of the very few occasions when I would be prepared to believe what Mr Hinze said. There was quite a big article in the Courier-Mail of 21 May. The headline was: 'Hinze calls up jobs aid'. The dateline is Longreach and the article states, in part:
The Main Roads Minister, Mr Hinze, has mustered nation-wide support against Federal Government legislation which threatens thousands of jobs including 400 in Queensland.
In a telephone hook-up with Labor and non-Labor Ministers in all States, he gained their support to fight the legislation.

The proof of the pudding will be here tonight when we see how many honourable senators who belong to his party are prepared to stand behind him and to fight this legislation. The shadow Minister in South Australia, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Jack Wright, was quoted in the Adelaide News of Thursday, 21 May. The headline to the article was: 'Wright calls for road push'. The article states, in part:
The transport Minister, Mr Wilson, was called on today for assurance that the Stuart Highway would be completed on time.

I am surprised that the only South Australian senator in the chamber tonight to speak against this legislation is Senator Messner. Senator Jessop has been a great advocate of road works in South Australia. The Stuart Highway has been debated in here on many occasions, but Senator Jessop is not here tonight to put a case for the Stuart Highway. The article continued:
'At the last election, the Tonkin Government made a firm pledge that the Stuart Highway would be sealed within five years,' the Acting opposition Leader, Mr Wright, said.
'The Tonkin election policy also said if elected a State Liberal Government would immedately confer with the Federal Government to have the sealing of the highway declared a 'special project.'
'Unfortunately Mr Wilson's Federal connections have not come good over road funding. And next year's allocation to South Australia represents a decrease in real terms . . .

I will prove that with some figures that were sent to me by telex today and by the figures cited in the Adelaide Advertiser by Mr Wilson, the South Australian Liberal Transport Minister. The article continued:
Mr Wright accused Mr Wilson of refusing to 'stand up' to his Liberal counterpart in Canberra.
I take it that Mr Wilson has many friends from South Australia who will refuse tonight to stand up to their counterparts and to the Minsiter here. The article continued:
Mr Wilson said the project was running on schedule and was expected to be completed by 1986.

Yet he said during the election campaign that it would be completed in five year's time-by 1984. So he is already two years behind schedule but he says it is running on schedule. We cannot believe a word that these Liberal or Country Party Ministers say. I will now quote the words of Mr Wilson, the South Australian Minister. They are reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of Saturday, 30 May, which is only a few days ago. The article is headed: 'Grants to SA down: Wilson'. the article stated:
SA was disadvantaged in its road grants allocation, the Minister for Transport, Mr Wilson, said yesterday.
SA had received 8.2 p.c. of this year's national allocation, a slow decrease from 11.1 p.c. in 1968-69.
SA had 9.7 p.c. of Australia's vehicles, 16 p.c. of national roads, 12.2 p.c. of the length of all roads, 15.5 p.c. of the area and 9.3 p.c. of the population.
Through kilometres travelled, South Australians were contributing 9.7 p.c. of fuel taxes, which was the main revenue earner for road grants.
''We are at least entitled to that percentage of the allocation which would increase our present share by $10.1m.,'' Mr Wilson said.
''It is money SA is in need of and deserves.
''A fairer allocation to all States may involve the Federal Government realising that more money should be spent on roads.

Today I received a telex from Mr Ross Williams, who is the President of the Royal Automobile Association of South Australia. In the telex he repeats some of the figures cited by Mr Wilson. The telex is addressed to Senator McLaren. It reads:

Association Council urge you protest South Australia's declining share of road grants in 1981 Bill which now provides all time low of 8.2 per cent of Australian national sum for State having 9.3 per cent of population 9.7 per cent of vehicles and 12.2 per cent of roads.

The telex is signed by Ross Williams, President of the Royal Automobile Association of South Australia. No doubt Government senators, like my colleagues, got one of these telexes. Are Government senators going to stand up for the organisations in South Australia? Are they going to stand up for the plea made by Mr Wilson, a member of their own party. I can see Senator Missen shaking his head. They are not going to do it. I do not know what he is going to do in relation to Victoria. No doubt, no plea has come from Victoria on this matter. They are in such disarray there. They have just pitchforked the Premier and there is a new Premier to be installed, I think, on Friday. Apparently they are in such a disarray in Victoria that there will be no plea from there. Let us look at what Mr Wran said yesterday. Those honourable senators who were fortunate enough to see him interviewed on television last night would have heard what he had to say. He spoke about what will happen. The article reads:
Mr Wran said every local government area in NSW would suffer from the cutbacks in federal funds to the States.

My colleague Senator Gietzelt, in his speech in the debate on the motion for the second reading, referred to some of the areas and towns in South Australia which will see numbers of people thrown out of work because of these cutbacks. Mr Wran is reported in the article as saying:
Seeing that tenders are let by the Department of Main Roads, presumably the department will have to submit tenders to itself.

That is the very point I made earlier. In the case of South Australia we will find a government advising its wealthy supporters that they ought to submit a certain type of tender. They will submit a higher tender because they want to run the whole public sector down. They are on record as doing that. Only about a month or six weeks ago 10,000 public servants demonstrated in Victoria Square in Adelaide against the threat to their jobs. There were 10,000 people present. It is pretty hard to get 10,000 people to a protest march in Adelaide. The only time I think as many people as that attended a rally was when the insurance companies were protesting against Senator Wheeldon's legislation. Of course, the insurance companies paid their employees to attend the rally. The people who attended this rally were not paid because they were not at work. Senator Jessop was the organiser. He admitted that in this chamber. As my colleague Senator Wheeldon said, Senator Jessop organised the rally and got the people there. He is one of the great supporters of private enterprise. I remind people that they ought to look at the cartoon which appeared in yesterday's Canberra Times showing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Lynch, the bagman, getting the bag full with all the donations from private enterprise friends. Mr Wran went on to say:
But apart from its essential inanity, this new Commonwealth legislation endangers the jobs of nearly 1,000 men in local government areas throughout NSW.

It will not be very long before we will be having a State election in New South Wales. The Liberals will get a rude awakening when they look at the figures which come out of the ballot box. The sooner we have an election in Victoria we will see a similar thing. The sooner we have an election in South Australia we will see a similar result again. Of course, then the Labor Party will be getting very close to having a majority on the Loan Council. As sure as the sun rises in the east the next time we have a Federal election the Labor Party will be in government in this place and the people of Australia will be able to get the things that they are entitled to have. I go back to the threat Mr Hinze has made. This is very important. It will have a big bearing on this legislation even if it is passed. The article states:
Mr Hinze, who was told on Monday by State Cabinet to mount a case against Canberra, said he might enlist the support of the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

He has been told that by State Cabinet. As I said in this place earlier, State Cabinet is presided over by one Joh Bjelke-Petersen whose wife sits in this place as a senator. I hate to think what measures will be dealt out to her when she goes to Kingaroy on Saturday if she supports this legislation. In relation to Mr Hinze the article went on to state:
As a senior minister on that body, he was prepared to call an extraordinary meeting from which the Federal Government would be excluded to fight Canberra.

The real old Queenslanders will do the same thing again-fight Canberra. We will see. Queenslanders have the opportunity now to see whether Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who has her first opportunity in voting on this matter, will stand up and fight Canberra as her husband has over the years, even when we were in government. Irrespective of what we were doing for the State Queensland had to down Canberra. We will see. I am sure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen just cannot afford not to take notice of the call sent forth by Mr Hinze and the decision taken in the State Cabinet that this legislation has to be defeated. The hour is getting late. I could say a lot more on behalf of my State of South Australia but I might leave those remarks to the Committee stage. I support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Gietzelt, to the motion for the second reading. I will be giving full support to the amendments we will be moving in the Committee stages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this Roads Grants Bill 1981 because I am vitally interested in the matter before us, that is, funding of roads. I do not think there would be one honourable senator in this chamber who has worked for the Main Roads Department for 14 years, as I did before I was married. I was secretary to the Main Roads Commissioner in Queensland for three years so I really feel that funding of roads is a subject about which I am fairly knowledgeable. Of course, as the wife of the Premier of Queensland-I draw Senator McLaren's attention to the fact that my husband is Premier of the great State of Queensland; I realise that New South Wales does need a new Premier and I think my husband would do a very good job for New South Wales-I have travelled that State from north to south and east to west during the past 10 or 11 years. I can speak from my experience about the huge road network we have in Queensland and the need there is for good roads between our many decentralised cities and country towns.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland actually is the most decentralised State in the Commonwealth. We have nine towns with populations of over 30,000 people. We have vast mining areas and more towns are being developed each year. Needless to say, in the far outback there is a need for good roads. In fact, I venture to say that some of the people who live in the far outback might wonder what bitumen really is. Because of all this I draw the attention of the Senate to a very real and disturbing problem that is affecting all of Queensland and all Queenslanders-that is the problem of inadequate funding for road maintenance and construction. In fact, the lack of adequate road funding is the biggest single difficulty facing the local authorities in Queensland at present. The Queensland road network covers some 192,000 kilometres, including 40,200 kilometres of declared roads which are the direct responsibility of the Main Roads Department. Local authorities throughout Queensland are experiencing extreme difficulties in maintaining and financing road projects because, I am sorry to say, of the Federal Government's belt-tightening.

As I said in my maiden speech, last year Queensland motorists paid the Commonwealth Government approximately $667m in fuel taxes. Yet in our State they were returned only $117m in the form of road funding. When one considers the vast area of Queensland, one realises that the situation is unfair both to Queensland and Queenslanders. Queensland also has a high population growth. I am sure that when the result of the census which is to be taken at the end of this month is released, honourable senators will see that Victoria has lost population and that New South Wales is finding it hard to keep its numbers up. One thing I am quite sure of is that honourable senators will find that Queensland is experiencing a great population growth. Fifty thousand people are coming to Queensland every year, mostly from the southern States.

Vehicle registrations are on the increase in Queensland. In the past 10 years, vehicle registrations have risen from 700,000 to 1,600,000. That proves that many more vehicles are using the roads in our State. It is obvious, I am sorry to say, that the Federal Government does not consider road funding to be of major importance to Australia and to Queensland in particular. In 1977-78 road funding in Australia accounted for less than one and a half per cent of the Federal Government's total Budget outlay as opposed to 3 per cent in 1972-73. If my arithmetic is correct-I hope it is-that means that funding has fallen by half. In terms of the Government's priorities, road funding rates very low which, for a country the size of Australia and, in particular, a State of Queensland's dimensions, is absolutely ludicrous. As well as the oil levy, Queensland is contributing hundreds of millions of dollars to the Federal Government in tax and other revenue. The Federal Government must realise that it has a responsibility to return some of this money to the State by way of additional road funding.

The Commonwealth Bureau of Transport Economics' predecessor, the Bureau of Roads, stated in its final report that Queensland should have received $228m in road funds in 1979-80. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that Queensland received only approximately $117m. Queensland has fared very badly in regard to road funding allocations compared with other States. I draw the Senate's attention to the assessment of the road system in a report of the Bureau of Transport Economics. It stated in its analysis of results that:
Expenditure in Queensland was two-thirds of the efficient allocation with under-allocations in all categories other than rural local roads.

Expenditure on national highways in Queensland was only one-third of the efficient allocation for this category. Expenditure on rural arterials in Queensland was half the efficient allocation, the largest mis-allocation of expenditure of all the Australian States. The report also states that for rural local roads expenditure in all States was above the efficient allocation, except in Queensland, I add, where it was the lowest. I am very sorry about that. I feel that Queensland has not done as it could. In terms of actual comparisons between an economically efficient allocation of road expenditure and what actually occurred in the five years from 1974-75 to 1978-79, Queensland experienced an under-expenditure on national highways, rural arterials and urban arterials. That is most unfair and I am sure that most honourable senators would agree with me.
