The problem is that this unfair treatment of Queensland last year is unfortunately being repeated in this year's allocation. How can we, as senators from Queensland, travel around our State and tell the people that we are not getting enough money for roads? How can we tell them, in fact, that Queensland is not even getting its fair share of the allocation for roads? I refer to a statement made by the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, in answer to a question from Mr Charles Jones. He said:

There is no doubt that some States are not getting a fair deal under the existing allocation of funds from the Commonwealth resources. Certainly, Queensland is doing badly under the existing arrangements.

I think the Minister should be in a position to know. It is absolutely essential that when the next 2-year plan for roads comes up, the Commonwealth Government does the fair and just thing in respect of Queensland. I sincerely hope that other transport Ministers around Australia will be fair and just enough to concede that this be done and support the effort that the Federal Transport Minister, Mr Hunt, is making to try to get a more equitable distribution of Commonwealth funds for the States for roads.

Queensland is an enourmous State with very large distances between towns, particularly in the country areas and the remote areas. With air services so infrequent and expensive, road transport is often the only means available for people to travel. The need for adequate road systems is probably more vital to a State such as Queensland than it is to the smaller States such as Tasmania and South Australia. They both received over-allocations in road funding, according to the Bureau of Transport Economics report. It was only last week that the State Government in Queensland announced that passenger vehicles registration fees would be increased by 60 per cent from mid-August to try to provide the Government with more funds for these all-important road works. This is an enormous increase and it will greatly affect the average income earner. It probably will result in a rise in the number of unregistered vehicles on Queensland roads. Why has the Queensland Government had to do this? It has had to do it simply because of the Federal Government's cutbacks. The State Government is not prepared to allow Queensland roads to suffer at the hands of Canberra. This appears to be the only way that the Government can make up the shortfall.

There is also the vexed question of the proposed legislation for the funding of national highways in Queensland. The Commonwealth plans to contract out highway construction. I listened to Senator McLaren giving quite a long speech on that subject. He kept talking about the Honourable Russell Hinze but he kept pronouncing it with the long vowel. The correct pronunciation is with the short vowel. He must have been thinking about the baked beans man.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the difference, Senator?
—There is quite a deal of difference, I would say. Mr Hinze is our Minister for Roads.
—In South Australia they pronounce it with the long 'i'.

—If Senator McLaren would really like to know, it is pronounced with the short 'i'. Mr Hinze sent a letter to the Federal Transport Minister requesting that the Commonwealth change its approach to the following: He wanted a recognition that in the efficient overall management of the national roads construction program, both day labour and contract methods of construction have a role to play. He also requested that any requirement for a major shift to contract work should allow a basic day labour presence and provide three years for practical implementation, at the same time avoiding major retrenchments. He also requested that any requirements of this nature should not be embodied in legislation but should be arranged in consultation with each State taking account of local efforts. I feel it is wrong, that it is an absolute must that the States should have a contract system for the national highways. Nevertheless, I will not be voting against the legislation. I am just telling honourable senators exactly what I feel about these things.
—Go the whole way, Senator.
—I do not think I will take Senator Georges' advice. Additionally, Mr Hinze stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth claims to totally funding the national roads in Queensland is not entirely correct. Over the past three financial years the State has spent $2.3m of its own funds on national roads and has programmed a further $2m this financial year. This has been necessary in order to achieve its target for completion of the Marlborough-Sarina section of the Bruce highway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not before time.

—I think that they are doing very well up there. I can remember in the early days when I went on the back road between Marlborough and Sarina when the Australian Labor Party was in power in Queensland. It was the most awful road one could ever travel on in one's life.
—How long ago was that?

—I can assure Senator Georges that I am not as old as he thinks. When I was travelling with the Commissioner for Main Roads on the roads in Queensland, the Labor Government was in power in that State. The tremendous improvement that we have had in roads is fantastic. All I can say is that, if members of the Australian Labor Party vote against this Bill tonight, which they say they will, the Government might end up saying that it will not provide any money at all for roads. That would serve members of the Labor Party right. Nevertheless, I feel quite sure that the Government will have the numbers to pass the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very sorry that some of the shire councils in Queensland have been rather disappointed about the fact that our Government has decided that all national highways should be built by contract. Representatives of the Barcaldine Shire Council in central western Queensland-for those honourable senators who do not live in Queensland, that is near Longreach-have told Mr Hinze that the Council could not afford to tender for these sorts of jobs. They said that a job that ran over the estimate could be a cost to ratepayers for years and that the only alternative will be to sack some men. I do not know whether the Council will have to go so far as that. I certainly hope that it does not. Local government associations in Queensland were also most upset about this decision. A letter was sent to me telling me the facts of the matter as far as all the local authorities throughout the State were concerned. It stated that they were quite disappointed at the fact that they would not have the right to choose whether to do their work by contract or by day labour. Last January, the Australian Automobile Association, in its submission to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on the need for increased road grants stated:
An adequate road system is vital to Australia's needs. . . . This situation is deteriorating annually relative to increased needs.
. . . Good roads are a vital link in our defence system.
This is a matter that I really feel our governments must take notice of. The Association further stated:
. . . Good roads are essential in encouraging tourist traffic.
. . . the consumer is paying for better roads but they are not being provided.
. . . Good roads are a national asset and it is the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to provide the necessary funds for essential road improvements.

Funding of road works by the Commonwealth Government serves two very important purposes. Firstly, it ensures the quality of the road network and, secondly, it guarantees employment for many Queenslanders involved in road construction and maintenance.

I was elected to the Senate to represent all Queenslanders and I would be remiss in my responsibilities if I did not strongly urge the Federal Goverment to give everybody in Queensland a fair go and to help to make sure that when the next lot of road funds is allocated Queensland will get its fair share. I make no bones about the fact that I deplore the way in which small rural communities in particular are being trodden on. The Federal Government must be careful that, in its efforts to balance the Budget, it does not lose sight of the basic needs. I believe that adequate road systems are a need and not a luxury for Australians generally and, in this instance, Queenslanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a vitally important area of concern-Australia's road system. It is near enough to one o'clock in the morning and the Government is forcing through by weight of numbers and the elapsing of time an important piece of legislation that should have been before the Senate months ago and thereby given the full attention that it really deserves. I would have thought that the task of this Parliament was to make reasoned, equitable and appropriate law. The Government has failed to ensure that this process can proceed by introducing a steady flow of legislation and providing adequate time for it to be debated. I would not have thought that this was too difficult a problem. Any private business that proceeded on the basis that this Parliament proceeds would have gone bankrupt long ago. To the extent that the Government fails to ensure that process, it is, of course, failing the Australian people. Additionally, it is manipulating unfairly the parliamentary process which, among other things, it was elected to preserve.

SPEECH.PARA: The Roads Grants Bill 1981, in the view of the Australian Democrats-as was the view of previous speakers-has nothing to commend it. Its main purpose, beneath the surface-not too far beneath the surface-seems to be to divest the Commonwealth Government of much of its responsibility for roads and to farm this out to the States and local government. We are getting the same picture that we have had previously-that is, that all is to be left to God and the States. I do not know what we in the Senate will be doing in the end. Presumably, we will sit, draw our salaries and play halma or something like that. If things go on in the way they are now, we will eventually be doing nothing at all in the Federal sphere. It would also seem that this Bill will insist that all grants for national road construction will be conditional upon the States calling public tenders for the works. The Australian Democrats ask whether this means the handling over of the more profitable road works to private enterprise. We also ask: Will private enterprise also dependably deal with the less profitable leavings?

I do not want to canvass at any length the familiar and obvious failings of the Government in its overall funding for roads. They have been dealt with to some extent by other honourable senators. I think this matter has yet to be seen generally by the Australian public as a national scandal. I think the message is slowly sinking through, judging from some of the contacts I have had, particularly from shire councils and various such bodies. I think it will have sunk in good and well before 1983. I doubt whether the lesson will be forgotten quickly. The basic fact is that, between 1955 and 1973, Commonwealth roads grants to the States averaged 2.73 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays. This figure has now fallen to 1.74 per cent. This, I think, speaks for itself as an indictment of the Government. I think it also speaks eloquently of the sincerity of honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who have lauded this legislation and have somehow tried to convey the impression that a good deal is being done by this Government for Australian roads.

The short-sighted nature of the Government's approach in this, as in several other areas that have been identified in the Senate recently, is a kind of penny-pinching, a short term penny-pinching, which I think will have catastrophic results in the long term. This is not confined, of course, merely to roads but applies also to health, education and social welfare. Indeed, the Australian nation is being put into low gear with a vengeance. Roads should be a major challenge to our nation at this time more than any other time. The whole question of transport in the future, its economy and its safety, becomes a matter of enormous importance to the nation. It is not just something that can be let slide. It is something that has to be coped with now. I think that good roads represent not only the lifelines of this country but also the lives of thousands of our citizens. I will quote some figures on that matter a little later.

The Australian Democrats recently received a letter from an embattled shire president saying that, at the present funding rate, it would take his shire 46 years to seal all existing main roads, without taking into account either maintenance costs or inflation. That is perhaps not quite typical but it is certainly representative of the deteriorating situation existing in far too many parts of Australia. Some points have been made to us by the Australian Automobile Association. I believe that these points have also been made to the Government, so the Government cannot pretend not to be aware of them. The Association has stated that realistic road expenditure by the Commonwealth would assist in many areas. It has said that congested roads in urban areas cause excessive fuel consumption in motor cars. This has been demonstrated over and over again. In fact, I think I saw it pointed out yet again as an important issue in the newspapers today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
—I anticipated the honourable senator drawing that fact to my attention. In order not to waste time, I have ascertained that a quorum is not present. Ring the bells. (Quorum formed).

—I was making the point that the Government's actions in this Bill are completely opposed not only by honourable senators on this side of the chamber, the States and the Shires but also by that very thoughtful and informed group, the Australian Automobile Association, which represents hundreds of thousands of Australian motorists who, I would imagine, also have votes. The association says, that realistic roads expenditure by the Commonwealth would assist in certain areas. Congested roads in urban areas cause excessive fuel consumption. Sixteen million barrels of crude oil could be saved each year by the provision of adequate roads in our cities. This is an essential and urgent task if we are to say, with any sense of conviction, that we will try to economise on fuel consumption. As the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) is in the chamber, I point out to him particularly that this could have implications for his portfolio. This is surely an area of concern for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Transport costs represent 25 per cent of the costs of goods and services in Australia. This is reflected in the congestion and delays which occur in and between cities. These costs will increase with fuel costs and will affect virtually all activities of the entire community to an increasingly serious extent. I think that the problem will become abundantly apparent to the bulk of the population and that the population will sheet it home, and I think properly so, to the degree of neglect which is perpetuated in this Bill. Better roads would save travel time alone, which is estimated to be worth $700m a year.

I turn to the question of road safety-the old cliche of our society, the great disease which we all prefer to ignore. Last year 3,500 people were killed and 90,000 were injured. There is evidence from all over the world that these figures could be substantially reduced by increasing the quality of roads. That is probably the most important factor, given that all other things are equal. Human nature will not change. We will have people who do not drive as carefully as they should. We will have people who drink and drive. We will have motor cars which break down. One factor that the Government can materially influence is the quality of the roads. In this way we could make a major contribution towards alleviating one of the great tragedies of modern society-the appalling rate of road deaths every year. I know that this point has been made but I make it again: If a disease which caused deaths and injuries of those proportions occurred in our society we would do something about it very quickly, I imagine. It is equally sensible and rational that we should be doing something about it at this time. The cost of smash repairs on cars is estimated by the Association at approximately $1,000m a year. That is largely unnecessary expenditure. So this question of roads is revealed as being of tremendous importance to this society.

I turn briefly to the Government's decision to insist on public tendering by the States for all national road construction. The Australian Democrats see this as a major blunder. The States have had decades of experience in determining the correct mix of contract work and day labour. All of the States are opposed to this move of the Government. We are a federal system and we hear great talk about the new federalism. The new federalism seems to me to be a situation in which the States are regarded as lackeys and subservient. They are to do more of the work but they will be pushed around more by the centralist federal system of Canberra, administered by Mr Malcolm Fraser and his cohorts whom we see on the other side of the Parliament. That is what the new federalism really means. I think it is about time that the States woke up to it. They hear talk that they will be given more powers. That is nonsense. They will not be given more powers. They will be given more work to do and more responsibilities but, as we see in this Bill, the whip will be cracked from Canberra.

Great disruption will be caused to road works. There will be an increase in red tape and I think a great number of retrenchments will take place in local work forces. This will dislocate even more the already fragile economies of some of our country towns and areas. A good example is the plight of the Tasmanian Department of Main Roads. We are given to understand that if the Government's proposals are accepted in this Bill some 470 of the 1,140 men employed by the DMR in Tasmania as a labour field force stand to lose their jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can see that is nonsense.

—No, I cannot. I will tell the honourable senator why. Very few private road contractors in Tasmania have the capacity to construct national roads. Where will we get them from? Obviously the mainland companies will get the work there and that will lead inevitably to a loss of jobs by Tasmanians.
—Why not the DMR?
—The Australian Democrats suggest-
—You cannot tell me.
—The point is not worth taking up.

—That is right, it is not worth taking up. The Australian Democrats suggest and recommend a readjustment now of the Commonwealth's spending pattern so that road funding returns to its traditional figure of about 2.5 per cent, which is low enough. Experience has shown, and the Government should be aware of that experience, that this will permit us barely to keep abreast of our needs to say nothing of making any progress in this important field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment that has been moved to the Roads Grants Bill 1981. The amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(1) The Bill fails to provide adequate funds to the States and the Northren Territory for desirable road construction and maintenance;

(2) the abolition of the discretionary power of the States to determine which national road works should be offered to private contractors by public tender is contrary to the national interest and will create disruption and dislocation of State road authorities, leading to inefficiency, waste, inflexibility and the loss of employment;

(3) the amalgamation of the former categories of Urban Arterial roads and Rural Arterial roads into a single category of Arterial roads will lead to an inequitable distribution of road funds between urban and rural areas; and
(4) the Government has again failed to use an expanded road construction and maintenance program to provide safer roads and more jobs'.

I support that proposition. I wish to point out that there are two main considerations for honourable senators to take into account when determining their attitude to this Bill. One is the overall commitment by the Commonwealth Government to road construction and maintenance within Australia. The second point is the strings that have been attached to those moneys by the Federal Government without the consent of the States. As to the first point, I, together with a number of other honourable senators, have received representations from local government on that particular issue. It has been canvassed substantially in the debate and I do not wish at this late hour of a quarter past one in the morning to delay the Senate in respect of that matter. Suffice it to say, that if, in the operation of this legislation, local government is seen to have been sold out, the Government can expect a very vigorous reaction from the grass roots of government within Australia, namely, local government.

It has been said by Senator Gietzelt who moved the amendment to the Bill for the Opposition that the legislation is anti decentralisation. I concur with that statement. Let me then deal with the ties that have been placed on this piece of legislation by the Federal Government. I refer in particular to the demand incorporated in this Bill for arterial roads to be placed to tender and, in fact, for the State governments to explain why the lowest tenderer does not get the job. As a previous Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, I have had quite considerable experience regarding the welfare of Department of Main Roads workers in my State. In fact, I led a deputation to one of the best governments that Tasmania has ever had-the Bethune Government-in respect of this matter. Subsequent to our struggle for a service and incremental payments scheme for the Department of Main Roads workers, we met the Bethune Government and it gave its recognition of the work that is performed by the day labour force of the Department of Main Roads in our State.

I was accompanied to that meeting by a stalwart of the trade union movement in my State who was a representative of the Amalgamated Engineering Union at that time on the TTLC, Mr Glyn Watkins. He and other union officials obtained an assurance as to the level of the use of day labour force in road construction. I remind the Senate that it was a Liberal Government in my State of Tasmania at the time. We now have a Commonwealth Government seeking to impose its will upon the various States in respect of this very important matter. I am also aware of the work that is done by the Department of Main Roads personnel through my contact with the Transport Workers Union and, in particular, Jim Foley who is a DMR representative of the Transport Workers Union and also Wayne Binns who is a representative of the Australasian Society of Engineers in the Department of Main Roads.

I cannot put the case better than it was put by the Department of Main Roads employees in Launceston in a letter addressed 'to: All Tasmanian Members of Parliament-Federal and State', which was received by me only on Monday of this week. That letter reads as follows:

At a lunch time meeting held today 25/05/81 at the Department of Main Roads Workshops, Launceston, of D.M.R. employees from all districts together with Federal and State members of Parliament, it was unanimously resolved that an urgent appeal be made to all our Federal politicians to endeavour to have Tasmania exempted from the requirement that all National Highways be constructed by the medium of public tender.

It should be noted that the D.M.R. provides stable and permanent employment for a day labour field force of 1140 employees not including several hundred administrative and professional personnel. This arrangement has been established and well proven in excess of 40 years.

If the D.M.R. were not successful in securing an EARLY contract made available under the tender system (to be adopted) it would lead to the immediate retrenchment of approximately 260 permanent employees and the subsequent disposal of all surplus plant.
Furthermore we are concerned that there will be a further reduction of equipment and man power if funds for arterial roads are issued under the same tender conditions, as the National Highways.

It must be recognised that the D.M.R. cannot compete or tender against private contractors for any work other than Specified Government Works where as the private sector has an unlimited opportunity to tender for all works on the open market. A resulting wind down of the D.M.R. resources by approximately 25 per cent would reduce the capacity of the Department to a stage where future major tenders would be impossible.
Because of the limited capacity of local contract firms, most major contracts would be undertaken by mainland based sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that is rubbish, don't you.
—I completely reject the interjections relating to the matter being rubbish. It is not rubbish. I will refer to the matter of contracts in a moment. The letter goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The results would be that these companies would utilize their own plant and workforce in preference to engaging state employees displaced by their successful tender. Any work available with these firms would be casual or short term only.

A detrimental result of the demise of this Department would be the severe effect on a number of de-centralized communities which are heavily dependant on the Department's present system of operations for their economic stability.

For example, the D.M.R. operations at Ulverstone, the second major industry in that district relies almost entirely on the continuation of the current National Highway Scheme. Closure of this depot would have a marked effect on the employment and business section of the community.

In addition concern is expressed for the loss of apprenticeships. The present D.M.R. workshops training system permits a large annual intagke of apprentices. As there is an already intolerable National shortage of skilled tradesmen in Australia we feel that every opportunity should be taken to preserve the current training programme that exists in the D.M.R. Contract arrangements can only lead to a decline in this critical area.
In conclusion we hope to have demonstrated that the D.M.R. workforce can only be retained at its present manpower level by retention of the current grants system.

We therefore respectfully request that all our Federal representatives give us their unqualified support by vigourously opposing this legislation in its present form which will adversely effect a large number of Tasmanians.
Yours faithfully, (Representatives Department of Main Roads)

I agree entirely with that letter. Furthermore, I point out that the legislation does not protect the employment of young people coming through the system, not only as apprentices but also as workers in the design area. If this Bill is passed and the requirements are insisted upon, who is to do the designing? Is there any guarantee that the Commonwealth Government will support a State Minister who insists that the design work is done by Tasmanians or, so far as other States are concerned, by employees in those States, and that the contracting company employs a certain number of apprentices? These are two of the very basic considerations which should exercise the minds of honourable senators when they make their decision on this matter.

As I understand it, no guarantee whatsoever is given by the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, on these two aspects. In addition, what is to happen to the expertise in the Department of Main Roads? Will there not be delays in respect of the building of roads by reason of the fact that all of the design work shall have been done or shall need to have been done before the tender documents are finalised. Is that not what is inherent in what the Goverment is putting to us now? If it is inherent in what the Government is putting to us now, there will be considerable delays in road construction works because at present the Department of Main Roads designs as it goes along. Under the new arrangement all of that will presumably be required to be done before the tender documents are finalised. In that event one will have a situation in which road construction is delayed for up to three or four years.

The effect of this Bill will be to cut out the subcontractors to the Department of Main Roads. I am advised that one of the effects of this piece of legislation will be to tend to cut out the small subcontractors currently engaged by the Department of Main Roads. A considerable number of owner-operators are in that situation. I fear for the livelihood of not only those people but also those workers who have served the community of Tasmania so well over many years in very difficult circumstances and in extreme conditions in the highlands and in various other parts of Tasmania. I regard this Bill as contrary to the principles of a fair go. I regard the statement by the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, in answer to my question on 27 August 1980 that the policy of the Government is somehow related to market forces prevailing, as being neither consistent with the other policy of the Government that there should be a degree of decentralisation nor with the Government's policy on federalism. In the Committee stage I will support an amendment to be moved which states:
Page 12, clause 24, sub-clause (1), paragraph (a), lines 32 to 38, leave out the paragraph, inset the following paragraph:

'(A) that, where moneys paid to the State in accordance with the grant are required by virtue of this Act to be expended on the carrying out of an approved project by way of the construciton of a national road, the State, in its discretion, may invite, and deal with, tenders for those works;'
I believe that, as a States House, the Senate must uphold the rights of the States and vote for the proposed amendment to be moved at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to the debate which has taken place. It appears that there is objection to the provisions of part of this Bill by some representatives of Tasmania but, as far as I can gather, by nobody else. It may be that somebody else has responded to those who would like to see everything conducted by government in other States, but it strikes me as passing curious that the wad of telegrams which I have received have all been from Tasmania. The representations in relation to the objections have been--
—You are a trainee, Senator.

—Thank you. Normally, when something is a matter of national importance, one receives some representations or hears of them coming a little more broadly than from one socialist government. I think it is significant that all of the telegrams appear to come from the socialist government of Tasmania and its representatives and employees. The objection is that, if the work is done by some degree of private enterprise, it will be less efficient and effective and more costly to the jobs in Tasmania which, I would have thought, will be contrary to the principle which has been established in this country in the last three elections. The people of this country have said that one of the things that they expect and want is a more efficient way of spending their dollars and getting more miles of road for their tax. They expect to get more effect from what is undertaken by way of national development using taxpayers' funds. What the Government has done and what I totally support relates to the suggestion that history shows-a study undertaken within the past two years demonstrates this clearly-that using the private tender basis, including the opportunity for government agencies to tender, is likely to produce more quickly more miles of road for the taxpayers out of their dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine has said, and said well, the socialist case, that is, that it is better to have the work done by government. He said that we must protect the jobs of the government employees. He quoted parts of a resolution of a meeting of workers of the Department of Main Roads. I received a letter some weeks ago from the secretary in Tasmania of the Australian Workers Union and I responded to it and asked certain questions seeking amplification. I then put the matter to one of the representatives of the major companies which may be a tenderer and asked him to comment on the assertions which had been made and which have been repeated in the resolutions to which Senator Harradine has referred. Having considered those, I came to the conclusion that the protection of Tasmanian jobs, the development of Tasmanian roads and the number of miles of made roads that Tasmanian citizens will be able to drive over will all be enhanced by the implementation of the principle which is inherent in the Bill. I do not think it is desirable to go into every aspect. I guess it is a matter of a basic difference of philosophy. Some believe that the way to achieve is to have government do it all, that government should use day labour and use its own planning systems and organise that which is to be done on behalf of the people. There are others who say--

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not happen now in Tasmania. A lot of work, about 50 per cent, is done by contractors.

—The interjection, as I understand it, is that a significant percentage of work-50 per cent-is done by private contract. One wonders at the reason for this organised objection. I do not propose to seek to incorporate all the telegrams. I indicate to honourable senators that I have a number of telegrams together with details of the meeting of Department of Main Roads workers and of the concern which has been generated amongst them. Yet, as a result of the representations put to me by the Australian Workers Union-one included the observation that if we were not careful we would import people who were associated with the Builders Labourers Federation and other more militant unions in Victoria and introduce to Tasmania industrial disputes which have not existed before-I checked as best I could for other views that have been put. I believe in the general principle that work can be done more efficiently by tender, and government can tender through the Department of Main Roads. In that way at least we will know how many miles of road we are getting for how many dollars. This is better than working on a basis of cutting out a particular allocation in a year. This has tended to lead, it appears, to the criticism of the way in which main road construction in Tasmania has been undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not criticise the individual employees or the unions. I think we have been particularly strike free and particularly fortunate, but I cannot see that a change to the system will bring about all of the evils to which Senator Harradine and others have referred to as being necessarily attendant to the change of the system. Of course those who tender for contracts will employ Tasmanians. They are not likely to be able to import a whole lot of people with work experience. They are not likely to find new truck operators and bring them across. The whole history is that, wherever jobs have been let out to tender in Tasmania, some 90 per cent plus of local contractors, including local staff and labour, have been engaged. I find it very difficult to reason why, other than an adherence to the socialist principle, Senator Harradine, the Australian Workers Union, the State Government and a number of individual employees are so concerned about putting the matter to the test to see whether it would not be better for the people of Tasmania-

TALK.START.PARA: —Their jobs are at risk.

—There is no job risk. There is no way that suddenly a huge number of people will move across Bass Strait to take up jobs. If the job risk is a reality, I would like someone to point out to me that this has ever happened. No one has explained or demonstrated this to me by way of correspondence or in discussions I have had. From where have Roche Bros Pty Ltd or the Dillingham organisation, two of the big companies which have taken on large contracts in Tasmania, drawn their work force in relation to contracts on behalf of government? All of their labour, except a few key management people, have been Tasmanian residents for a long time. I do not accept that this legislation will affect in any adverse way employment in Tasmania. I believe the result will be that Tasmanian citizens will get a little more for their dollar.
—How many apprentices did Bechtel Pacific employ in Tasmania?

—I do not know the answer to that. I know the answer in relation to some other companies. A considerable number of apprentices have been employed by some of the major contractors for road works. If Senator Harradine would like to debate that matter perhaps as a side issue we could do so at another time. I will not hold up the Senate at the moment. Having studied the matters raised and having been concerned about them, I am satisfied that what is proposed in the Bill is in the interest of getting the best for the taxpayers' dollar in Tasmania, as well as the best for Tasmanian employees and employment. Therefore, I propose to support the measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I proposed to speak at the Committee stage only but my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Rae, has provoked me to rise now. It seemed to me--
—I had not spoken when you put your name down.

—I put my name down as soon as I heard what the honourable member had to say. It seemed to me that the first reason Senator Rae gave in justification of his argument tonight was that the only objection to this legislation, and in particular to that provision which requires tendering, came from the State of Tasmania. I realise that the good senator does not often read newspapers or watch television. If he did he would find that the State of Queensland objects to this legislation also. I am in the extraordinary position of supporting Mr Hinze, the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, who objects violently to this legislation. If objecting to it is an indication that one is a socialist and represents a socialist government, in Senator Rae's definition of the term, we have the extraordinary situation of his claiming that Mr Hinze is a socialist and represents a socialist government. I will admit that one may say that he represents a national socialist government. It is extraordinary that Senator Rae, just because the only telegrams that he, as a Tasmanian senator, has received have been from Tasmania, should denigrate them and say that they are worthless. If Senator Rae had attended in Launceston on Monday of last week a meeting of the employees of the Department of Main Roads he would have known that their concern was genuine. They were not the only people who were labouring on the roads. They included engineers and others, but Senator Rae says that because the only telegrams he received were from Tasmania we must disregard them. The honourable senator did not receive any telegrams from Queensland because the people of that State know that he is a Tasmanian senator, but the Government of Queensland objects strongly to the provisions of this legislation. Senator Rae knows that.
—Have you a telegram from Queensland?
—I have seen the reports in the Press.
—Have you a telegram from Queensland?
—I have received telegrams from Tasmania and I take them seriously because I am from that State.
—I take them seriously also.

—The honourable senator does not take them seriously merely because he did not receive any from any other State. I am appalled that he should so write down the representations of his own constituents. I have heard him claim in this place that such representations meant something because they came from Tasmania but tonight he has denigrated such communications merely because they came from that State. The concern of our colleagues in Tasmania is a genuine one and the honourable senator knows why that is so.
—Will you table Mr Hinze's letter?
—Order! Senator Rae, you have had your opportunity to speak.

—Senator Rae is embarrassed and upset because he has denigrated representations made to him because they have come from his own State only. I cannot help that. The hour is late. The concern of our colleagues in Tasmania is simply this--
—I love the new unity ticket, the Harradine-Grimes ticket. It is impressive.

—I have no worry about supporting Senator Harradine on this matter. We are supporting the same people, people whom we claim to represent and whom Senator Rae denigrates. The simple fact is that our colleagues from the Tasmanian Department of Main Roads and other government employees also, are concerned because for years they have constructed the roads in that State. They have not done so just with government labour. In fact, the national roads of Tasmania have been constructed on a 50-50 basis by both government employees and private contractors. In Tasmania the Department of Main Roads has always contracted out labour to private industry and built roads itself. I do not think Senator Rae, in his high speed travelling over our roads in Tasmania which is known to all of us, really thinks our roads are so bad and so poorly constructed. The concern of the workers in Tasmania is that when we are forced to contract out in this way the contracts that the large mainland firms will be interested in are the easy ones and the contracts left to the Department of Main Roads will be those that Senator Harradine talked about-for the roads through the mountains and areas where there is snow or inclement weather, and where there is difficult construction. They suspect that the cream of the contracts will be taken off by the mainland contractors who may provide some local employees with jobs but whose engineers and other people with expertise and whose equipment and planning will come from Melbourne or Sydney. That is something about which Senator Rae has always complained in this place because every time that happens so many dollars from those contracts go out of our State. Every dollar that goes out of the State, whether through unemployment problems or something else, sets back our economy that much. That is what our employees are worried about. As Senator Harradine asked, how many of those mainland employers employ Tasmanian apprentices in all those occupations, such as fitting and turning, which are associated with road construction? They employ none. That is another problem about which the employees of the Department of Main Roads are worried. The Opposition's amendment asks only that we leave the discretion in the peculiar and particular situation which applies in Tasmania to the State Government. All the Queensland Government asks is that that situation apply to it.
—Is that peculiar also to Queensland?

—Apparently that is the belief of the Queensland Government. I have no brief from the Queensland Government but it was Senator Rae who said here that the only people complaining are the Tasmanians. That is not so. The people from that other decentralised State are also complaining. I think that should be on the record, and I think Senator Rae knew that when he made his speech but he deliberately did not want to mention it. Senator Rae said that the roads built by private companies, by private tender, in Tasmania were better and were built more efficiently. I ask Senator Rae to drive down the southern outlet road in Hobart. Two private firms won tenders for that road; both went broke and both had to be taken over by the State Government. We have the problem that so often we do not understand or know the viability of firms. Senator Rae's colleagues in the Tasmanian Parliament produced a statement saying that the tender system does not matter, that the State Government does not have to accept the lowest tender but can accept the highest tender and therefore look after its own. As Senator Rae knows, that is nonsense. I am glad he did not use that argument tonight. I bring up that argument because his colleagues-Mr Goodluck, Mr Groom and Mr Burr-have produced it in another place. In fact, if the Tasmanian Goverment does not accept the lowest tender it will have to make up the difference in the cost of that road.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for all these reasons that I raise this matter. We have an efficient road building organisation in the Department of Main Roads. It has an efficient system of planning those roads as it has done it for so long. The Department is experienced in building those roads in sometimes difficult terrain. Mainland firms that come in do not train the apprentices in Tasmania that we need to train. We have had experience of mainland firms that have come in and gone broke. We believe that the best people to organise the construction of roads in Tasmania and to organise the balance between public and private construction are in fact the people who have been building the roads in Tasmania for so long- in other words, the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian road authorities. That is why the Opposition has moved its amendment. That is why Mr Burr in another place expressed such concern. That is why there were huge meetings of workers from the Department of Main Roads and of members of the Australian Workers Union and other workers in Launceston, on two occasions, and in Hobart; and tomorrow there will be another meeting in Ulverstone. Nothing that Senator Rae said here tonight will ease that concern. Senator Rae is right-it is a philosophical difference. Senator Rae somehow believes that by opening up road construction in Tasmania to firms from Melbourne, Sydney and elsewhere--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Tasmania.

—There are no firms big enough for the sort of construction the honourable senator is talking about. Senator Rae believes that such firms should be allowed to cream off the easy contracts, without training any apprentices, and to take the profits of their enterprise out of the State to other States. Senator Rae believes that the Tasmanian firms which at the moment subcontract to the Department of Main Roads so efficiently and in co-operation with public enterprise in Tasmania cannot do the work. In saying that he denigrated anything that Senator Harradine and I said as socialist-a strange expression to use when we consider that 50 per cent of the construction in Tasmania is done by private firms. Because he believes all that and because he believes in the strange market force philosophy which I do not really think he understands, he is opposing our amendment. He has to go back to Tasmania and justify that opposition. He certainly will not justify it by the speech he made here tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate tonight which has been far more wide-ranging than was anticipated in the first place. Nevertheless, it seems the points made by honourable senators touched really on three main areas. The first area was tendering, which the last three speakers referred to. The second area related to the adequacy of funds.
—It was the difference between the socialist approach and otherwise.

—Quite right, Senator Rae. The third area was the national approach and the individual details of that, which Senator Bjelke-Petersen spent some time on. I will make some comments with regard to the tendering procedures. The Opposition sought to make the contributions of those honourable senators who supported the Government sound as though they represented a dogmatic philosophical approach on the part of the Government which denied all common sense and was a sell-out to private enterprise. As Senator Rae so ably pointed out, that is absolutely absurd. The principle that tendering is a way in which we can get better value for each dollar spent on roads and consequently more roads developed in each State represents a very real philosophical approach to getting better efficiencies out of the road funds available. The Government is determined that the maximum value should be obtained from the very substantial outlay in this legislation-some $685m-in respect of national roads. The only way this can be achieved is by the creation of a competitive environment in which the relative efficiency of contractors and day labour can be determined on a project by project basis. The Opposition has sought to make the point that the States are not really in support of this. Certainly that is not true of all States. I mention the State of South Australia where the Minister, Mr Wilson, made the point on 4 July 1980 that he clearly supports works on national highways being put to tender, but he said that there should be a three-year strategy for applying that policy. South Australia is prepared to apply that policy, and it is certainly approaching things from that point of view in other aspects of government.

SPEECH.PARA: If one considers the realities of the issue one finds that across the board in all States roughly 10 per cent of total expenditure on roads is going to national construction. Accordingly, we are talking about the calling of tenders, as required by this legislation, involving an average of 10 per cent of total expenditure. I think it is a rather unreal argument for the Opposition to be putting that this is somehow going to cause widespread unemployment in the State day labour force. It is also particularly relevant to note that the percentage in Tasmania, which is about 20 per cent of total expenditure, is a little higher than average. In conjunction with that, one must rememeber that it is always open to the States to tender in these situations and consequently there are not likely to be the kinds of movements which the Opposition and Senator Harradine fear.

With regard to the adequacy of funds, we are in the process of negotiating new formulas, and the States have agreed to this approach as part of the run-up to this legislation. We know that the States are supportive of this legislation, bearing in mind those negotiations. The formula approach which is being adopted is not aimed at interfering with any State responsibilities nor is it intended that it should cut across any existing arrangements the States may have for allocating funds to local government from their own resources. Rather, the aim of the formula approach is to provide local government authorities with a greater certainty of future Commonwealth funding levels on which to plan their road programs and to overcome past difficulties in identifying Commonwealth local roads funds provided to each council. The formula approach will simplify administrative arrangements. States will no longer have to submit annual programs to the Commonwealth for approval. Consequently, a feeling of freedom must be engendered amongst the States in this respect.

I mention one other aspect of the legislation, namely, the question of the contraction of the number of road categories from four to three. I think this matter was mentioned originally by Senator Gietzelt. The amalgamation of the former rural arterial roads and urban arterial roads categories is in line with State requests for a further reduction in the number of road categories. One can only assume that State and the Commonwealth interests in this regard are exactly the same, and consequently the values which the Commonwealth and State governments see in this kind of arrangement must be very real and are important in terms of getting value for each dollar. The arrangement is also consistent with the recommendation of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations that there should be only three road categories. The amalgamation of the two categories will provide the States with greater flexibility in the development and implementation of their overall road programs. However, it is just as well to mention that the Commonwealth has never been in a position to determine the overall funding split between rural and urban areas for arterial roads. The States, which provide the bulk of funds for arterial roads, have effectively determined this apportionment. That is in line with the general philosophy of this Government to encourage the widest possible local participation in decision making.

In respect of this general matter of adequacy of funds, I mention the remarks of Senator Bjelke-Petersen. Particularly she drew attention to the fact that Queensland could be lagging behind in terms of that State's proportion of the total split up for roads. It may be true that that does occur in several States. In fact, the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, is on the record as seeking the co-operation of other States in finding a new formula in this regard. He is calling for a statesman-like attitude on the part of all States to determine a new split up in this regard. There was one point that Senator Bjelke-Petersen made concerning a reference to a report of the Bureau of Transport Economics. Because the shortfall appeared to be the greatest in Queensland compared with any other State, she said that somehow indicated that Queensland was far worse off than many other States. I point out to her merely that that particular document deals with not just funds emanating from the Commonwealth in respect of roads in the various States but, more particularly, with the total funds coming from local government and States. Accordingly, one must read that as being a matter for the State determining its own sets of priorities and how it regards roads compared with other priorities in its expenditure.

As it is late and as I realise I am delaying the Senate I will deal finally with two other matters which Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentioned. She drew attention, I think quite rightly, to the fact that roads are an important national activity and, consequently, are the matters which this Government is interested in from the point of view of developing a defence capability. Of course, the Government is interested in ensuring that these things are done in co-operation with the States for the total economic and social benefit of the people living within those State boundaries. It goes without saying that although the funds available are never as great as one would like to spend in particular areas, this expenditure outlined in the legislation is consistent with the Government's general economic approach to ensure that inflation is continually kept on the down track and kept to a minimum so as to get the maximum benefit for all Australians. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gietzelt's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 12, clause 24, sub-clause (1), paragraph (a), lines 32 to 38, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

(a) that, where moneys paid to the State in accordance with the grant are required by virtue of this Act to be expended on the carrying out of an approved project by way of the construction of a national road, the State, in its discretion, may invite, and deal with, tenders for those works;

It is pretty obvious from the debate that took place towards the latter end of the second reading stage of the Roads Grants Bill 1981 that a number of Government senators had no understanding of what was entailed in this Bill, particularly as it relates to clause 24. It would appear that they did not hear the early part of the debate and therefore did not understand that there was unanimity on the part of the States about the issue of the States making their own decisions on public tendering for the construction of a main road. In her contribution, Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred to the communication that she had had from Mr Hinze, the appropriate Minister in Queensland. Senator McLaren referred to a Press statement issued by the South Australian Minister, Mr Wilson. I referred to the statement that had been issued by the Department of Main Roads in New South Wales. Of course, we had quite a prolonged debate, as we invariably do when the interests of Tasmania are at stake, by the various senators who seek to represent that State's views in this place.

Accordingly, I think I am entitled to say that Senator Archer misunderstands the intent of this Bill. Therefore, clause 24 ought to be amended if his interpretation has any relevance at all. We seek to give the discretion to the States to determine whether they will carry out their work programs by their own organisations or whether they will utilise the tendering system with private contractors. Clause 24, and the amendment that I seek to move on behalf of the Opposition, seeks to express confidence in the ability of the State Ministers to make that decision and exercise that discretion. The purpose of the amendment is so that the States may exercise their sovereignty and make their own decisions. Where, in their opinion, the work can more profitably and capably be carried out by their own day labour programs, they have the capacity to do so if the amendment that the Opposition is putting forward is adopted. Otherwise we would be entitled to say that the Commonwealth is taking the view that it has no confidence in the State road construction authorities in the six States of our Commonwealth. That is so because clause 24 (1) (a) of the Bill states that the procedure shall be done as approved by the Minister, that is, the Commonwealth Minister for Transport. There is no discretion available to the States to make any decision other than that of putting the job of construction work out to private tendering. The Opposition believes that that is a negation of the very policies that this Government claims to have in respect to its relationship with the States.

We heard a great deal about the centralist Government in Canberra when Mr Whitlam was the Prime Minister. The same criticism is being levelled now against the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by the Queensland Premier and other State Premiers of different political persuasion suggesting that the same centralist tendencies are appearing. Here is a clear example of this in clause 24 (1) (a) of the Bill, which provides that the Federal Minister will be the sole authority. The Opposition finds that untennable because it believes that the role of the Senate, as a States' House and House of review, is to protect the interests of the States. The Opposition amendment does precisely that. It establishes the discretion of the State Minister or the State Government, if it so desires, to invite tenders for any construction of a national road. If there is any integrity at all in our claim that we are representatives of the States then we are entitled to say that some mature consideration ought to be given to the amendment.

Having adopted the second reading of the main Bill, we say that the concern expressed by the work force in Tasmania is a concern expressed in every State of the Commonwealth. The telegrams and meetings referred to by Senator Harradine, Senator Grimes and Senator Rae have a basis in the fear that jobs may be at stake. If there is any downgrading of or reduction in the capacity of State construction authorities as a result of this legislation it stands to reason that the balance of the work will be thrown more and more into the private sector, making the public sector in the future perhaps incapable of carrying out its responsibilities.

Clause 24 (1) (a) makes this a very far-reaching piece of legislation. The Opposition shares the concern of the workers in Tasmania. I am talking now not only of the actual construction side but also the supervisory and professional sections of the work force as well as the views of the Tasmanian Government. I think it is proper that the Tasmanian Government should alert the work force to what is at stake if clause 24 (1) (a) is not amended. That same concern, of course, would be expressed in every other State of the Commonwealth, as it has been expressed by the responsible Minister in each of the States. We believe that, having adopted the second reading, we are entitled to expect this chamber to look at the Bill more carefully than perhaps it looked at the Opposition amendments in the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few matters I wish to raise. I make no apologies for raising them at this late hour. It is the Government's intention that we stop here all night. If we had decent sitting hours we would not be here now. One thing I want to take up with Senator Messner was the mention in his windup of the second reading debate that the South Australian Minister signified that he was quite happy with the arrangements. I remind Senator Messner of Mr Wilson's statement, as reported in the Advertiser on Saturday, 30 May-last Saturday. Mr Wilson said that South Australia was disadvantaged in its road grants allocation. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We are at least entitled to that percentage of the allocation which would increase our present share by $10.1m.
It is money South Australia is in need of and deserved.

That is quite the opposite of what Senator Messner has been telling the Senate tonight. He has said that Mr Wilson is quite happy with the deal he is getting under this Bill. As was pointed out in the second reading debate, no State government is satisfied with the deal that it will be getting under this Bill. That ought to be emphasised over and over again. Perhaps Senator Messner has received a communication from Mr Wilson that is at variance with the statement that he gave to the Advertiser last Saturday. It will be interesting to know whether that is the case. We can explore at a later stage whether the South Australian Minister of Roads is communicating one train of thought to this Government and is communicating another train of thought to the local Press in South Australia.

I have some questions to ask arising out of the Bill. I refer to clause 3, under the heading 'interpretation'. Clause 3(2) seeks to ensure that where standards have been notified to the Minister in respect of national roads a project must be carried out in accordance with the notified standards. Who will set the standards? Will the standards be identical in each State? What action can be taken against a State government if the notified standards are not carried out? I pose those questions because officers from the Department of Transport briefed the Opposition's transport committee last week and we were told that, under the block grants situation that is to operate, if private contractors are engaged to do certain work on roads and go bankrupt and the State then has to come in and spend more money on that particular road, which means that the State will run short of money for some other project for which it has programmed, that project would not be carried out. I will like to have that fact verified for the Hansard record. Also, if a road is not up to standard and more money has to be spent, does that mean that some road in that State will not be constructed that year?
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to speak at length. I think the Government is idiotic in trying to get legislation through at 2.30 a.m. For the first five weeks after the Senate resumed earlier this year there was virtually no work at all for it. For all practical purposes, honourable senators could have stayed at home because of the lack of work. But we know that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) lives in daily fear of what his own senators might do when they are in the States. I wish to make a couple of references in support of the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Gietzelt. In doing so, I wish to point to some of the anomalies that exist in Queensland at present. I can remember a National Party conference in Mt Isa not many years ago at which a decision was taken virtually to take legal action against the Queensland Government because of the neglect of roads in the far north, the central areas and north Queensland generally.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard Senator Bjelke-Petersen refer earlier tonight to the condition of roads in States under a Labor government. I point out to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who said that there are more large cities and towns in Queensland than there are in any other State, that those towns and cities were built up under previous Labor governments. The only ones that have been--

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—It is all right for Senator Bjelke-Petersen to interject, but the only towns and cities that have been built up since then are in the mining areas. In fact, a lot of the State funds go into road building to help the major mining companies. So there is a prostitution of the very principle of road building carried out by the State Government. This Bill will further aggravate that situation not only in the coming financial year but also in years to come until the situation can be changed by a Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: I travelled over the Bruce Highway during the wet. I know that some of my colleagues on the other side of the House waited until the rain stopped. I include the Premier of Queensland who would not go out to have a look at the roads until the rain had stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —He goes by aeroplane.

—That is right. There is a famous cartoon relating to the time before the Flinders Highway was built. It depicts the Premier flying across in his aeroplane and saying: 'I don't know what you are all whinging about, it is quite comfortable to travel over'. The Premier had his own plane, he was able to do this. The plane was paid for by the taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I really want to make is that funding in Queensland is being misused. We have what is known as the Kingaroy line. All the good roads are south of that line. I refer to roads in the remote areas such as the Bynol Road from Normanton to Burketown and on to Camooweal and the section of Highway 1 that runs from Burketown to Doomadgee where the bulldust is three feet deep. That is where we can see the necessity for building roads. We have tried to get a bitumen surface for the road from Gilbert River to Normanton. We have not been able to get it.

The Burke Shire is one of the most neglected shires of Queensland. The roads there are almost impassable even in the best of weather. When the Whitlam Government was funding local shires direct with untied grants for the purpose of road construction a real amount of progress was made. Many of those local shires bought their own heavy equipment so that in fact, they could do main roads work as well as look after their shires. There was a tremendous improvement. When the Fraser Government took over much of that heavy equipment became quite obsolete because there was no use for it.

I do not criticise the speech that Senator Bjelke-Petersen made tonight. It is obvious that she has been directed either by Mr Hinze-without his '57 varieties'-or by her husband to vote against the amendment and to support the Bill in this House. We cannot have it two ways. When the suggestions were made originally the States cried like-I will not use a rude word. The States put on a very good stage performance. The only States that are sticking with us now in our attitude to the recommendations not only of the razor gang but also those made in other areas are Tasmania and New South Wales. I can imagine people, if they want to be hypocrites, saying certain things outside. We used to have a senator in this place who had a great record of voting against the motion that a Bill be read a second time but who always, when it came to the crunch, voted with the Government on the motion that the Bill be read a third time. He did this about 459 times over a period of years. He voted with the Opposition at the second reading stage but he was always with the Government when it came to the final reading and the passing of the legislation. There is no room in politics for hypocrisy. We seem to have a great deal of it in this country at present. It is starting right here in this chamber and in the other place. Statements are made which are critical of legislation that is projected or actually passed by the Government. When the crunch comes there is nothing but support from those people who do their crying outside.

TALK.START.PARA: —I interrupt for a moment. The question before the Committee is that the words proposed to be left out be left out. I ask the honourable senator to come back to that matter.
—That's not important at this hour.

—I am. I felt that there were a couple of points that I should have raised. As my colleague, Senator Cavanagh, said, the real importance is, I suppose, that if we are going to be idiotic enough to stay here until daylight then Government members have to do that too. I hope that this will be the final night when we sit to this hour. I support the amendment that has been moved by my colleague, Senator Gietzelt. I felt that it was necessary in supporting that amendment to add those other points in relation to the unfair distribution of the Commonwealth road grants that were given to Queensland in the first place. The most neglected zone is the northern zone, the central zone comes next and the rest of it goes into the area south of the Kingaroy line.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that I want to make relates to the allocation of money for subsidies to transport in Queensland. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is on record as having an overseeing role in the area of transport, including road construction. Any city which has a population of over 40,000 people is entitled to a subsidy. Mr Temporary Chairman, I can see your look of whimsy, but I am about to close off after I have said a few more words so you will not have to pull me into line again. This year money was taken by the Bjelke-Peterson Government and put into the electrification of the Brisbane metropolitan area. It was a job which was stopped by the National Country Party Government immediately after its election to office in 1957, when materials, sheds and other equipment were sold off to friends. Consequently, we did not go ahead with the electrification of the railway line when it would have cost only a very small amount. Now it is a major job. So money that should come to Townsville to assist with public transport is going to the electrification scheme in Brisbane. I support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly to Senator McLaren's questions. Firstly, I refer to Mr Wilson's remarks. During my comments I referred to his earlier comments-that is Mr Wilson's comments-with regard to tendering, not with regard to the total funding arrangements. I do not recall seeing the article in the Advertiser.
—I will show it to you if you like.

—I thank the honourable senator very much. If Mr Wilson made that claim I imagine it was made against the background of the present situation as set out in the legistion. As I pointed out earlier the question that is open for debate at the moment with the States relates to the formula arrangements which are yet to be settled. Of course those will be the topping-up arrangements in terms of further funding. In respect of the question that Senator McLaren asked about clause 3, of who sets the standards, again this is an example of the co-operative arrangements between the States and the Federal Government. They will be undertaken at officer level in discussions with the States and approved finally by the Federal Minister. Of course the emphasis is on the word 'approved' so naturally there will be consultative and negotiating processes going on earlier in order to determine those standards which are acceptable, I hope, to the States as a whole. Finally, the Government does not accept the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt.
—Why?
—For the arguments which were outlined in my speech at the end of the second reading debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the answers he has given me, to a point, but he did not answer fully the questions that I asked. One question that he omitted to answer was: What action can be taken if the notified standards are not carried out? That matter is of great concern if this amount of money is to be expended. I point out that again we have the contradiction and I referred to it in relation to the Minister's second reading speech in which he said that he had consulted with State Ministers and that consultations had yet to be carried out and certain things had yet to be worked out. Tonight the Minister confirmed that the standards have yet to be worked out, so again we have a very glaring anomaly in the Minister's second reading speech and it is spelt out in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to another matter about which we are concerned and I am sure Mr Wilson is concerned about it. He referred to it in an article in the Advertiser of last Saturday. I refer honourable senators to Schedule 1 which relates to finance. We all know that inflation is not coming down, it is going up. In the last Budget we were told that it was to be 10 per cent this year. We now know that it will be 11 per cent, if not higher. An amount of $27,240,000 is appropriated and that will be paid to South Australia. That is the only State in which I am interested. Honourable senators from the other States can speak for themselves. For the year commencing July 1982 we have a similar amount as for July 1981, but for the year commencing 1 July 1983 the amount is $19,068,000. So there is a drop of $8,172,000 in the two-year period from 1 July this year to 1 July 1983 in payments to South Australia, yet the rate of inflation will increase. South Australia will be placed at a distinct disadvantage, and I take it that that is what Mr Wilson is complaining about. I find it very hard to understand why the Minister said that Mr Wilson is quite happy with what is going on. I am sure that he is not happy. As Senator Gietzelt pointed out in his speech on the motion for the second reading of the Bill, every State Government has lodged a protest with its senators and members of the House of Representatives pleading with them to reject the legislation. Every State has done that, yet Senator Messner said tonight that the South Australian Minister is quite happy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you read the statement?
—I have no need to read the statement. I read the second reading speech. I am basing my argument now on the answer given by the Minister.
—The facts will only confuse you.

—The facts will not confuse me. If they are confusing me they have certainly confused Mr Wilson. Mr Wilson is on record in the Adelaide Advertiser, which was known for many years as the Liberal Party Bible in South Australia-it gave it a much better go than it gives the Labor Party-as complaining about this matter. The headline states: 'Grants to South Australia down'. Those are the Minister's own words. I will stand corrected if Mr Wilson made a further statement in the Advertiser on Monday or yesterday or today. I saw no repudiation of that statement. He must agree with it or he would have been quick smart to say that he had been misquoted. Yet the Minister has told us here tonight that Mr Wilson is happy. I am sure the Minister will keep on saying that so I will not pursue it, but it is now on the record. I still want an answer about what action can be taken by the Federal Government if the roads standards, to which the Minister has referred as being agreed to by advisers and then put to the various Ministers, are not maintained. What action can be taken to see that the taxpayers do not lose money to private contractors?

SPEECH.PARA: When we were in government in South Australia we could not get money from the Feds to construct the Eyre Highway, which is a national road and should have been funded by the Commonwealth Government. Menzies, McMahon and Gorton did nothing about it, and it was left to the Dunstan Government to use State finances to fund the road. At that time we did not have the necessary machinery and we engaged private contractors. What happened to them? They went broke, and the taxpayers had to turn around and foot the bill twice over. This is what we are afraid will happen under the regulations in this Bill requiring compulsory tendering for all works on national roads. That is what we are concerned about, and I want to know what action can be taken if the standards are not met. If after constructon of the road has started we then find that some private contractor has been taking short cuts, who will foot the Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to Senator McLaren's question is that this is a cause, if you like, which needs to be satisfied ahead of the funding for national highways being made available by the Federal Government to the States. As to the question of the standards which are to be applied, naturally this would be set out in the specifications for individual roads and is in accordance with the general standards which the Federal Government would have arranged previously through consultations at various levels and in respect of particular kinds of roads. Consequently, providing those specifications are met, the funds would be made available.

—That is the very point of my question. What will happen if the specifications are not met after construction of the road begins? For the first few weeks of construction of some miles of road the specifications might be complied with, but what would the situation be if a contractor who has put in a very low tender starts to lose money and then begins to cut corners, as we know contractors do? The Minister would know from his own experience in South Australia what happened when the tender was let to private contractors to construct the high voltage power line to the south-east. When the first big blow came, lots of the high tensions power lines and pylons blew over. When an examination was made of the concrete mix, it was found that the private contractors had not been putting the required amount of concrete in the mix. This is the sort of thing I am concerned about here.

—I thought Senator McLaren would have appreciated that in the event of a breach of contract by a contractor in circumstances such as that, where these matters are set out in the specifications, obviously the contractor would be liable to be sued by the Government for recovery of those funds which might have been wrongfully spent. Consequently, the taxpayer would be safeguarded in the normal way. These are normal commercial principles which the State Government would be responsible to negotiate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the words of the Minister. I support Senator McLaren in his objections to this matter. During the period of the Moore Government in Queensland from 1922 to 1931 this is exactly what happened.
