Contracts were let to companies without substance because they happened to be friends of somebody-a government Minister or someone else in a high place. A job on a stretch of road just south of Rockhampton in Queensland was let out to one of the private tenderers. It turned out that he did not have the equipment to do the job and when his company spread the bitumen, it did not even bother to smooth out the corrugations in the road. So there was this rippled road there for many years afterwards. As a matter of fact, it has been repaired only in recent years when the road in that area was reconstructed. It goes without saying-I have seen this happen-that when a company goes bankrupt the Government can sue for all it likes but it will not get the money back for the taxpayers. These companies will declare themselves bankrupt and like a couple of building companies floating around this country, they will surface again under another name and catch the taxpayer again. The Minister's remarks are so much poppycock. He cannot prove what he has said. This is exactly what will happen when the Government starts letting out all these contracts to people who are ill equipped financially to be able to carry out the work. What the Minister has said tonight has no substance to it. If he stays in government long enough he will reap the benefits, and they will not be nice.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gietzelt's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want clarification on clause 21. It states that the Minister may require a State to give certain information. But, in other parts of the Bill, we find that the Minister may request. I raised that matter with the officers who attended our Caucus committee. I was told that that could have been a clerical error. I want it verified and put on record. It seems to me that we see that the provision of the Bill are at odds. In one provision in the Bill, the Minister may require a State government to do certain things. Yet the explanation of clause 24 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This clause provides that payment of an amount to a State for national roads is conditional upon:-
(b) the State complying with a request on . . .
(d) the State complying with requests . . .

I want to know why the Bill is drawn with those two differences. Why is it not that the Minister has the power to require in all instances rather than in some instances and then makes a request in other instances? In my view, there is no need for the request to be complied with in some cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite clear on the point that Senator McLaren raised. I am not sure which set of words in clause 24 he was referring to.

—Perhaps I can enlighten the Minister. It is in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. In the first instance it is on page 11 under clause 21 which empowers the Minister to require. On page 12 we find under clause 24-'Additional Conditions for National Roads Projects'-the words 'request' and 'requests' are used in respect of sub-clause (b) and sub-clause (d) respectively.
—I believe Senator McLaren was making the point that he had been advised by officials in his caucus background briefing in this matter that 'requests' means the same as 'requires' and consequently--
—Don't give us that.
—I understood from what Senator McLaren was saying that that was the point he was making and he was seeking confirmation of that.
—No. I did not say that.
—I believe that is the case. It is on the record that there is no difference in the interpretation in each particular case.
—Surely one is mandatory and the other is a request that can be accepted or rejected. We cannot let the Minister get away with that.
—Do you wish to respond, Senator Messner?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Messner

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my practice to speak on the third reading of a Bill. It is always claimed by honourable senators opposite that this is a States House and that they are free agents to vote according to their own wishes. We have clear evidence here that this is not a States House. We on this side of the chamber all know from the record that every State government in this Commonwealth has requested their senators to reject the Roads Grants Bill. Government senators had the courage to do it. So much for the Senate being a States House. I think that that should be put on the record. Whenever these people go out on the hustings in election campaigns and try to fool the people, that they are free agents and are not bound by policy, they need to be reminded that there is clear evidence again here tonight, in the way in which they voted, that this is not a States House. As I have said on many occasions, it is a political House and is used as such. Nobody should ever be fooled into thinking that it is a States House. It is no such thing.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Senate adjourned at 3.1 a.m. (Thursday)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the recommendations 1 to 27 contained in the report by a Departments of Labour Advisory Committee Working Party on 'Prospective Demand for a Supply of Skilled Labour 1980-83 with Particular Reference to Major Development Projects', have been implemented, which are intended to be implemented, and which are not to be implemented in 1981.
(2) What will be the cost of implementing each separate recommendation.
(3) What is the projected increase in employment of implementing each recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The recommendations of the DOLAC Working Party already implemented include maintenance of the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme (Recommendation 1), national promotion campaign (Recommendation 2), action to increase apprenticeship training in Commonwealth Government departments and agencies (Recommendation 3), provision of the CRAFT $1,000 employer cash rebate in respect of trades in short supply (Recommendation 4), support for group apprenticeship (Recommendation 9) and recommendations relating to statistics and machinery for regular assessment of the labour requirements of major development projects (Recommendations 15, 17 and 18). The implementation of the remaining recommendations is dependent upon the outcome of discussions with State authorities and with both sides of industry.

(2) It is not possible to provide information on the cost of implementing each of the 27 recommendations, as many have no discernible expenditure implications or their costs are interrelated. Those for which costs can be identified include the trade training promotional campaign at over $400,000 and the $1,000 Employer Cash Rebate Scheme for the metal, electrical and building trades, estimated at over $7m.

(3) The recommendations in the report are directed not only at expanding the volume of apprentice training in skills in short supply but also at the quality of that training. On the basis of preliminary figures, apprenticeship intakes in the first 9 months of the current financial year show an increase on the record levels achieved in the comparable period in 1979-80.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are rabbit populations in all States increasing dramatically.
(2) What funds are currently available for rabbit control research by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization and what programs are involved.
(3) Are there any current State research programs on rabbit control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. I am advised that rabbits continue to be an important pest of Australian agriculture. The elements within my portfolio do not have a responsibility to monitor trends in the size of rabbit populations in the States and are unable to provide that information. It is the prerogative of the States, through their vertebrate pest control authorities, to carry out such monitoring. They are in a better position to give some indication of recent fluctuations in rabbit populations that occur from year to year and from region to region within a State depending largely on climate, food supply and the effects of predators and control measures.
2. In CSIRO, expenditure by the Division of Wildlife Research on research related directly to control of rabbits was $585,777 in 1979-80 and in 1980-81 is expected to be at least $600,000.
The research is designed to provide a detailed understanding of rabbit biology and rabbit populations and thereby a sound basis for the development of improved strategies and tactics of control.
Currently the research projects are:

(a) Studies in population ecology, especially the effects of various environmental factors, such as heat and predation, on the size of rabbit populations in arid and semi-arid areas where myxomatosis occurs only infrequently and where severe damage is caused to vegetation when favourable seasons favour rapid increases in numbers of rabbits;

(b) biological control of rabbits by myxomatosis. As a basis for understanding long-term trends in the effectiveness of myxomatosis as a control measure and for recommending efficient strategic use of the disease, the development of genetic resistance to the disease is being measured. Field work is being carried out on the introduction of various strains of myxomatosis virus and on their spread and impact in rabbit populations which have a high degree of genetic resistance to myxomatosis. Comparisons are being made of naturally occurring and deliberately initiated outbreaks of myxomatosis in rabbit populations infested with the European rabbit flea;

(c) studies of the olfactory processes used by rabbits in communication. Odours derived from various skin glands serve for the identification of individuals and groups, and affect behaviour. An understanding of the basic biology of these processes may ultimately provide a basis for improvement in control techniques, particularly poisoning;

(d) effects on non-target species of poisons used in pest control. This is a long-term study of the effects on native and other non-target species of the poison 1080 which is widely used in rabbit control operations.

3. Vertebrate pest control authorities in some of the States have current programs of research on rabbit control. Many of the results of these programs are made available through publication in scientific journals. They are also discussed at Australian Vertebrate Pest Control Conferences convened at intervals of about five years under the aegis of the Standing Committee of the Australian Agricultural Council. The Standing Committee also has a Vertebrate Pests Committee which meets annually and provides a forum for discussion between the various vertebrate pest control authorities about research being undertaken. The Committee comprises representatives of such authorities from the States and Territories, together with appropriate Commonwealth Departments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the high cost of the recently announced telephone aids for disabled people put the aids beyond the reach of most disabled people.

(2) Is the Minister for Social Security aware of a report in the Canberra Times of 14 April 1981, which states that applications for financial assistance to purchase an aid should be made to the Department of Social Security.

(3) Has the Department of Social Security made provision for assistance of this nature; if so, what are the details and if no provision has been made by the Department what channels are available for disabled people seeking financial assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no reliable statistics available to indicate the numbers or the incomes of disabled people who may require these aids. It may be held, however, that people wholly or substantially dependent on pension or equivalent payments may face difficulties in meeting the costs associated with such aids.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. The Department of Social Security has not made specific provision for assistance of this nature to disabled people in general.

The assistance referred to in the Canberra Times article would seem to relate to that available through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) which is administered by my Department under Part VIII of the Social Services Act. Through the CRS, eligible disabled people may be provided with necessary aids, appliances and modifications (including telephone aids) as part of a total rehabilitation program. Eligibility for rehabilitation assistance free of charge applies to disabled people from within the broad working age group who are likely to gain substantial benefit from the rehabilitation programs offered.
